Brina Merilis came in with the whole damn Legion and deposed Skald. Couldn't have happened to a better man.
If you don't mind digging, I own the Quicksilver Mine. It's a better life than working in that damned Iron-Breaker Mine with all those milk drinkers.
Good luck.
It was supposed to be an honor, but very well.
Giants are a common problem in the Pale. The Empire always demanded I leave them be, but the Empire isn't here now.
Go and slay one of the beasts. It should let them know that Dawnstar is not to be trifled with.
I'm counting on you.
You don't have time? Fine.
You've shown those monsters that they will no longer be tolerated in the Pale. Good work.
Here, a reward from your Jarl.
If you've got an axe, you can always make gold chopping wood. Just bring me everything you cut.
That I am. My father left it to me after he died in that Great War against the Elves.
I don't care what's going on in the world. Rebellion. Dragons awakening. The mill is enough trouble for me to worry about.
How the tree came to grow there is a bit of a mystery...
Some say that when Vvardenfell erupted, a piece was blown to the middle of Skyrim and from the crater grew the tree.
I've also heard that it was a spore that fell from an island floating in the sky, but that just sounds like nonsense.
All I know is that the sap makes you feel as healthy as a cave troll, but slow as a drunk horker. And that and it fetches good coin.
Well met, hunter.
No? Well, then she hasn't gotten to you yet. But she will. And you don't you believe a word of it.
Oh she will, mark my words. And don't you let her.
Shop at Belethor's for the best prices and selection. He pays me to say that.
Hm hmm.
We done?
Best if... you didn't mention to anyone that you saw me here.
I've said too much already.
Remember - don't trust the Imperials. No matter what honeyed lies they tell you.
Live long. Fight well.
You take care of yourself, now.
If you need any jewelry, just let me know.
If you need a drink, just holler.
Yeah, take care.
Come back anytime if you need a remedy.
Do forget to see me at my shop sometime - Arcadia's Cauldron.
Stay out of trouble.
Keep your nose clean.
Need anything else, just let me know.
I think I've got some mugs need scrubbin'.
Goodbye, dear.
Is it cold in here? I should put more wood on the fire...
Now please, no more questions.
If there's nothing else, I have work to do...
You should buy some produce from Carlotta's stall. Most of it comes from my farm.
You should stop by my farm if you get a chance. See what life's really about.
It's the leaving that's hardest, I know.
Some parting advice - women love sonnets.
Yeah, take care of yourself.
Do come back.
Remember, I'll give you the best deals, or die trying.
Next time, come see my at my shop. I've got some things you'll just love.
Good doin' business with ya.
We'll have to have a pint together sometime, you and me.
Good hunting.
Remember, I've got the freshest meat in all of Whiterun.
Right. Till next time.
Thank you very much for your business.
Farewell.
I was done talkin' anyway.
You go on your way now, boy.
You go on your way now, girl.
Farewell, my lady.
Farewell, sir.
Take care.
You watch yourself out there.
Keep your eyes open for those Stormcloak dogs, yeah?
Do be careful, child. Skyrim is not as safe as it used to be.
By the way, you might want to stop in at Warmaiden's. These days, folk need all the protection they can get.
Long live the Empire.
The Stormcloaks are living on borrowed time, believe me.
May your sword be sharp, and your tongue sharper.
Keep a song in your heart, and a blade in your boot.
It's back to work, then.
I'll see you.
Yes, yes. Goodbye.
May all your possible futures be bright.
Remember, fresh fruit and vegetables every day. Mostly.
Thanks for the business.
I've really got to be going.
I think I hear my daughter calling...
Goodbye, ma'am.
Goodbye, sir.
May Talos guide you. Always.
Stay vigilant! Our enemies are legion!
Goodbye. And if you happen to see Mikael, tell him I was asking about him...
Farewell.
See you.
Right, then.
Hmm hmm.
We done?
Finally. I got stuff to do, ya know.
Back to my book...
Damn it, I lost my page...
The blessing of Arkay be upon you.
Walk always in the light, in these days of darkness.
Sure. Whatever.
Bye, now.
Don't let the door slam into your backside on the way out.
Now if ya don't mind, my house could do with a bit of dusting.
Grace of Kynareth be with you.
Travel great Skyrim, and Kynareth travels with you.
You need to be careful in this city. Never know who you can trust, these days.
Goodbye, dear.
Right, I really am busy. So...
If there's nothing else, I really do have important matters tend to.
If you run into my husband Nazeem, remind him that he's not married to himself.
Take care of yourself.
You know, if you've got the aptitude, you should join the Mages College in Winterhold...
Remember, your mind is the best weapon you have.
Stay sharp.
Don't forget to check inside the shop if you need anything.
Thanks for the business.
Enjoy your visit to Dragonsreach.
If there's any more I can help you with, just let me know.
Next time, deal with Avenicci.
Now if you don't mind, I've got a city to keep.
Maybe we'll meet in the field. Just pray we're on the same side.
If you run into any Stormcloaks, kill a dozen for me.
I've got my eyes on you.
Mind yourself in front of the Jarl, or we'll have serious problems.
Ride strong.
You always keep us in mind when you need a fresh horse, yeah?
Uh huh.
Back to work, I guess. There's never a shortage of dung to shovel around here.
Good. Chat time's over.
Yeah, whatever.
Please, leave me to recover my... mental energies.
Riften's biggest exports used to be fishing and honey, until the Black-Briar family moved in. Now the meadery is the biggest game in town.
The Thieves Guild has been pushing hard to regain a foothold in this city. Rumor has it they're falling apart from the inside.
The city guard has been tearing Riften apart looking for the source of our skooma problem. I'd hate to be in their shoes if they get discovered.
Sibbi Black-Briar is furious that his ex-lover tried to murder him. He's leaving no stone unturned searching for her.
Mjoll the Lioness used to adventure across Skyrim before she settled down in Riften. I hear it all ended when she lost her enchanted blade.
Crime is at an all-time high in this city thanks to the Thieves Guild. Don't we have enough problems with the war going on?
If Maven Black-Briar keeps raising prices on mead, I'll have to resort to watering it down just to make ends meet.
If it's true that the dragons have returned, what will it mean for all of us? Is this how it all ends?
They mean to take our history and crush it all in the name of some damn treaty.
The soil beneath our feet is steeped in the blood of our ancestors. We've fought for this land and... died for it.
I lost my own daughter to the Imperial dogs, and by Talos I'll not lose anyone else!
Talos is part of our culture. He's part of our heritage and our tradition. He's Skyrim personified.
To suddenly have all that wrenched away is like losing someone you hold dearly in your heart.
The Empire already took my daughter from us, but by Talos they will not take our homeland!
Lilija joined the Stormcloaks many years ago, when the first of the skirmishes broke out across Skyrim. I was so proud of her.
She served as a Battle Maiden, using her healing arts to help those that fell on the battlefield. Never even lifted a blade in her life.
It didn't matter. The Imperial soldiers cut her down... killed her like a dog and left her body to rot in the mud.
And that's why I won't rest easy until every single Imperial soldier joins her, and Ulfric sits upon the throne of Skyrim.
I trained our daughter Lilija as a healer... to one day tend the Shrine of Talos and replace me as a Priestess of Talos.
When the fighting began over the White-Gold Concordat, she ran off to join the Stormcloaks. She had her father's fire, how could I say no?
She died out there, only having tended to the wounded soldiers for a few months. We never even found her body... the Empire burned all the dead.
It was my sister, Lilija. She served as a Battle Maiden with the Stormcloaks.
We recently heard she'd been killed... I... I find it difficult to talk about. Perhaps you'd be better off speaking to my parents about it.
Anyway, I'm glad my work at the Black-Briar Meadery keeps me busy. Helps me keep my mind off of things.
My father was a Stormcloak soldier in his younger days. Now he just walks the streets spewing his hatred and propaganda.
My mother is the Priestess of Talos. She tends to the shrine and teaches his ways. I'm just not so sure she's delivering the right message.
Sorry, fresh out. Maybe next time.
Absolutely. Did you still want to buy one?
Nothing but the best. Black-Briar Mead... fresh from the vat.
Best of all, you don't have to pay the ridiculous prices Maven charges. So what do you say to that?
Here you go. Oh, and keep it quiet. This stuff isn't exactly easy to get a hold of at these prices, if you catch my drift.
Suit yourself. If you change your mind, I'll be around.
Sure. How do you think I get my hands on the good stuff and offer it so cheap? You think old Maven is just giving it away to anyone?
Good thing she makes so much money. Makes it easier for merchandise like this to fall through the cracks.
Take this with our gratitude.
I've seen documents dating back to the late Second Era. Beyond that, it's hard to say.
Events in the last several hundred years resulted in a significant loss of our history, I'm afraid.
The Great Collapse, as it has come to be known.
An unfortunate natural disaster that ravaged the area. The College fared far better than the city of Winterhold, but it was not left untouched.
No one is sure of the cause. Some believed the eruption of Red Mountain had far-reaching consequences that were only felt years later.
I know there are some who have blamed the College, said that we were responsible. I assure you this is not the case.
Oh, the Hagraven feather and so on. You can throw all those out.  You see...
Damn! This place is coming down! Quick, get the Skeleton Key and the Eye and lets get out of here!
No luck there, lass. Something must have fallen on the other side of the door because it isn't moving!
We have to find another way out of here before the place fills with water!
Crystal....  gone...
[coughing]
Find... Paratus... in Oculory...
What brings you, wayfarer grim, to wander here, in Sovngarde, souls-end, Shor's gift to honored dead?
Beware! The World-Eater waits within the mist!
There is no escape. Courage is useless.
None may pass this perilous bridge 'til I judge them worthy by the warrior's test.
Living or dead, by decree of Shor, none may pass this perilous bridge 'til I judge them worthy by the warrior's test.
Yamarz has demanded we stay inside the walls. We cannot leave.
I must petition Malacath for relief. This curse must be lifted.
But I cannot travel to Malacath's shrine. The ritual must be done here, and I do not have the materials I need.
I beg of you, can you bring me Troll Fat and a Daedra Heart? I have no wish to depend on a stranger, but I have no choice.
Lost it? Well, at least you showed signs of initiative by telling me.
I guess I shouldn't be surprised with the way things are going around here.
Someone lied. Someone told the guard poor Cicero did something he did not. We were detained, delayed! The Night Mother kept from her new home!
But you wouldn't know anything about that, would you? Hmmm? No. No... Of course not. Because then Cicero would get angry, and that would be... ugly.
Now Loreius. Loreius has learned the meaning of ugly.
I'll go back to the Orphanage in a while. I'll give them time to, you know... clean up the mess.
When I grow up, I'm going to be an assassin. That way I can help lots of children, just like you.
You came to visit! It's so much better here with Grelod gone. Thanks to you.
I am Sanguine, Daedric Prince of Debauchery!
I know, I know, how could I lie to you? Well, how could I trust you until we've shared a few drinks?
But it wasn't long before I realized you'd make a more interesting bearer of my not-quite-holy staff than this waste of flesh.
Details, details. The Sanguine Rose breaks all the time and is fixed with but a thought.
In fact, here it is now. Think of it - a never-ending stream of minions. And all of the prestige of being Sanguine's chosen.
Ha ha ha ha ha ha ha!
Calcelmo's orders- no one gets through to the tower. Kill any intruders on sight. Call for backup if you need to.
Azura has given me the gift of foresight. I had a vision of you walking up the steps to this altar long before you were born.
You have been chosen to be her champion. I know it is unexpected, but do not worry. It will all unfold as she has predicted.
You must go to a fortress, endangered by water, yet untouched by it.
Inside, you will find an elven mage who can turn the brightest star as black as night.
It is cryptic, I know, but Azura's signs are never wrong. I believe the fortress may refer to Winterhold. Ask if they know this elven enchanter.
I've been looking for you.
Thank you for coming.
Sigrid! Love of my life! When you get a spare moment, I could use some water.
Don't you sweet talk me, Alvor. Not after last night. I'll bring you water when I'm done with my other chores.
Woman, you'll be the death of me yet. Fine, take your time. I'll just die of thirst in the heat of this forge.
Care to have a drink with me, sweet Sigrid?
Drunk again, Embry? Don't let Alvor hear you talking to me that way. He'll stick your head in his forge.
So that's a no I take it?
It seems like Dorthe grows a head taller every season.
Aye. She's helping me in the house, and even helps her father at the forge.
She'll make a fine wife someday.
Thank Shor I have a lot of years before I have to worry about that!
Please! Release me! Cut my bonds!
You cut these bindings this minute! You hear me? You cut these bindings right now!
Come now, my friend. Haven't we played this game long enough? Untie me, and we can all go our separate ways.
Thank you! Thank you! I'll never speak of this to anyone, I promise!
Well it's about damn time. Capturing a woman from her home, keeping her bound like an animal. Ridiculous...
Ah, you see? That wasn't so hard, now was it? Let's the two of us just forget we ever met, hmm?
He is our creator and master. The Daedric Lord of the Sworn Oath and the Bloody Curse.
Malacath teaches us to honor all words with action. To demand blood from your enemies and strength from your allies.
He watches over all Orcs as his children. A truth those who leave the stronghold are quick to forget.
The Code of Malacath. It is both tradition and law in the strongholds. Break the code, and you must pay Blood Price.
The code is not written anywhere. It is known and carried on by the Orcs, and all who live in the strongholds follow it.
For an outlander, following it is simple. Do not steal or attack anyone in the stronghold, or be ready to pay in gold or blood.
It is said that an Orc first learns to wield a hammer in her mother's womb.
By tradition, a mother always teaches her children how to smith. If a chief has a second wife, she is called the [QUOTE]Forge-wife[QUOTE] in honor of this.
We have lived in Skyrim since before the Nords came. Our way is simple, all work to make the tribe strong.
Only the bravest are allowed to lead, and to marry. A great chief is able to attract many wives and raise bold children.
Wise women like myself are mothers of chieftains. We guide the tribe and advice our kin on what is most pleasing to Malacath.
I thought you might not remember your first trip here. You had a big night. I think you've definitely earned the staff.
You should try that bit on the barkeep. Maybe get yourself a free drink.
That amount should allow me to readily acquire a drink.
I'll be at the market come morning. You better be there too.
I'm ready when you are. Just give the word.
Aventus Aretino. He was sent to live here after his mother died. He escaped. And...
Before he left, he said he was going to do the Black Sacrament. You know, to call the Dark Brotherhood. So they'd come and kill old Grelod!
Word out on the street is that he went home to Windhelm, and people have heard strange chanting coming from his house. He's really doing it!
Aventus Aretino. He was sent to live here after his mother died. He escaped. And...
Before he left, he said he was going to do the Black Sacrament. You know, to call the Dark Brotherhood. So they'd come and kill old Grelod!
Word out on the street is that he went home to Windhelm, and people have heard strange chanting coming from his house. Looks like he really did it!
A little boy who lived here. Aventus Aretino. He was nice, but really quiet, and sad, because his mother just died.
He ran away. Back home to Windhelm. Samuel told me he's trying to get some murderer people to come here and kill Grelod. I really hope he does.
A little boy who lived here. Aventus Aretino. He was nice, but really quiet, and sad, because his mother just died.
He ran away. Back home to Windhelm. Samuel told me he was trying to get some murderer people to come here and kill Grelod. Did he really do it?
Oh, Aventus Aretino. He was sent here when his mother died, but he ran away.
I heard he went back to his house in Windhelm, and is trying to get the Dark Brotherhood to come and murder Grelod. That would be so wonderful.
Oh, Aventus Aretino. He was sent here when his mother died, but he ran away.
I heard he went back to his house in Windhelm, to try and get the Dark Brotherhood to come and murder Grelod. And... he actually pulled it off!
Aventus Aretino? He only lived here for awhile. I think his mother got sick and died or something. Anyway, he's gone now. He ran away.
But Samuel told me he's back home in Windhelm, and is doing some kind of dark ritual. He's trying to summon some killers to come get old Grelod.
Aventus Aretino? He only lived here for awhile. I think his mother got sick and died or something. Anyway, he's gone now. He ran away.
But Samuel told me he's back home in Windhelm, and did some kind of dark ritual. He summoned killers to murder old Grelod. He's saved us all.
And one more thing! I will hear no more talk of adoptions! None of you riff-raff is getting adopted. Ever! Nobody needs you, nobody wants you.
That, my darlings, is why you're here. Why you will always be here, until the day you come of age and get thrown into that wide, horrible world.
Now, what do you all say?
We love you, Grelod. Thank you for your kindness.
We love you, Grelod. Thank you for your kindness.
We love you, Grelod. Thank you for your kindness.
We love you, Grelod. Thank you for your kindness.
Those who shirk their duties will get an extra beating. Do I make myself clear?
Yes, Grelod.
Yes, Grelod.
Yes, Grelod.
Yes, Grelod.
That's better. Now scurry off, my little guttersnipes.
I'm lucky enough that none of my friends have been killed. Of course we have soldiers coming through all the time.
Those falls... dangerous place. Derkeethus thought he could find some good fish in the pools.
Haven't heard from him in a long while.
Not much to it, really. We fish, and keep to ourselves. Try to keep from upsetting the Empire or the Stormcloaks, and so far the war's left us alone.
A bunch of lazy rabble trying to make a living. Can't get better workers in because everyone's afraid of the tomb up above the mine.
Dead dragons... it hasn't moved since Ysgramor and it's not going to start now. Superstitious milk drinkers.
So it seems the milk drinkers were right. That dragon was nearly the death of us.
All we can do now is rebuild.
We got the mill up and running before we found out that the big stand of trees on the hill was sacred.
Now we can't cut them, and can't afford to buy another mill somewhere else.
So we scrounge whatever we can from around the tundra.
A lifetime of study, you might say. The best comes from Riften, but I haven't been there in years.
Ever tried making your own? It's... not easy. Trust me.
Not at all. I consider it a blessing.
My family was convinced coming here was a death sentence, or worse. It took years of insisting that this is what I'm meant to do.
Mages in Cyrodiil are all about politics. The Synod and the College of Whispers are too busy guarding secrets to bother to teach.
Skyrim was not J'zargo's first choice, but Winterhold is removed from politics, dedicated to study. This is the place for J'zargo to become great.
So far, if only because no one is telling me how great I ought to be.
I just want to learn, I don't want to think about what's expected of me.
Mutual advantage! Any fool can see that.
For centuries, we have benefited from the Empire's protection, and prosperous trade with the south.
In exchange, the people of Cyrodiil sleep peacefully, knowing their northern border is guarded by the fiercest warriors in all Tamriel.
And here you go... your payment, just as I promised.
The way things have been going around here, it's a relief that our plan went off without a hitch.
I didn't think you'd get pinched.
Can't say I'm surprised with the way things have been going around here.
Magic is shunned by most. If it can't be swung over your head and used to crack skulls, most Nords want nothing to do with it.
Magic is seen as something for elves, and weaker races.
Not at all. I consider it a blessing.
My family was convinced coming here was a death sentence, or worse. It took years of insisting that this is what I'm meant to do.
Well, look at the evidence. Nords generally don't trust magic, so it's not off to a good start.
Throw in the Oblivion Crisis, which was caused by magic-users, and the troubles now with the Aldmeri Dominion, who are elves and magic users.
And finally take the fact that the College is the only thing left standing after most of Winterhold was destroyed. It's all fairly damning.
Well, that depends on what you're looking for.
Faralda can teach Destruction spells, and offers training in that school.
Phinis is one of the best Conjurers in all of Skyrim, and can help with spells from that school.
Don't let Tolfdir fool you; he's the pre-eminent scholar on Alteration. One of the best in Tamriel, and always willing to pass on his knowledge.
If you can find him and focus his attention, there's a great deal Drevis can teach you about Illusion magic.
And finally, there's Colette. She may be... difficult to get along with, she's very knowledgeable when it comes to Restoration magic.
You... You can see me?
Confound it all. I was quite sure I was invisible, or at least transparent.
But you can hear me, obviously. Something still isn't quite right. At least I'm making progress.
Oh my, that's quite a difficult question.
Never underestimate the ability to influence others. Whether they're friends or foes, they're almost all susceptible to Illusion spells.
They can turn the tide of a battle in a moment's notice.
There are also spells that help in avoiding conflict altogether. Invisibility is tricky to master, but exceptionally useful.
Certainly. Destruction spells come in different forms, each useful for various purposes.
Concentration spells can be cast immediately, though they're weaker. Good for a tight spot, and less costly if you miss.
You'll also need to decide whether to devote yourself to a single type of spell.
Focusing solely on flame spells will make them more powerful, but you may find yourself at a disadvantage against foes immune to fire.
It's lies. All of it. I don't care what she told you, it's all lies.
Faralda. Don't act like she didn't say anything. I know her, I know what she's been up to.
Now. Enough. We will speak no more of this. I am the only friend you need.
Are those parts ready yet?
I can only hammer so fast, Gerdur.
They don't have to be perfect. Just send them over when they're ready.
Fine. Then I'll invite him out to play. He lives right there. I'm going to knock on his door...
No, child! Wait! That boy, that house - they're cursed.
Then it's true, what everyone is saying? That Aventus Aretino is doing the Black Sacrament? Trying to summon the Dark Brotherhood?
Oh, Grimvar... always with the nonsense. No, no, of course not. Those are just tales...
Ha! Then I'm right. I knew it. He's trying to have somebody killed!
All right. I won't deny it, child. What you heard is true. But Aventus Aretino walks a dark path. His actions can lead only to ruin.
Hmm. Yes, it is quite sad. A young boy, Aventus Aretino, lost his mother recently, and was sent to an orphanage.
But he has returned home, and people have heard strange chanting. They say it's the Black Sacrament, the ritual to contact the Dark Brotherhood.
Why a little boy would want to contact a group of murderers is beyond me, but he is inviting evil into this city.
Go, boys! Attack!
If I am to die today, so be it. But you'll not soon forget the Dark Brotherhood.
Hmm? What is it?
Another soul for the master!
I suppose it would be inappropriate of me to ask how you obtained this, so I simply won't.
A rubbing, eh? Odd. I expected notes.
I undertstand. Now, let me take a good look at this. Over here, please.
My guards told me. Poor Margret. And witnesses report that the attacker was shouting some nonsense about being a Forsworn.
I want to make things clear. Markarth has its troubles, but there are no Forsworn in this city.
They're only a threat in the hills and along the roads, where they live. Everywhere else, we are in control.
It's unfortunate that we live in such violent times, but there you have it.
Now I've been told that the attacker claimed to be a Forsworn. It's nonsense. More likely he was just sick in the head.
So don't concern yourself with it. Markarth is safe. You have my word.
He is the pus in the wound. Oh, proper ones curl their noses, but it's pus that drinks foul humors and restores the blood.
I worship Peryite, yes, because sometimes the world can only be cleansed by disease.
Not everyone has the stomach required to entreat my Lord. But Kesh likes you, friend. There is a way Peryite may speak to us who will take Him in.
If you wish to commune with Him, we'll need the incense.
Ah, no. Don't think you've got the stuff. Come back when you've seen a bit more in life, perhaps.
Ah, a wanderer, yes? No? Pilgrim, perhaps? Have you come to commune with Peryite, Taskmaster and blighted Lord?
Yes, the incense. Fetch for me a deathbell flower, one silver ingot, a flawless ruby, and some vampire dust. Then I will show you how.
I'll see you at Northwatch Keep, friend.
Please, get word to my mother.
Let's go, let's go!
Of course. I should've known. Avulstein was behind this, wasn't he?
Of course. I should've known. This was all Avulstein's idea, wasn't it? Where is he?
A wise decision, but I fear he may not be safe there anymore.
They'll go looking for me, and Whiterun will be the first place they search.
So he might still be in there?
I don't dare go back in now. I'll just have to hope that in the confusion he can slip out.
Avulstein... you stupid boy...
What is my freedom worth, if the price is my brother's life?
I cannot stay. Not here, not in Whiterun. It likely won't be safe for Avulstein, either.
Our best hope now is to fall in with the ranks of the Stormcloaks.
But would you do me a favor? Tell my mother to suffer the winter's cold wind, for it bears aloft next summer's seeds. She'll know what it means.
I thank you again, friend. You've given me my life back.
I don't dare return to Whiterun. But my mother... She'll need some consolation.
Tell her... tell her to suffer the winter's cold wind, for it bears aloft next summer's seeds. She'll understand.
Though shall mourn my brother, I thank you, friend. You've given me my life back.
Listen, when you're ready to do something useful, find me outside Haemar's Shame, in Falkreath.
Mortal. I am Namira, the Lady of Decay. Your consumption of the blood and bile of Arkay's own is pleasing to me.
I give you my ring. Wear it, and when you feast on the flesh of the dead, I will grant you my power.
Wallow in your wretchedness, my newest champion.
Your mockery will be the end of you. And on that day, another servant will feast on your entrails and discover a ring clenched in her teeth.
Be grateful for what time I give you until then.
To Oblivion with your loot! This ends now!
You don't have what it takes to kill me.
For once you'll actually pay for your crimes.
Once again, the Empire takes the blame for the crimes of others.
You're the one who put out the fire in the Lighthouse, right?
That was good work. Deeja's in the hold of the ship. Go down two levels.
I know it's a bit strange. Not exactly a name to bring comfort to the sick and ailing who come to buy a poultice or salve.
But what you must understand about Falkreath is that our town is defined, for better or wrose, by the large and ancient cemetery here.
That's why the inn is called Dead Man's Drink, the farm is called Corpselight Farm, and so on. I suppose it's sort of a running joke.
Well, my family back in Hammerfell didn't approve of my interest in lethal poisons and death in general. So I left, and wandered north.
When I found this town, with its huge cemetery, I felt right at home. I opened the shop and I've never looked back. This is where I belong.
I was Dengier's personal guard for years. I risked my hide more than once to protect him.
Why would I do that? For money? Because I swore an oath? No, it was because he was a good man and a true friend.
A true Nord places loyalty and honor above all else.
His name's Bolund. He's the one who works the lumber mill down by the river.
If you meet him, don't expect much in the way o' conversation. He ain't one for talking, especially with folk he don't know.
I was once, but not any more. I was wounded in a skirmish up near Windhelm. This was years ago, mind you.
Now, maybe I don't pick up a blade in Ulfric's name no more, but I still hold with his ideals. Skyrim is Nord land, and we ought to rule it.
We don't need no help from the Empire on that count.
You think some Emperor sitting on a gilded throne in Cyrodiil is going to know what's best for Skyrim?
The Imperial City's so far from here, it might as well be on one of the moons. And yet the Empire thinks it can tell us what to do an' how to live.
I'm no man's fool. I know Ulfric Stormcloak's selfish and power-hungry, but he's the devil I know. Does that put it plain enough for you?
For one thing, I won't empty Falkreath's coffers to buy myself fine clothes an' expensive mead.
For another, I won't get mixed up with criminals and other sorts who take advantage of the honest folk for profit.
I might be old, but I haven't forgotten that a Jarl's first duty is to look after his people.
Aye, not so long ago. Some'll tell you I stepped down on account of my old age.
Truth is, I found out about all the Imperial spies crawling around Falkreath. A few well-placed bribes, and they bought themselves some friends.
Suddenly the nobles are calling for a new Jarl, and all the while their pockets are jingling with the sound of Imperial septims.
They named me Thane, and they got my nephew Siddgeir in my place. A real friend to Cyrodiil, that one.
I should think so! I'm well used to taking care of a house and the folk living in it.
Taking care of the entire hold is another matter entirely. It would be a big enough job without the war on and the dragons about.
I just hope I can do right by the good folk who are looking to us to see to their needs.
Comes down to trust, I expect. After Dengeir gave up his seat to his nephew, he didn't trust anyone.
Everywhere he looks, he sees assassins, spies an' plots against him. I'm the only one he confides in.
So, when he was made Jarl again, he didn't wait a moment to name me his Steward. He said I was the only choice.
Master Arngeir, are you going to just let him continue to...
I have something to say first.
Here we go.
The only reason I agreed to attend this council was to deal with the dragon menace.
We have no interest in negotiating with the Empire. It's only a matter of time before they are driven out of Skyrim.
There's nothing else to talk about, unless the Empire is finally ready to renounce its unjust claim to rule over the free people of Skyrim.
I knew he wouldn't be able to resist.
We're here to arrange a temporary truce to allow the Dragonborn here to deal with the dragons. Nothing more.
You should be glad enough of a chance to lick your wounds at this point in the war.
I consider even talking to the Empire a generous gesture.
Are you done? Did you just come here to make speeches? Or can we get down to business?
Yes, let's get this over with.
We have nothing to say to each other. Paarthurnax's murder is beyond my powers of forgiveness.
Yes. But understand - during the days of Alduin's rule, all dragons were his allies. There was nothing else they could be.
If not for Paarthurnax, Alduin could not have been overthrown. It was he that first taught men to use the Thu'um.
I'd give a week's pay to see the look on Ulfric's face again, when he had to swallow the terms of the truce.
I hope this truce gives you what you need. It won't last.
As soon as I get back to Whiterun, I'll get my men ready.
When I return to Whiterun, I'll get my men ready to help trap this dragon.
The look on Tullius's face while the Greybeard read the terms was worth the trip.
I don't much like this truce. Feels like a betrayal to me.
We're counting on you to make this all worthwhile.
I sacrificed a lot here today for this plan of yours.
That could have gone worse. Now it's up to you to deliver.
You'd better be able to deliver, Dragonborn. I sacrificed a lot here today.
Is everyone here? Let's get this started.
Don't worry, I'll come to this peace council of yours.
I never thought I'd ever willingly stand in the same room with Tullius again. At least not without a weapon in my hand.
It's good to be back in High Hrothgar after all these years.
I'd just as soon get this over with.
I'll come to your council. But I doubt any good will come of it.
When has any good ever come from talking to the Empire?
I don't know how you convinced Ulfric to talk to the Empire. Worse than a waste of time if you ask me.
I'm glad I finally got a chance to see this place.
Talking peace with Ulfric? You must be an optimist.
You've done well, to even get the two of them in the same room.
If you can arrange an end to the fighting, Dragonsreach is at your disposal.
If you can arrange an end to the fighting, Dragonsreach is at your disposal.
We should get started. Alduin is only getting stronger.
What are we waiting for?
We must make them see their danger, Dragonborn.
We must succeed here today.
And so we meet again. But this time I know who and what you really are.
I'll give you credit for boldness. But associating yourself with the Blades is a choice you will come to regret.
I'm here to ensure that General Tullius does not exceed his authority.
You gave Ulfric more than he deserved. This will certainly prolong the war.
These terms are satisfactory to my government. The truce is unlikely to last long in any case.
I'm here because it's required of me. But there's nothing to be gained by talking to that murderer.
I understand this council was your idea, Dragonborn. I'm afraid I don't hold out much hope for success.
I don't know why you gave Ulfric so much. That murderer will never rule Skyrim.
I'm glad you were able to negotiate a truce, but I don't trust Ulfric. He'll break his word as soon as it suits him.
We should get started.
You fight well, brother.
You fight well, sister.
Argh!
Uf!
Yergh!
Egh!
Oof!
You must speak with the Farmhand at Chillfurrow farm.
So you're the... the assassin? I need you to kill the Visiting Noble at Dragonsreach, in Whiterun. Here's the gold. I... I hope it's enough.
So you're the one from the... Dark Brotherhood? I need you to kill the Big Laborer at Katla's Farm. Here's the gold for the kill. Make it painful.
You must be the... assassin. I need you to kill the Itinerant Lumberjack, in Morthal, at the logging camp. Here, this is all the gold I have.
You're the assassin, right? Look, there's this Reckless Mage in the Frozen Hearth Inn, in Winterhold. I want him dead. This gold should cover it.
You're the one? From the... the Dark Brotherhood? The man I need killed is a Seasoned Hunter. He's just outside Falkreath. Here's the gold...
You're here! I was wondering if that Black Sacrament even worked. I need you to kill a woman, a Poor Fishwife, on the Riften Docks. Here's the gold.
Dark Brotherhood? You look the type. Listen, there's this Grim Shieldmaiden walking the streets of Markarth. Kill her. Now take this gold, and go.
Are you the assassin? From the...? Well, there's this Traveling Dignitary, in Solitude. I need her... you know. This gold will cover it, right?
I'm glad you're here. I need you to kill a Coldhearted Gravedigger, tends to work in the Hall of the Dead in Windhelm. This is all the gold I have.
Good, you're here. Look, in Ivarstead, there's this Beautiful Barbarian. I need her dead. Don't ask why. Just do it. This gold should cover it.
If anybody asks, this meeting never took place.
I don't know you.
Would it kill you to let a man go about his business in peace? Really, the nerve...
Look, I'm busy. Please go bother somebody else.
Did you want something? I'm quite busy.
I'm dying for a rest. I swear, I could lie down right now, and just sleep forever.
The Dawnstar Sanctuary? That where you lot are holing up in now? Hmm... Tell you what. It'll cost you - a lot - but I can help you out.
What exactly are we talking about here?
Tell me what you need, and I'll get my people get on it.
Of course you do.
All right. What's your fancy?
I'm afraid that's it, my friend. I've done all I can. I hope the place is at least livable now. Good luck with, your, um... murders.
What... what happened?
Thank you. I don't know what's going on, but I think I owe you my life.
Sweet Breath of Arkay, were these the cannibals that were plaguing the Hall of the Dead?
I need to get back to Markarth. Here, take this. It's the least I can do for saving my life.
Don't worry, Arkay's protection is absolute.
(yawn) I'm so tired...
Let me speak to our guest.
Don't be shy. You should be the one to carve.
This is your initiation into the coven. Go ahead. Have the first bite.
Another new Apprentice, I see.
Are you of the sort that believe you're here to change the world? Or are you only in it for yourself?
I assure you that I shall be watching you -- all of you -- very closely.
I am an advisor to the Arch-Mage. The Thalmor wish to promote relations with your College.
I am at the Arch-Mage's disposal if he requires advice.
Now that stability has been established between the Dominion and the Empire, we seek only to help Skyrim.
To guide its people through this time of transition, to help lead them to a better future.
Perhaps not as often as he should. In time, I believe he will be more trusting.
Not within society, no. Many who practice within the school of Conjuration do so on their own, secretly.
Falion is the only one I know who is public about what he does. He was once my teacher here, but left the College years ago.
He didn't like the Arch-Mage. Hated dealing with him, hated having to answer to him.
Falion said he hated what this place was becoming. So he just left. Aren found a note on his desk, and that was it.
I understand he settled down in Hjaalmarch, and his presence there caused something of a problem.
You are new, yes?
Have you mastered the Expert level destruction spells yet?
You... you have? Already?
Well, J'zargo is surprised. And pleased! There is real competition here. This is good.
Ah, this is good. But J'zargo will know them first.
It is good to finally be around mages who may be able to keep up with J'zargo.
Is it? This is disappointing.
J'zargo hoped there might be one who could keep pace with his accomplishments.
Oh, but you are wrong.
The only reason you could disagree is because you are losing so badly you cannot see it.
There is much for J'zargo to be sure of.
There is skill in magic, there is charm, and there is a strong will. J'zargo will be successful, of this there is no doubt.
You've done it. The shrine is ours again.
Now we need to prepare a grand feast to welcome you to Namira's coven.
You will have the honor of bringing a fresh kill for the main course. And I know the perfect person.
You are looking for Arkay's protection while you delve some dank tomb, I take it?
My duties keep me busy in Markarth. I don't know if I can help you.
Treasure, you say?
I suppose the Jarl won't mind if I'm gone for a little while. Lead on.
You know, in the Priesthood of Arkay, we have a joke about an empty pocket being better than a full grave.
That's no small amount of coin, friend.
I suppose I can come with you for a short venture. Lead on.
I'm just not up for it, sorry. I'd rather stay here, have a glass of wine, and perform my rites to Arkay in peace.
I think you need to calm down before I summon the guards.
Yes, I'm positive I heard something.
Accidents' like this don't just happen! Someone is trying to sabotage my uncle's research!
I'll deal with my uncle. Just... go! Scour this place from top to bottom!
Aedra, what a day!
I know you, Ulfric. You have no intention of coming to terms.
You're here to blacken the Empire's name, and I won't be party to it.
You may think this war is nearly won. You're wrong. I've been fighting you with a mere handful of troops.
Once the Emperor is convinced of the need, then you will see the full strength of the Imperial Legion.
If you think you can hold Riften, you're as deluded as you've always been.
We get Riften back. Now we'll see if there's anything behind your fine words.
I know how this works, Tullius. I've learned the value of Imperial promises the hard way. Never again.
You're losing this war and you know it.
If you think that winning a few battles means you're winning the war, you're even worse at strategy than diplomacy.
You slaughtered the very people you claim to be fighting for! True sons of Skyrim would never do such things.
Damned Imperial lies! My men would never stoop to such methods, even in retaliation for your butchery at...
This is our homeland, Tullius. All the blood spilled in this war is on your head.
Well said! You may be fighting on the wrong side in this war.
Well said.
I expected better from you.
I should have known better than to expect you to give us a fair hearing.
I'm impressed at your even-handed treatment. Thank you.
I knew I could count on you.
What? Have you forgotten your oath to the Emperor?
As I expected, you favor your friends.
Come see me in Windhelm when this is all done. There's always work for those willing to fight for Skyrim.
Your actions here were a disgrace. You betrayed Skyrim at every turn.
You... you disappointed me. You gave too much away. More than was necessary to secure this truce.
I'm sure that will be a great comfort to the families of your comrades who died to free the land you just gave back to the Empire.
You should think harder on your commitment to Skyrim's freedom next time you're deciding what's right.
You made your decision. Now live with it.
Very honorable, I'm sure, but you should not put your own honor above the freedom of Skyrim.
You've disgraced yourself and our cause. You are no longer fit to be known as a son of Skyrim.
You've disgraced yourself and our cause. You are no longer fit to be known as a daughter of Skyrim.
Ulfric showed his true colors today, eh? Don't worry. You aren't the first to be taken in by his self-serving lies.
I think you may have joined the wrong side. You showed yourself to be a true friend to the Empire today.
I'm sorry to hear that. I thought you'd finally seen through Ulfric's lies.
Excellent! You aren't the first to have a change of heart, after seeing what Ulfric's reckless pride is doing to Skyrim.
Come see me in Solitude when this is all done. The Emperor can always use another good soldier.
Now, back to the matter at hand.
I suppose that's the fairest deal we're likely to get.
If we're not going to get Riften, we need you to give us something.
You know as well as I do that that we can't hand over Markarth on these terms.
You know I can't agree to these terms. The Emperor would repudiate this treaty and I would be recalled.
Don't hand me a mug of sheep's piss and call it Colovian brandy. These terms are still not acceptable.
Come on, Ulfric. You have to give a little ground here. The dragons are a threat to us both.
I'm listening.
Let's hear it.
Out with it, then.
Shor's bones, where will these demands end?
Damn Imperial arrogance!
You see what talking to them gets us?
We want compensation for the massacre at Barleydark Farm.
We want compensation for the massacre at Riverwood.
We want compensation for the massacre at Rorikstead.
We want compensation for the massacre at Karthwasten.
We want compensation for the massacre at Old Hroldan.
We want compensation for the massacre at Kolskeggr Mine.
We want compensation for the massacre at Stonehills.
We want compensation for the massacre at Frost River Farm.
We want compensation for the massacre at Granite Hill.
We want compensation for the massacre at Half-moon Mill.
We want compensation for the massacre at Heljarchen.
We want compensation for the massacre at Anga's Mill.
We want compensation for the massacre at Loreius Farm.
We want compensation for the massacre at Whistling Mine.
We want compensation for the massacre at Ivarstead.
We want compensation for the massacre at Shor's Stone.
We want compensation for the massacre at Heartwood Mill.
We want compensation for the massacre at Sarethi Farm.
We want Hjaalmarch back, and Idgrod Ravencrone restored as Jarl.
You withdraw from Falkreath, and allow Siddgeir to resume his rightful place as Jarl.
We want the Pale returned to Imperial control. The traitor Skald the Elder will be replaced with a more loyal candidate.
We want Kraldar removed as Jarl of Winterhold, and an Imperial candidate put in his place.
Never mind. I can see that these are the best terms we'll get from this council.
So be it. The Empire at least puts the greater good above our own interests.
Why would I give you that, if I wouldn't give you Riften?
What next, Tullius? Shall I just hand over all of Skyrim?
I'm willing to let the Dragonborn decide the fairness of my request.
I guess I have no choice but to let the Dragonborn decide. Although I'm starting to doubt your fairness.
For what it's worth, I'm sorry to see you go. You fought well for us.
Don't listen to him. Ulfric's been telling lies about himself for so long, he's actually starting to believe them.
Jarl Baalgruf, I assume you are familiar with the Dragonborn's plan?
Well that's an excellent question. You haven't overlooked that little detail, have you?
Come on Galmar. We have a lot of work to do.
This is quite an achievement, Dragonborn. And General Tullius. Riften is ours!
Giving up Markarth is a heavy price for this truce, Dragonborn. I hope it was worth it.
I admit, I really didn't expect you'd be able to arrange a truce. Getting Ulfric to agree to anything at all is quite an achievement.
Yes, I'm ready to do my part.
Just say the word, and my men will help you spring this trap.
Your man Horik is wearing his old Legion armor. What should I make of that?
He's proud of his service, Skald. The Legion taught us loyalty. And we're loyal to Dawnstar.
We warned you, but you just had to go and cause trouble.
Now we have to pin all these recent murders on you. Silence witnesses. Work. Work. Work.
You'll never leave Markarth!
You'll never see the sun again, you hear me? No one escapes Cidhna Mine.
No one.
At last, the treasure is mine! All mine!
There must be a way to activate these doors deeper in the ruins. Here, take this key. It should open the doors on either side of this chamber.
There'd better be. I didn't come all this way to leave empty handed.
Hmm. These doors seem to be the only thing left between me and the treasure.
I... oh, all right. If there is a thief, he won't leave this tower alive. But shouldn't we inform Master Calcelmo?
All right men, spread out and search the tower. No telling who- or what- we're dealing with here.
What a waste! There must be a dozen men up there!
Yeah. Calcelmo called in his entire expedition team- said he needed every man he could get to protect his research.
Better them than us. We lost three good men to the traps up there, and for what- just to see another damn spider clanking around?
Well, at least this post is safe enough. Come on, let's get back to work.
You heard me, captain- our work must not be disturbed.
Kill any intruders on sight. Call for backup if you need it. But let no one through.
Sir, are you serious?
...As you say, sir.
What do you think this is?
Another trap, most likely. Things are dangerous... three of the guards died when the lower hall flooded with steam last week.
What the...?
Everyone, fall back! Run for it!
Oh thank you, kind stranger. Thank you for helping Cicero and his poor, stranded mother.
He he. That'll teach the little loony.
A jester. In these parts. Man must be completely off his tree.
Move along, now.
You there! Fool! Hold fast. You've been accused of a crime against the laws of this land. What say you in your defense?
Wh... What? A crime? Me? Preposterous! Poor Cicero is just standing here! Cicero loves order. Oh yes! He would never disrespect the law!
You look like a crazy man to me. And what's in that coffin, hmm? Maybe some time in a cell will help loosen that lying tongue.
Damn that Loreius. Oh, how he will pay for this treachery...
Listener! Is that you? Oh, I knew you'd come. Send the best to defeat the best. Astrid knew her stupid wolf couldn't slay sly Cicero.
Oh, but this isn't at all what Mother would want. You kill the Keeper or I kill the Listener? Now that's madness.
Ouch! Pointy pointy! My home is well defended. I always have been a stickler for details. Get it? [QUOTE]Stick-ler.[QUOTE] Ha ha ha ha ha ha ha! Oh, I slay me!
You're... still alive. Cicero respects the Listener's abilities, of course, but could you at least slow down a bit? I'm not what I used to be. Heh.
All right, so Cicero attacked that harlot, Astrid! But what's a fool to do, when his mother is slandered and mocked? Surely the Listener understands!
Brrr! Chilly! You'll enjoy this. Not an original part of the Sanctuary, per se. Let's call it a [QUOTE]forced addition.[QUOTE] Forced by what? Oh, come and see!
Cicero admits, he thought the Listener would be dead by now. Heh. Maybe we could just forget all this? Hmm? Let bygones be bygones? What do you say?
If it's any comfort, I do feel slightly bad about Veezara. Stupid lizard got in my way! But please tell me that hulking sheepdog has bled to death.
And now we come to the end of our play. The grand finale.
Our terms are simple.
Riften must be returned to Imperial control. That's our price for agreeing to a truce.
Elisif, are you really going to be a party to this foolishness?
Do you really think Ulfric will just turn Riften over because some Imperial general barked an order?
That's quite an opening demand, Tullius.
I'm sure General Tullius does not expect something for nothing.
Of course not! What will you offer for Riften, Tullius? Some empty promises? Maybe some more Imperial bluster?
Ulfric, you can't be taking this demand seriously? We can hold Riften against anything the Empire can throw at it.
Come on, Tullius, you can't seriously expect us to just hand over Riften at the negotiating table.
You haven't been able to take it back yet. Why should we give it up now?
Jarl Ulfric, what would you want in return?
First, let me be clear. The sons of Skyrim know from bitter experience that talking to the Empire is a waste of time, or worse.
Imperial promises are simply a way to lull you while they prepare a dagger for your back.
But I accepted the Dragonborn's invitation to this council, and I at least will negotiate in good faith.
Aye! We haven't forgotten Markarth, Tullius!
You heard the man, Tullius.
You heard what she said, Tullius.
Riften is off the table. The Empire barely has a toehold left in Skyrim. We don't need to pay such a high price for this truce.
We've made you a fair offer. If you're really serious about this truce, you need to reconsider.
Have you killed them all yet?
Well, hurry up.
Then we've no time to lose. Follow me!
Don't fall behind!
So, you've done it. The men of violence are gathered here, in these halls whose very stones are dedicated to peace.
I should not have agreed to host this council. The Greybeards have no business involving ourselves in such matters.
Peace? I doubt it. They may put their weapons down for a moment, but only to gather strength for the next bloodletting.
They are not yet tired of war. Far from it. Do you know the ancient Nord word for war? [QUOTE]Season unending[QUOTE]... so it has proved.
Yes, yes. Which is why I allowed this... violation of all our traditions.
But regrets are pointless. Here we are.
Take your seat at the council table and let us see what wisdom we can find among these warriors of Skyrim.
You should be glad enough of a chance to lick your wounds at this point in the war.
We consider even sitting down to talk with these rebels more than generous.
We want control of Markarth. That's our price for agreeing to a truce.
Besides, Jarl Laila will never agree to...
Galmar. We will do whatever I decide is in the best interests of Skyrim. Are we clear?
Vignar. We will do whatever I decide is in the best interests of Skyrim. Are we clear?
Yes, my lord.
Enough, Galmar.
It has its advantages. I've never liked having the Empire perched on my doorstep. And Riften would be easy to hold...
Yes. With Markarth in our hands, we'll be able to raid the Imperial supply lines out of Solitude...
You're right. Tullius isn't in any position to ask for Riften.
In exchange for Riften, the jewel of Skyrim? Hardly.
Whiterun seems like a better choice to me. From there we can threaten to undermine the whole Imperial position.
In exchange for Riften, the jewel of Skyrim? Hardly. How about the Reach? Gaining control of the silver mines would be invaluable.
I'm glad you agree. I was starting to wonder whose side you were on here.
Well. Good! You favor the Empire less than I feared. Maybe we will be able to come to some agreement here after all.
Not enough to outweigh the loss of Riften. The whole south of Eastmarch would be open to Imperial attack.
You can't just leave me here!
Fie. We beseech you. Darken this gem so that we may use its power to restore The Order of the Black Worm.
Grant us this power so that in your name we may vanquish our enemies.
Fie!
Yeah, fie!
The Order shall rise.
So. Arngeir, is it? You know why we're here. Are you going to let us in or not?
You were not invited here. You are not welcome here.
We have as much right to be at this council as all of you. More, actually, since we were the ones that put the Dragonborn on this path.
I know what path you set her on. And now Paarthurnax's wisdom is lost to us, just when we need it most.
I know what path you set him on. And now Paarthurnax's wisdom is lost to us, just when we need it most.
We know what path you've set her on. But she has made a different choice. Paarthurnax is still safe from your malice.
We know what path you've set him on. But he has made a different choice. Paarthurnax is still safe from your malice.
Were you? The hubris of the Blades truly knows no bounds.
She did what had to be done. It was long overdue. My only regret is that I wasn't able to kill him myself.
He did what had to be done. It was long overdue. My only regret is that I wasn't able to kill him myself.
For now. The Blades' memory is long, as you know.
If it were up to you, the Dragonborn would sit dreaming on this mountain doing nothing!
Delphine, we're not here to rehearse old grudges.
The matter at hand is urgent. Alduin must be stopped. You wouldn't have called this council if you didn't agree.
We know a great deal about the situation and the threat that Alduin poses to us all. You need us here if you want this council to succeed.
Very well. You may enter.
Damn right we do.
Don't play dumb, Tullius!
Tell him, Ulfric.
I just want to make clear that the only reason I agreed to attend this council was to deal with the dragon menace.
We have no need to negotiate when the rebels are so clearly losing the war.
I have no authority to negotiate a permanent settlement, unless Ulfric is ready to sue for peace and turn himself over to Imperial justice.
Enough posturing, Tullius. If you came to talk, let's get on with it.
We're here to arrange a temporary truce to allow the Dragonborn here to deal with the dragons. Nothing more.
One moment.
Here we go.
Fine. Let's get this over with.
What is there to know? It's in the temple, you bring it out. You bring it to me, I pay you. Now get moving.
You're... probably right. Just hurry, please. Who knows what those things are doing to her.
Thank you, friend.
Father!
Fjotra, dear. Did they hurt you?
Of course not. My spirit remains strong.
My little girl. Always strong. Do you know where you have to go?
I'm to go to the temple in Markarth. I... I'll have to leave you and mother.
It's our honor to have you there.
This man is going to take you to Markarth. Are you ready?
This woman is going to take you to Markarth. Are you ready?
Of course.
Please, lead on.
Start changing it over to the Black-Briar Meadery West as soon as possible. That was Maven's part of the deal.
She's put me in charge of keeping the mead flowing, so that's exactly what I'm going to do.
If you're in the area and you ever need anything fenced, you just let me know.
I knew the Greybeards would send you there if they thought you were Dragonborn. They're nothing if not predictable.
When you showed up here, I knew you were the one the Greybeards sent, and not some Thalmor plant.
You should know. You got the map for me from Bleak Falls Barrow.
I should say so. I'd be careful in the future before you confront someone without all of the facts!
Sibbi and I were to be married. We were supposed to be happy together forever.
Then I found that wretched poetry from Svana. When I confronted Sibbi about it, he threatened to kill me.
I was scared so I told my brother Wulfur. He went to talk to Sibbi for me and... and... Sibbi killed him. My brother wasn't even armed!
When I heard what Sibbi did, I fled. Now you've found me, and you're going to tell him where I am.
It's nice to receive good news for a change. Did you recover anything else from the warehouse worth mentioning?
Results speak volumes over words and you've just proved it.
Did you happen to discover where the fetcher was getting his skooma from?
Then there's no time to lose. It won't take long for Sarthis's associates to learn of his death.
The source of the poison must be destroyed once and for all, otherwise another dealer will simply take his place.
Do this task for me and you'll be well on your way to a title in Riften.
Then I want you to head out there immediately and eliminate all of them.
I can't afford to have another Sarthis blunder into Riften because they think we're too lazy to disrupt their pitiful operation.
Do this task for me and you'll be well on your way to a title in Riften.
Good. Report back to me when your task is complete.
Good. Make sure not one of them escapes alive.
I can't say I'm happy with your decision. If you change your mind, let me know.
I'm very disappointed. I'd advise you to rethink that decision soon.
Look, I don't think I should say. I mean, they could kill me!
It's not worth dying over.
It's got nothing to do with the coin... this is my life we're talking about.
You can't threaten me any worse than they have!
Thank you.
Okay, okay, I'll tell you.
I get my skooma from Sarthis Idren. He has some sort of a setup over at the Riften Warehouse.
You can't get inside though. They've kept that place locked up tight since the war began.
If it wasn't for skooma, I'd already be on my way out of this horrible city.
All my gold... completely gone. Now I have to start over. I'll never use skooma again!
Although I suppose a little mead now and then would be harmless...
I overheard Bolli say that only the Jarl carries the key to the warehouse.
When I meet Sarthis there, he's usually waiting for me outside with his bodyguard.
Yes, I'm afraid we're aware of Sarthis's presence in the warehouse.
Unfortunately, we're certain he has informants within the city guard. Every time we've made a move to arrest him, he's escaped.
However, if you'd take care of this discreetly, you might be able to surprise him without warning.
Ah yes, Sarthis... a thorn in my side for the last few years.
I've tried repeatedly to eradicate that meddler, but he has ears within the city guard. Gives us the slip every time we raid the warehouse.
However, if you'd wish to eliminate that burden for me... well, let's just say it would go a long way with earning my favor.
Excellent. Here, this is the key to the warehouse.
See if you can drop in on this dealer of poison and convince him to close down his operation permanently.
Good. Here, take the key to the warehouse.
Pay dear old Sarthis a visit and tell him Maven sends her regards, would you?
Hm. Well, if you change your mind, come see me again.
Let me give you a word of advice.
Think about your choices carefully from now on. You'll go much farther in Riften with me on your side.
Oh come now, this is mead... not some wine to be sipped and savored.
You... you're in charge here until I can sort this all out.
It will be my pleasure.
Look, I assure you, this is all just a huge misunderstanding!
I said move!
Farewell, Sabjorn.
Then this is beyond coincidence. First Aringoth and now Sabjorn.
Someone's trying to take us down by driving a wedge between Maven and the Guild.
Sabjorn keeps that locked up tight. If you can get through that way, go right ahead.
Hold on, my boy. Hold on!
Hold on, my dear. Hold on!
I thought it high time I caught up with you.
I've never seen anything like this in Nordic ruins before. Why, just look at all these coffins!
This bears closer inspection. I'd like to stay a while and examine this.
You, however, should press on. See if you can find whatever this vision of yours mentioned. But if it is truly dangerous, be careful.
Go on ahead. I'll be sure and catch up with you before long.
I'm just doing what I'm told.
Gods, it's cold. They'd better find something good in there to make this worthwhile.
As long as the College keeps paying, I'll keep digging.
For thousand-year old ruins, they're not much to look at.
Can't imagine what the College expects to find in here.
But why?
This little adventure of yours has cost me a number of test subjects. I need more, and you'll do nicely.
Ohh... but I will have your blood...
My thirst will be sated...
Oh, I can smell your blood...
You'll be so much easier to rob when you're dead...
Tell you what. You start running so I can stab you in the back.
Can't wait to count out your coin...
You cannot even conceive of the power I wield...
Fire, frost, or lightning - you will suffer at my hands!
Don't you see? I am master of the arcane!
Come. Come and face the Forsworn...
First you... then all of the Reach!
The Forsworn will reclaim what is rightfully ours!
Soon you will know the cold of death...
The endless sleep comes for us all...
Eternal slumber awaits...
Foolish human. Your time is at its end!
Time for you humans to learn your place!
Soon, all Nords will be thralls to the Thalmor!
Nord beast! Both your life and lands are now forfeit!
Behold, the future. Behold, the Thalmor!
Ha ha ha ha ha! You wish to defeat me? Impossible.
Don't you see? Elven supremacy is the only truth!
Death is the only way out of your misery!
You are but a dog, and I am your master!
Ha! You can never truly stop me!
Ugh! Only a fool tries to kill the dead!
Agh! Pathetic mortal!
Never!
Agh!
Unh!
Oof!
Waaagh!
Naggh!
Unh!
Oof!
Noo...
I will return...
Aggghh...
Uggh...
Agggh!
Uggh...
Unnff...
I sense a presence...
Hmm? Does someone live among the dead?
Lookee here. Looks like we got ourselves a hero.
You picked a bad time to get lost, friend.
Now ain't this a surprise.
Who dares disturb my rest?
You are not welcome here!
All the living shall fear the dead!
Mortal fool! No one hides from the dead!
Death comes for you now!
Nothing... Nothing...
The glimmer of life is gone...
Such an abrupt end to our game.
Finality.
You dare hide from me?
I still sense your presence, living fool...
Gone. The living are right to fear the dead.
There is no more life here.
We meet again, mortal!
Time to end your foolish charade!
...retire some day... get myself an island...
...never enough gold... just need one good haul...
...might pay off my bounty this time... walk into the city a free man...
..told him to just hand over the gold, but did he listen? Oh, no... they always have to fight back...
...I'll never do another span in that stinking jail... rather die than give myself up...
...he he he... two threes? What was he thinking? Fool never saw me pull that ace out of my boot...
...need me some skooma... the imported stuff... just one last time...
...gonna start keepin' a knife in my boot... tired of gettin' disarmed...
...should have known she was lying... said she'd wait for me... but they never wait...
...lyin' little harlot... that brat ain't mine... could be anyone's... won't get one rusty septim from me...
...[QUOTE]go to the college[QUOTE] da said... [QUOTE]use your smarts[QUOTE] he said... like I'm supposed to figure out which college he meant...
...hmph, wizards... Now that's power... Bet they got that [QUOTE]secret[QUOTE] magic... can turn wood to gold... yeah... Wish I could turn wood to gold...
...mead, mead, mead... ...kill 'em to get some beer every now and then? ...stupid bees and their stupid honey...
...picking pockets, now that's the real art... ...no rough stuff, just take it and go... ...hmph, don't sound like much fun, though...
...once was a woman, as fair as an evenin', of springtime in old Stros M'Kai...
...with three beers down, the Orc did frown, and bid the Elf goodbye... ...for none could know, 'twas not for show, and someone had to die...
...kill him, he talks to me like that again... ...get him while he's sleeping... ...or poison his meat... ...see how he likes that...
It is done. The defiler is defeated. Take Dawnbreaker from its pedestal.
That's about the truth of it. Write tales about the sights I've seen. The battles I've fought.
Earned quite a name for myself when I was younger. The Bards College still teaches some of my work to their students.
It's a school that teaches music, poetry, that sort of thing. Most bards in Skyrim have been to the college at some point.
If you're thinking of applying, talk to Viarmo in Solitude.
Beirand's my husband. He works the forge up at Castle Dour. I barely see him nowadays, what with him filling orders for the army.
My husband. He was the blacksmith up at Castle Dour.
Ah... To be honest, no. But High King Torygg supported them, and now her lady Elisif has thrown in with them.
You could say I'm a King's man at heart. Hmph. I guess that's [QUOTE]Jarl's man[QUOTE] now.
My loyalty lies with Solitude. So where Jarl Elisif leads, I follow.
Nothing at all. It's very... nice. If you want something with a little more style, however, you should see what we have available.
Nothing at all. It's very... nice. If you want something with a little more style, however, you should come by our shop. Radiant Raiment.
We could fix you right up.
I do. So few people possess the taste and sophistication of a proper wardrobe these days.
Be sure and investigate Radiant Raiment's fine selection of clothing. We have many items you'll fancy, I'm sure.
I suppose I would, but you're the only one who gets that greeting.
It's never been an issue. People say you helped with the problems at Wolfskull Cave.
I applaud anyone who assists the court.
Oh, we do all right. Rumor is, you had a hand in the Blackblood Marauders' demise...
I'm impressed.
Radiant Raiment has the finest attire in all of Skyrim. That is how we...
Wait. You're that new bard, the one who saved the Festival. Aren't you?
That was a good bit of work.
Radiant Raiment has the finest attire in all of Skyrim. That is how we get business.
Well, as it turns out, I had a pet skeever when I was a boy and he used to wink.
Down at the docks. There are a few good spots, if you can avoid the East Empire Company workers and those Red Wave thugs.
Not much. But as a bard, I find the whole affair depressing.
There are no heroes in this war. No winners to be had and no real conclusion.
Not much. But as a bard, I find the whole affair depressing.
There are no heroes in this war. Even with Ulfric here in Solitude, there are no winners to be had. No real conclusion.
They're... adequate. Honestly, I rely on the business brought in by the Burning of King Olaf, and that's not likely to happen this year.
Oh, very brisk. When the snow sets in, even the hardiest Nord needs some spiced wine to warm the blood.
I have my ways, but it's not easy these days.
The Blackblood Marauders have been plundering ships off the coast. A lot of people been hurt by their foolishness.
It's been easier lately.
The Blackblood Marauders haven't been seen since the Icerunner attack, so my shipments have been more regular.
No. Although it's true my husband Torygg was the High King and I am his widow, I am in no position to claim such a title.
Ulfric Stormcloak is victorious, and the Jarls have fallen in line.
It seems I will never take my rightful place as High Queen.
Not yet, no. Although it is true my husband Torygg was the High King, and I am his widow... now is not the time to lay claim to such a title.
This land is riven by war, and her people suffer for it. The Stormcloaks are a blight on Skyrim, and like any blight... must be purged.
Only then will I take my rightful place as High Queen.
I was a member of the court during the reign of Torygg's father. It was Torygg who appointed me to the position.
Please. You're in the presence of a born huntsman. I can hear the sweat sliding down your forehead.
Ha! I like you.
No man is a match for a dragon.
Buying one of our blades wouldn't hurt your chances, though.
They were smaller back then.
I thought so.
Did you see a hound on the road? A fine, strong creature that's been wandering near town.
Fruit, fresh off the boat! The freshest in Skyrim!
Get your fresh fruit and produce here!
Apples, tomatoes, leeks and cabbages! Fresh and ripe!
Fresh fish! Fresh fish!
Fresh Fish! Straight from the Fjords!
The finest fish, here! Caught daily!
Spiced Wine to warm the blood!
Keep the cold at bay with our spiced wine!
Spiced wine, the taste of home and hearth!
Come on, now! I want those arrows dead center! The lives of your fellow soldiers are counting on it.
Concentrate. The battlefield is full of distractions. Ignore them! Focus on your targets.
Some day soon, you will all see battle. And what you do here, today, may well save your lives!
You won't get anything out of me, you filthy sons o' horkers.
I stand with the Stormcloaks. You Imperial dogs will never break my will. Never!
I've got weapons for givin', and armor for gettin'!
Arms and armor! Forged by a master craftsman!
A coin or two for a veteran? It's not much to ask...
You know you can afford a septim or two.
Let us walk in the steps of the Divines.
Remind us of our place, when we forget.
May knowledge of your Divinity carry us through our daily trials.
I showed up to watch, yeah.
I don't know if they were right to execute him for what he did, but I'll tell you something...
It couldn't have happened to a nicer guy.
Then you didn't know Roggvir, and you have no idea what it means to be a Nord of Skyrim!
He did the honorable thing, even when he knew it would cost him everything.
My brother was the best man in Solitude.
I'm a Thane. In the future, you may want to gain that information before talking with someone. Risk of looking like an idiot, and all that.
Yes. My older brother and the person you probably want to be speaking to right now.
But really, since Torygg's death, Falk Firebeard wields the true power of the Jarl's court. My brother is nothing more than a pompous little fop.
Yes. My older brother. He was a bit of a fop, really.
And truth be told, since Torygg's death, he had no real power in court. But still... He didn't deserve to die.
I make sure Erikur keeps breathing.
I provide my wisdom and insight to the court.
It does indeed. You know, I hear you had something to do with Sybille Stentor's demise...
That must have been a hard bit of business. I hear Stentor had been alive for a long, long time.
Aye, but I'll be here in Solitude for longer still. Fihada's skill as a fletcher drew me to this place. I wanted to learn.
And there is still much of Skyrim I wish to see. I hear there is a city, Wind-Helm, that is nearly white with... What do you call it? Ah yes! Snow.
And far to the west lies a ruin. Volskygge. Inside, there is said to be a wall, black as night. And it speaks! In the ancient Dragon tongue!
There are wonders in this place I never dreamed imaginable.
What? You see a man fallen on hard times, and you think he's been like that forever?
I was there. I fought in the Great War. I was on the field at Anvil. And when I was struck down, they left me.
You understand? They left me for dead. I didn't leave them.
I shouldn't be. Mama says if I do, people are going to ask about uncle Roggvir.
Maybe if I don't talk, they won't either.
I shouldn't be. Everyone wants to ask me about mama and uncle Roggvir.
Maybe if I don't talk, they won't either.
And why wouldn't I be? We sing tales of kings, queens and their politics, 'tis true. But do you know who really makes history?
The person who writes it.
Thank you. I'm still at the beginning of my lessons but Inge... Dean Six Fingers... says I'm quite good with the flute.
Thank you. I'm still at the beginning of my lessons. Dean Six Fingers used to say I was quite good with the flute.
Aye. I'm the headsman here in Solitude. It's my job.
She still mourns greatly for her husband, High King Torygg. So she leaves many of the courtly details to me.
All my life. I practically grew up in the Hall. My father and mother were the priest and priestess of Arkay before me, you see.
I believe I was put here to protect this place from the darkness that pervades Solitude.
Their aim could be steadier, but they're battle ready.
Perhaps, but necessary. As you know my cousin, Fura, died out there fighting for us. She wouldn't have had to, if it weren't for Roggvir.
Perhaps, but necessary. My cousin, Fura, is somewhere out there in Skyrim right now, fighting Ulfric Stormcloak and his damned insurrectionists.
She wouldn't have to be there at all, if it weren't for Roggvir.
No, no. Mostly, I'm just a simple herbalist. Lami over in Morthal should be able to help you.
No, no. I'm just a simple herbalist. You'll want to see Arcadia, over in Whiterun.
Oh, master. It's your time to do with as you please, but what about those who depend on you so much?
Tendrils of thought may wind their way through this realm, but those tendrils bind our reality together.
A method to your madness and your madness is the method and the melody...
I found the bone! I've brought it to you but still I am refused...
Before we begin, I want to make two things perfectly clear.
One, I'm the best infiltrator this rathole of a Guild's got, so if you think you're here to replace me, you're dead wrong.
And two, you follow my lead and do exactly as I say... no questions, no excuses.
Then we understand each other... good.
Now, it's time to get your feet wet and I don't want to waste a lot of time talking about anything but business.
Easy, huh? So, should I just hand you purses of coin or are you going to work to earn your keep?
Let me give you a small bit of advice. Nothing in this line of work is easy. If it was, every dreg in the Ratway would be robbing Riften blind.
If something's being handed to you on a silver platter, then there's a catch... steal the platter instead. You get it?
Now you I like. I've been getting sick of the pushovers that usually walk in here.
I think you and I are going to get along just fine.
Now, it's time to get your feet wet and I don't want to waste a lot of time talking about anything but business.
I'm not going to sugar-coat it for you. We're in a bad way down here.
Who knows. Old Delvin thinks it's some kind of a curse. I think he's crazy.
If you want my opinion I say it's just plain old bad luck.
You can get out there and start making a name for us again... make them start fearing us like they did long ago.
And, while you're at it, make a little bit of coin on the side. Not a bad deal, eh?
Brynjolf, huh? Lemme guess. He plucked you off the street and dropped you into the thick of things without tellin' you which way is up. Am I right?
Lyin' to my face isn't gonna win you any favors with me, I can promise you that.
On the other hand, takin' some of these extra jobs off my hands, now that'll get you to the top of my list.
See, that kind of attitude comes from someone who wants to get rich and stay alive long enough to enjoy it. We're goin' to get along nicely.
So, if you've got the nerve, I've got plenty of extra jobs to help get the Guild back on its feet.
Look around you. The Flagon, the Guild... it's all fallin' apart.
A few decades ago, this place was as busy as the Imperial City. Now, you're lucky if you don't trip over a skeever instead.
Look, I know the others think I'm a bit daft for sayin' stuff like this, but I'm gonna give it to you straight.
Somethin' out there is piss-drunk mad at us. I don't know who or what it is, but it's beyond just you and me. We've been cursed.
I'll tell you what we do. We spit in that curse's face and turn things around down here. Put things back the way they were.
That's where you come in. I've got plenty of work available that could guide us down the road to recovery.
All you need to do is ask and we can both come out of this smellin' like a rose.
Welcome to the family, lad. I'm expecting you to make us a lot of coin, so don't disappoint me.
Welcome to the family, lass. I'm expecting you to make us a lot of coin, so don't disappoint me.
Simple. Do as you're told and keep your blade clean. We can't turn a profit by killing.
You should talk with Delvin Mallory and Vex. They know their way around this place and they'll be able to kick some extra jobs your way.
Oh, and talk to Tonilia in the Flagon... she'll set you up with your new armor.
The Skyforge? Aye, my clan-fathers have worked it since the first Gray-Manes came to Whiterun.
Skyforge Steel is all the Companions will use, for good reason.
Why? Who says I have to be?
Skyforge Steel is my art and honor. The Companions need the best, so they come to me.
Battle-Born is a name out of legend, sung in the songs of old and heard in deeds of valor for a hundred generations.
[QUOTE]For Clan Battle-Born![QUOTE] they cry in the mead halls. [QUOTE]First into the fray and last to quit their ale![QUOTE]
We've got honor. Wealth and titles, too. Aye, and buxom women to warm your bed on a cold Skyrim night.
Now if that don't answer your question, then no words will.
Uncivilized, pelt-wearing axe-draggers. It's a wonder they don't still live in a cave like those ancestors they keep boasting about.
It's true the Vignar Gray-Mane and his lot are one of Whiterun's oldest and, depending on who you ask, most respected clans. I don't dispute that.
But it's one thing to take pride in your lineage, and another to cling blindly to the past. What they call honor and tradition, I call ignorance.
Money, you laggard! What else? It always comes down to coin.
