When we destroy the rebellion, perhaps the Thalmor will call off their damned inquisitions. It's just making things worse.
Sometimes I miss being out there in the middle of the action.
Unblooded.
Ice-Veins.
Bone-Breaker.
Snow-Hammer.
Stormblade.
Always good to see someone I can trust.
Sometimes I wonder if Ulfric understands what I'm dealing with out here.
That godless Emperor can shove his damn treaty into the steaming nether-reaches of my you-know-where.
My hatred for the Empire is exceeded only by my hatred for their witch-elf puppet-masters.
What will Skyrim have become if her children submitted to tyranny?
The Empire would have us become their slaves as they have become slaves to the Thalmor. I will not live as a slave, nor will I die as one.
The Empire is weak. That is why we fight them. Skyrim must be ruled by the strong.
Some say Ulfric desires to be king and nothing more... have they not seen that his anger floats on a sea of tears?
Countless dead haunt countless sleepless nights... when Skyrim becomes whole again, perhaps so will I.
When we've reclaimed our homeland from the Imperials, we'll take the fight to the Thalmor. They are the true enemy. Make no mistake.
If there was someone else Ulfric could trust with all this planning nonsense, I'd be out there breaking heads with the rest of you.
Auxiliary.
Quaestor.
Praefect.
Tribune.
Legate.
Skyrim is the birth place of the Empire. We won't let a bunch of thugs rob her of her lineage.
General Tullius expects much of me, and thus I expect much of my men.
In these grave times each Legionnaire must be his better self at all times and under all conditions.
The Empire is man's last bastion. If Ulfric wasn't blinded by lust for power, he'd see we are on the same side.
Were the Stormcloaks to prevail in dismantling Imperial rule in Skyrim, who would be her protector? No. We will crush this rebellion. We must do.
Ulfric would expunge from Skyrim citizens whose only crime was to be born of a non-Nordic woman. That is unacceptable to free men everywhere.
Every Legionnaire's secret weapon lies in this: knowledge of himself. And like any blade, he must be forged between the hammer and the anvil.
On the coldest of nights, in the steam rising from my breath, I see the many faces of the dead.
We stand out here in the cold, as brothers, warmed by the knowledge that we fight for the rights of every free citizen of the Empire.
Unblooded.
Ice-Veins.
Bone-Breaker.
Snow-Hammer.
Stormblade!
Look deeply into the faces of the warriors around you. These are the true sons and daughters of Skyrim. See her strength and nobility in their eyes.
The Empire would have us become slaves to the Thalmor. We are not slaves. We are men. Free men who will slay anyone who begs to differ.
It was anger that brought each of us here, but it is love that keeps us fighting.
The measure of a man is taken at the moment of his death. And know this for truth, the ghosts of many heroes walk among us.
One lives for the things he is willing to die for.
My hatred for the Empire is bested only by love for my countrymen.
The Emperor would turn Skyrim into a puppet of the Dominion. I for one would not care to dance for the amusement of those foul elves.
That we have forgotten them, this I fear the gods will remember.
Before we wage war upon our foes, we must wage a war against our lesser selves. Cleave to your higher voice and with it shatter your foes.
I'll fight the entire Legion myself if they dare show their faces here.
Legion soldiers gleam like fresh-fallen snow and clank like a kitchen. They head this way, we'll know it.
I long to be out there, with my brothers, waging war against the Empire.
Keep an eye out for Stormcloak spies.
Been so long since I killed a Stormcloak, my sword arm's getting flabby.
Stay alert. Never know when those Stormcloak dogs might charge.
Did I ever tell you about the day when Skald the Elder was Skald the Younger?
I can't imagine Skald ever being young.
Oh, he was young, and handsome. I had half a mind to go after him, myself, before I met my husband.
Frida, you aren't saying....
I was a beauty in my day, dearie. Don't act so surprised.
Dawnstar has always held its own against the bandits and wild animals of the Pale.
Did you ever have to fight off bandits, Frida? Like in your stories?
Why, I once fought alongside your father when we were both younger. Saved him from getting his fool head sliced off.
Who were you fighting against?
Oh, dearie, it was so long ago. But I do remember the celebration we had afterwards. Mead never tasted so good.
Thoring, do you remember the time when that wolf pack come clamoring into town?
How could I forget? That old alpha male almost took off my leg.
Never did find out why they came sprawling into town like that.
Animals in the Pale don't need a reason to attack Dawnstar. It's just their nature.
Now, who was it that kidnapped the Jarl's son 20 years ago?
You mean Hildolf the Skull-Splitter? Remember when we rounded up the townspeople and dragged him out of that cave?
Those were the days. I'd never seen my husband fight so bravely before.
Aye, to your husband. Divines bless his memory.
Tough day at the mines. I swear the ore is getting harder to dig.
You're just getting older.
That's why I come here to talk to you. You're all heart.
You should quit working in the Eastern Mine. Leigelf's no good to work for.
Leigelf is a good man, and I'm not running out on him now.
Oh, got a bit of an interest in your boss do you?
No, not that it's any of your business.
That thing was a dragon. No doubt. Just like the children's stories and the legends. The harbingers of the End Times.
This way.
Come on, hurry up.
Better to stick together down here.
Let's see where this goes.
Good dog.
Stupid dog.
No going back that way, now.
We'd better push on. The rest of them will have to find another way out.
Hmm. That doesn't go anywhere.
I guess we'd better try this way.
Hold up. There's a bear just ahead. See her?
I'd rather not tangle with her right now. Let's try to sneak by. Just take it nice and slow, and watch where you step.
Go ahead. I'll follow your lead and watch your back.
Almost there.
Whew. That was close.
Sneaking is overrated, eh?
That looks like the way out! I knew we'd make it!
Surely even down in Cyrodiil people have heard news of the war in Skyrim?
The Nords are tired of spending our blood fighting the Empire's wars, and paying for the Empire's decadence with our taxes.
Ulfric is our rightful High King. He's leading the fight to drive the Empire out of Skyrim, once and for all.
You haven't heard of the civil war in Skyrim? I guess down in Cyrodiil people have other things to worry about.
It's pretty simple. Ulfric founded the Stormcloaks years ago, as a sort of private army to advance his ambitions.
He's always used the ban on the worship of Talos to stir people up against the Empire.
He never succeeded in getting much support, so a few months ago he murdered the High King! That got the Empire's attention.
I was assigned to Ulfric's guard. We were on our way to Darkwater Crossing, in the south of Eastmarch.
The Imperials were waiting for us. As pretty an ambush as I ever saw. We were outnumbered five to one, at least.
Ulfric ordered us to stop fighting. Didn't want us all to die for nothing, I guess.
I thought they were taking us south to Cyrodiil. Parade us in front of the Emperor. But then we stopped in Helgen, and you know the rest.
A masterstroke by General Tullius! He's only been in charge here for a few months, but he's turned things around for the Empire.
We've been trying to catch Ulfric since the war started, but he always seemed to slip through our fingers... like he knew we were coming.
This time, the General turned the tables on him. Ulfric rode right into our ambush with only a few bodyguards.
He surrendered pretty meekly, too. So much for his death-or-glory reputation.
I thought we were taking Ulfric back to Cyrodiil, but I guess the General changed his mind. You know the rest.
I swear, if I wasn't around, Elgrim would forget to eat his meals. How we make any coin at all is beyond me.
In fact, I need to arrange for someone to pick up an ore sample for me in Shor's Stone... goodness knows Elgrim won't lift a finger to do it.
When Elgrim said we were setting up shop down here, I told him he would catch his death.
The dirt, the moisture... it's disgusting. Who wants to spend their life living like a skeever?
But that old bellyacher just fed me some nonsense about light ruining his mixtures and being close to the water... agh.
I know how to mix a few basic potions, but I'm nowhere near as skilled as a master alchemist.
I've picked up a few tricks by reading the tomes scattered all over the shop, but I don't have the knack to pull half of the formulas off.
Oh! No, I didn't mean it that way. Elgrim can barely put his on his own shoes let alone have the energy to pursue a young girl.
He's been gushing about how talented Ingun is at alchemy. He'd never say it to her face; that's not his way.
I just think Elgrim's taken it upon himself to mentor the young thing so he focuses a lot of attention on her.
You would? Oh, that would be wonderful.
Speak to Filnjar in Shor's Stone. He's got some sort of ore sample he wants us to identify and was willing to pay us well for it.
The job pays well, so I hope I can make arrangements soon. We could really use the gold.
It's about time; I sent them a letter weeks ago. That Elgrim... he'd forget his own pants if his wife didn't help him dress.
Here you go. Tell Hafjorg that she can chip off whatever she thinks is a fair trade for their time.
Redbelly is supposed to be nothing but an iron mine. Been working it for years.
Then right before the spiders had moved in, we found that chunk of ore. Never seen anything like it.
I want to know what I'm dealing with before I start tearing it out of the ground.
Thank you. I'll be sure to get Elgrim to examine this as soon as his... busy schedule allows.
Here, I had him make you a few things for all that travel.
I do. Sadly, I'm one of the few traditional Saxhleel Jewelers that remains in Tamriel; it's becoming a lost art.
Only trouble is gathering materials has become hazardous. The roads to the mines and to the other cities are thick with bandits... and worse.
Would you be interested in gathering some materials for me? I'd certainly be happy to compensate you.
Thank you, marsh-friend.
Thank you, land-strider.
I'm seeking a small list of items to complete my next creation: two flawless sapphires, a mammoth tusk and a chunk of gold ore.
Forgive me. It's a term I haven't used in some time. While most in Tamriel call my kind Argonian, we prefer the term Saxhleel.
Forgive me. It's a term I haven't used in some time. While most in Tamriel would call us Argonian, we prefer the term Saxhleel.
Madesi was actually my original Saxhleel name. Unlike others, I decided to embrace tradition and keep it that way.
Good, these will make wonderful settings for my rings.
The ivory from this tusk will be perfect for the inlay on my amulets.
Perfect. Melting this down will give me plenty of gold for those necklaces I started.
No, I think I have enough here to get started.
Here, let me give you this. It's the least I can do for all your trouble.
And this must be the Hall of Stories.
Oh... I've heard of this. These walls are supposed to show the history of the ancients who built this place.
Too bad we can't read these carvings.  Who knows what secrets we'd uncover?
One thing at a time soldier. Focus on our primary mission. We're searching for the crown.
Looks like we weren't the first ones here, either.
Even if these carvings tell us where the crown is, I'm sure we're going to have to find a way through this door.
See what you can figure out auxillary, I'm going to check out these carvings over here. Let me know if you find something.
Hmm... what is that? Some kind of stone claw? I wonder what it's used for.
Careful! I wouldn't do that again unless you know for sure it's going to open.
Uh oh! Look out!
Looks like the door will open if we turn these rings the right way.
Maybe there's something on the claw itself that could help us.
Now that you've transacted the Oath, it's time to reveal the final piece of the puzzle to you; Mercer's true crime.
Mercer was able to unlock the Guild's vault without two keys because of what he stole from the Twilight Sepulcher... the Skeleton Key.
By doing this, he's compromised our ties to Nocturnal and in essence, caused our luck to run dry.
Well, yes. But the Key isn't only restricted to physical barriers.
All of us possess untapped abilities; the potential to wield great power, securely sealed within our minds.
Once you realize the Key can access these traits, the potential becomes limitless.
Ah, so they've finally sent someone to deal with that lunatic.
Well, is it taken care of?
Well, that's good to know. I suggest you tell your people at the College to keep a tighter leash on their mages.
I'm afraid so. There's a problem with one of the Jarls here in Skyrim.
He's been complaining of a member of the College running amok in his hold.
She's been complaining of a member of the College running amok in her hold.
We have, of course, severed all ties with the mage in question, but the Jarl isn't appeased.
So, the mage needs to be [QUOTE]taken care of,[QUOTE] if you understand me.
This city is crawling with Imperial Legion, and you know what? I'm still nervous.
All these damn Stormcloaks. They're making me nervous. Never in a million years did I imagine they'd gain control of Solitude.
Lazy and useless, the lot of them. They can't even keep the Stormcloaks in line. No way I trust them with the Emperor's life.
I'm all for diplomacy, but the sooner the Emperor deals with this civil war mess, the sooner we can get back to Cyrodiil.
You worry too much. The Emperor's never been safer. You think assassination attempts are planned overnight? We discovered the plot. End of threat.
I suppose. But what about the old man? Son killed, family name ruined... and he acts as if nothing even happened. Think he's even fit for duty?
I'm going to pretend I didn't hear that. Commander Maro is the best the Penitus Oculatus has ever produced. You should be half the man he is.
You misunderstand. It's just... I feel for him, is all. To carry a weight like that. It's got to take its toll. That happened to me, I'd be a wreck.
Are you now? You were at Helgen, one of the prisoners. Although no one seems to know how you got mixed up in that affair.
Normally, I would have welcomed someone like you -- resourceful, clearly no friend of the Empire.
But I've had some disturbing reports of you... seen talking to General Tullius in Castle Dour, for example.
So what do you have to say for yourself? How can I be sure you're not an Imperial spy?
You... you were at Helgen. One of the prisoners. What makes you think I'm interested in someone like you for the Legion?
You... what? How could you possibly...
Oh, so you're trying to play both sides, is that it? What do you really want?
You'd do well to get out of here before I change my mind and have you locked in irons...
Well... you did show remarkable initiative. And you didn't have to bring the crown to me...
But let me warn you - joining the Legion is for life. Any previous loyalties... I trust we understand each other.
You can prove your new allegiance to me, by delivering an important message to the Jarl of Whiterun.
So you as good as admit you're working for the Imperials. Yet you walk in here, and ask to join me. What are you playing at?
The Imperials wouldn't have just let you walk away. Remember that.
You're not short of guts, are you? What's your game?
Why would Tullius waste resources getting the crown only to give it to me? Poisoned perhaps? No. He's not that cunning.
Alright. I believe you. You aren't the first to turn away from the Empire in disgust.
But remember - you're one of us now, forever. Whatever Imperial loyalties you may have had... that's all in the past, forgotten.
Now, to prove yourself to me, I have a task for you. Take my axe, and deliver it to the Jarl of Whiterun.
Dear brother, I need you to steal into that chamber, and eavesdrop on their meeting.
It'll be no use clinging to the shadows. They'll see you for sure. No, you need a hiding place. Somewhere they'd never think to look.
Like inside the Night Mother's coffin.
Dear sister, I need you to steal into that chamber, and eavesdrop on their meeting.
It'll be no use clinging to the shadows. They'll see you for sure. No, you need a hiding place. Somewhere they'd never think to look.
Like inside the Night Mother's coffin.
Beyond this gate is the first step in becoming a Nightingale.
Okay, lass. We've got these getups on... now what?
What sort of arrangement? I need to know the terms.
No shipments have come in.
What do I pay you for, to stand around all day? You're supposed to be bringing goods to the store.
There are no goods to bring to the store. That's what I'm saying.
Lazy oaf.
Where are my goods? Did the shipment come in?
Only a few things came today. Cedran said he'd drop it off later.
Cedran said he'd... what am I paying you for? Next time, you bring the shipment in yourself.
Careful. You spill one drop of silver, I'm taking it out of your hide.
I'm being as careful as I can.
Did you just talk back to me? I'm not paid to listen. I'm paid to keep you working. Now work.
Mulush, we need a break. The heat from the smelter is too much.
Are you complaining? Work. If you have strength to whine, you have strength to smelt.
I could smelt metal in half the time as you weak-willed pink-skins. Do I have to do everything?
No Mulush. I'll work harder.
I don't want any of you thieving workers even thinking about stealing any silver.
If I see you sneaking off with even one speck of silver, I'll break your leg and throw you into the river.
Yes, Mulush.
Careful of the molten metal. That gets on you, kiss your fingers goodbye.
I know what I'm doing. Stop telling me.
Divines, I'm tired. This is too much work.
Just keep at it, or Mulush will beat you.
Ha, I knew you'd join up! Great news. We'll take back Skyrim together, eh?
I'm glad I'll have you beside me in there. This place chills my blood, and I don't care who knows it.
I remember you... you were with us at Helgen. I heard you joined us. Welcome to the Stormcloaks!
Ooh... This place really chills the blood, eh?
These old ruins... My father always told me to stay away from them. Good advice, I'd say.
You, too, huh? I'd take a straight fight with the whole Legion over creeping around a place like this.
But never mind all that. We've got a job to do, and nothing's going to stand in our way.
You must be the new recruit. Welcome to the Legion.
At least we got the damn crown. I hope it was worth it.
I wish the Legate would let us clear out of here. Place gives me the creeps.
I don't know what we're doing here, but orders are orders.
I keep thinking I see something moving in the shadows...
I hope we don't run into anything worse than Stormcloaks in here.
It's the waiting that gets me.
I don't like the look of this place.
Nobody allowed in. Ulfric Stormcloak's orders. Consider yourself warned.
You must be the new unblooded. Welcome to the fight, brother.
You must be the new unblooded. Welcome to the fight, sister.
At least we got the damn crown. I hope it was worth it.
I wish Galmar would hurry it up. We shouldn't be here.
I don't know what we're doing here. Ulfric must have his reasons.
I keep thinking I see something moving in the shadows...
What are we waiting for?
I hope we don't run into anything worse than Imperials in here.
Keep a sharp eye out.
Don't interfere with Imperial Legion business. Now move along, unless you want three inches of steel in your gut.
The terms are quite simple, Brynjolf. Nocturnal will allow you to become a Nightingale and use your abilities for whatever you wish.
And in return, both in life and in death, you must serve as a guardian of the Twilight Sepulcher.
Aye, there's always a catch. But at this point, I suppose there isn't much to lose.
If it means the end of Mercer Frey, you can count me in.
What about you? Are you ready to transact the Oath with Nocturnal?
Good. After I open the gate, please stand on the western circle.
By transacting the Oath with Nocturnal, you're entering into a business deal.
You'll be provided all of the power and knowledge befitting a Nightingale.
You're free to use those powers as you see fit to further your own goals or the goals of the Thieves Guild.
In return, you'll be required to defend the Twilight Sepulcher and everything within when the need arises.
More importantly, upon your death, your spirit will be bound to the Twilight Sepulcher as one of its guardians.
Once the Oath has been struck, the terms are binding.
Knowing this, are you ready to undergo the ceremony?
How's the forge today?
It's fine. Much better than the rickety tools I had in the Legion.
Remember that old rusty sword I had? Damn thing must have had over a hundred chips in it.
Well, if you had learned to swing it correctly. A sword is an extension of the arm, not a meat cleaver.
I was about to say how impressed I was that you always managed to put it back together.
Flattery doesn't suit you, Thongvor.
Hello, my friend. Come to visit the forge?
I grow tired of counting coin all day. Put steel in my hand, not gold.
Your family's success burdens you, does it?
Sometimes I miss the Legion, back when the Empire stood up for Skyrim.
No politics, Thongvor. I told you before.
Good to see you, my friend! I knew you'd make a proper Legionnaire.
I'm glad you'll be with me in there. I don't like the looks of this place... and I'm not talking about the Stormcloaks.
I remember you... You were with us at Helgen... I heard you came around and picked the right side. Welcome to the Legion!
I'm glad you're with us. I don't like the looks of this place... and I'm not talking about the Stormcloaks.
These old ruins... They don't want us here, the ancient ones. Better left alone.
But never mind all that. We're the Emperor's soldiers. We'll do our duty no matter what stands in our way, right?
You, too, huh? I'd much rather a straight up fight than creeping around a place like this.
You've come for me, have you?
You think I don't know what you're up to? You think I can't destroy you?
The power to unmake the world at my fingertips, and you think you can do anything about it?
Come then. See what I can do now.
You're the one with the staff, my boy.
You're the one with the staff, my dear.
If it can help us get inside the College, and reach Ancano, we'll have to hope that there's a way to stop all this.
Be on your guard. I've no idea what to expect inside the College.
Head for the Great Hall, quickly! Don't stop for anything!
Ah, at last. I've been anxiously awaiting your return.
Why are you here? Killing Gaius Maro is but the first step of your contract - you must also plant the incriminating letter on his body...
Yes, I know. As does Astrid. You have done well, and have earned both your reward, and a bonus, as I may have mentioned.
But you should know that we have a more pressing matter to deal with.
It's... Cicero. There's been an incident. You should proceed into the Sanctuary. I'll let Astrid explain.
Yes, I know. As does Astrid. And you've earned your payment, though the bonus is forfeit, as I'm sure you're aware.
But you should know that we have a more pressing matter to deal with.
It's... Cicero. There's been an incident. You should proceed into the Sanctuary. I'll let Astrid explain.
What should we have tonight?
Something simple, a stew perhaps.
Stew again, papa? I want steak.
Maybe we could spend a little bit more and buy some meat, Endon.
Maybe. Let me think about it.
Markarth has changed, but the inn is as lively as ever.
The city hasn't changed that much, dear. Same old dwarven stones gathering the same old moss.
The stones aren't what bother me, love. The Forsworn are tearing the Reach apart.
Let's not talk about this over dinner.
Look at you, begging on the streets. Learn a trade.
Picking on me again, you backbiting Nord? Tired of those prissy nobles turning down your rotten slabs of venison?
How dare you. No one turns down cut meat from Hogni Red-Arm!
Hogni Red-Arm, more like Hogni Fat-Arm.
Alms. Give me some meat, you fat Nord!
What did you say to me, Reachman?
I said give me some meat. I'm hungry, and the Divines know you don't need more food in that huge gut of yours.
You little twig. I'll snap you in two!
Just try it. Maybe a little time inside Cidhna Mine will get rid of all that fat on you.
Damn him - the old bear was right! Did you run into any trouble?
I'm glad you're here.
If you'll follow me, I'll try to explain on the way.
This is the headquarters of the Nightingales, cut into the mountainside by the first of our kind.
We've come to seek the edge we need to defeat Mercer Frey.
So, this is Nightingale Hall. I heard about this place when I joined the Guild, but I never believed it existed.
The assumption that the Nightingales were just a myth was seeded within the Guild on purpose.
It helped avert attention from our true nature.
What's wrong, Brynjolf? I can almost hear your brow furrowing.
I'm trying to understand why I'm here, lass. I'm no priest, and I'm certainly not religious. Why pick me?
This isn't about religion, Brynjolf... it's business.
This is Nightingale Hall. You're the first of the uninitiated to set foot inside in over a century.
It's my hope that you will, yes.
This isn't about religion or destiny. This is nothing more than a business transaction between yourself and Nocturnal.
Consider this an extremely risky job but with a massive potential for profit, and you'll do fine.
I call upon you Lady Nocturnal, Queen of Murk and Empress of Shadow... hear my voice!
My Lady, I've come before you to throw myself upon your mercy and to accept responsibility for my failure.
Lady Nocturnal, we accept your terms. We dedicate ourselves to you as both your avengers and your sentinels.
We will honor our agreement in this life and the next until your conditions have been met.
I have two others that wish to transact the Oath; to serve you both in life and in death.
Listen, lad. There's one last piece of business we need to settle before we go after Mercer... the leadership of the Guild.
Listen, lass. There's one last piece of business we need to settle before we go after Mercer... the leadership of the Guild.
I don't know how you made it this far, but you'll go no farther.
It's a curse! It has to be! I've got to get out of this town.
Irgnir, get a hold of yourself. They're just dreams. Please tell her, Erandur.
It's the same dream over and over again. You think that's normal? It's evil I tell you!
Erandur, she has a point. You keep telling us no harm will follow these dreams, but they must be an omen.
I... I will. Thank you...
Now, we'll take our friend here back to Hammerfell, where she will pay the price for her treason.
Not on the way back. Once she gets there, it's not up to me to decide what's done with her.
And as for you, I owe you a portion of the reward, don't I?
Well, here you go. Spend it wisely, and if I may... Don't allow yourself to be fooled by a pretty face. You're better than that.
Stay your hand, warrior!
It's no secret why you're here and you have proven your skill in combat. Let us talk a moment, and no one else needs to die.
I think we can all profit from the situation in which we find ourselves.
My men will not attack you, if you will lower your weapons.
Brynjolf, the time has come to decide Mercer's fate. Until a new Guild Master is chosen, the decision falls to you.
Aye, lass... and I've come to a decision.
Mercer Frey tried to kill both of you, he betrayed the Guild, murdered Gallus and made us question our future. He needs to die.
We have to be very careful, Brynjolf. Mercer is a Nightingale, an Agent of Nocturnal.
Then it's all true... everything I heard in the stories. The Nightingales, their allegiance to Nocturnal and the Twilight Sepulcher.
Just outside of Riften, beyond the Southeast Gate is a small path cut up the mountainside.
At the end of that path is a clearing and an old standing stone. I'd ask you both meet me there.
I suggest you talk to Karliah first. She has some news that'll turn your stomach.
Time's wasting and Mercer's still out there. Let's get this show on the road.
This is enough to make your head spin, eh?
I think we should trust the lass and take the deal.
I'm just as puzzled as you, lad.
I'm just as puzzled as you, lass.
I think we can trust Karliah. Let's see what she's on about.
I have some preparations of my own to make. I'll meet you at the stone.
Not now, lad. Karliah said it was important.
Not now, lass. Karliah said it was important.
We'll speak when the Oath is complete.
You appear ready for the Oath.
You appear hesitant to don your Nightingale Armor. What's troubling you?
It's just ahead. Please, keep following.
I'm preparing to leave for the standing stone. What is it?
I promise you, all your questions will be answered. You just have to trust me.
From the moment you were struck with my poisoned arrow at Snow Veil Sanctum, my path changed its course.
Perhaps I couldn't bring Mercer back alive, but together, we were able to clear my name and to put Gallus's memory to rest.
I'd always intended Mercer's fate to ultimately be decided by the Guild, and it seems they've spoken.
Get to Windhelm with the crown as quick as you can. Tell Ulfric he owes me a drink.
It's the rebels! Defend the entrance!
Stormcloaks!
Yes. An axe. How long have you been in Skyrim. Give the man my axe.
If he keeps it, I will bide my time. If he returns it to you, it means war.
Men who understand each other often have no need for words.
There are but a few simple truths behind one warrior giving another his axe.
Balgruuf will know my meaning.
Men who understand each other often have no need for words.
There are but a few simple truths behind one warrior giving another his axe.
Hrongar will know my meaning.
Keep your wits about you. The Jarl of Whiterun is known for his temper.
Get yourself kitted out with what you need. Welcome to the fight, brother!
This temple is dedicated to Mara, and the light of love she shines on us all.
I'm only a humble acolyte, though. If you wish to avail yourself of Mara's blessing, you should speak with Dinya Balu or Maramal.
They should be back shortly. You're welcome to wait here if you like.
Mind you, it's no business of mine what each Companion does in the name of honor.
But this sneaking around. It doesn't befit warriors of your standing. Aela knows better, and so should you.
In any case, I have a task for you.
Have you heard the story of how we came to be werewolves?
Aye, that sounds like him.
As in all matters of faith, though, the reality is more complicated than one believer would tell you.
The boy has a nugget of truth, but the reality is more complicated than that.
It always is.
The Companions are nearly five thousand years old. This matter of beastblood has only troubled us for a few hundred.
One of my predecessors was a good, but short-sighted man. He made a bargain with the witches of Glenmoril Coven.
If the Companions would hunt in the name of their lord, Hircine, we would be granted great power.
They did not believe the change would be permanent. The witches offered payment, like anyone else.
But we had been deceived.
The witches didn't lie, of course. But it's more than our bodies.
We'll get to that.
It's not so simple as just killing them, though.
Ah yes, their trickery.
The disease, you see, affects not just our bodies. It seeps into the spirit.
Upon death, werewolves are claimed by Hircine for his Hunting Grounds.
For some, this is a paradise. They want nothing more than to chase prey with their master for eternity.
And that is their choice. But I am still a true Nord. And I wish for Sovngarde as my spirit home.
That's what I've spent my twilight years trying to find out.
And now I've found the answer. The witches' magic ensnared us, and only their magic can release us.
They won't give it willingly, but we can extract their foul powers by force.
I want you to seek them out. Go to their coven in  the wilderness. Strike them down as a true warrior of the wild.
And bring me their heads. The seat of their abilities. From there, we may begin to undo centuries of impurity.
You shall have no Shield-Brother this time. But the spirit of Ysgramor goes with you, to restore the honor of his legacy.
Good. Now move quickly. And don't leave any of them alive.
This is not about your desires, lad.
This is not about your desires, lass.
I hope it was important, because it means you weren't here to defend him.
One of the fiercest battles I've ever seen.
The Silver Hand. They finally found enough courage to attack Jorrvaskr.
We fought them off, but...
The old man... Kodlak... he's dead.
No, but they made off with all our fragments of Wuuthrad.
But you and I are going to reclaim them.
We will bring the battle to their chief camp. There will be none left living to tell their stories. Only songs of Jorrvaskr will be sung.
We will avenge Kodlak. And they will know terror before the end.
The others have probably prepared Kodlak's funeral by now.
Come up to the Skyforge to pay your respects.
Before the ancient flame...
We grieve.
We grieve.
We grieve.
For the fallen...
Return Wuuthrad to Ysgramor. It should open the way.
Do you have the fragments of Wuuthrad, still?
I'll need to prepare them for mounting again.
Don't get too flowery on me, lad.
Don't get too flowery on me, lass.
Of course. My fellow Harbingers and I have been warming ourselves here. Trying to evade Hircine.
And so slain the beast inside of me.
I thank you for this gift. The other Harbingers remain trapped by Hircine, though.
Perhaps from Sovngarde, the heroes of old can join me in their rescue. The Harrowing of the Hunting Grounds. It would be a battle of such triumph.
And perhaps some day, you'll join us in that battle. But for today, return to Jorrvaskr. Triumph in your victory.
And lead the Companions to further glory.
Aela's laid claim to your services, and I've learned the hard way not to upset her. Best you stick to her for now.
Aela said you were hers, and I wasn't supposed to interfere. She scares me.
And there is more work to be done, but I fear that Kodlak's gotten wind of our recent efforts. He's asked to see you.
My advice? Always be honest with the old man, but don't tell him anything he doesn't need to know.
Where have you been?
We did well today, Shield-Brother.
We did well today, Shield-Sister.
They're mercenaries, only in it for the money. They're led by a man named Kematu. Get rid of him, and the rest will scatter.
I don't dare show my face, lest they recognize me, so you'll have to find out where they are.
Please, our tribe suffers and we need help.
Our Chief, Yamarz, was once a strong and proud warrior. Now he is stricken, cursed.
He is weak, and so our tribe is weak. The giants sense this, and intrude on our territory. Now they assault our very home.
Yamarz refuses help, but I sense that you may be just what we need.
No, don't go!
No, don't go! You may not be one of our tribe, but you are an Orc nonetheless!
We meet at last, my dear lady.
What is this?
What have you done?
Oh, come now. You didn't really expect to manipulate people forever, did you? Your luck had to run out sometime.
But where will I go? I can't keep running forever!
After all this, I have to pick up and leave again?
If you really think this is the only way, I trust you. Let's not waste any time.
Keep talking, little man, and we'll see who gets [QUOTE]punished.[QUOTE]
Hmph.
Wait, oh wait. I know you! Yes, yes. From the road! Cicero never forgets a face.
Another member of the Family! Hello, hello. So very good to meet you.
No time to talk now, my friend. No time. Out mistress needs tending. Keeping.
Why talk? Cicero has nothing to say to you. Call it a matter of... trust.
Oh, I do wish we could get to know each other better. But not now! I must tend to mother. See her settled.
I am! I am! But not just my mother. Our mother, hmm? The Night Mother! Oh yes!
And you helped me! You helped poor Cicero! You talked to Loreius, got him to fix my wheel!
Oh, you may have pleased me, but you have surely pleased the Night Mother. And our mother, she will never forget.
I am! I am! But not just my mother. Our mother, hmm? The Night Mother! Oh yes!
But you disappeared! You were there... then you weren't! Did you mean to help poor Cicero or not? I'm left to wonder...
Ah, it doesn't matter. What's done is done, right? Cicero is here! As is the Night Mother! Joy of joys!
I am! I am! But not just my mother. Our mother, hmm? The Night Mother! Oh yes!
Oh, but you didn't help poor Cicero! You helped that stupid farmer! Stupid Loreius! Oh, the guard said cruel things about us. Untrue things...
He said I attacked someone! On the road! But it never happened. Never. Sweet mother and I were just waiting. My knife was sheathed!
He said I was transporting weapons! For the war! In mother's coffin! He made me... open it! Indignity! Sacrilege!
He said I stole something! Me! Poor Cicero. A common thief. The very thought is insulting. One might even say... maddening.
So polite! So nice! Cicero likes you. The Night Mother is sure to like you too. Oh, we're going to be fast friends. Fast friends.
Do you mistrust poor Cicero? I am, as you say, just an innocent jester. A fool! Oh, but my work is not foolish, no. For I am our mother's Keeper.
Oooh... So silent. So menacing. A true assassin of the old way. Cicero likes you. Oh yes, Cicero likes you, indeed.
Follow me. Quickly and quietly now. I want their guts on the ground before they even know we're here.
But do not make the mistake of underestimating the Legion. Plenty of them are Nords same as us.
You hear anything?
I've found the final resting place of the Jagged Crown. Can you believe it? Well, I'm almost certain.
We're headed to Korvanjund. But, if old King Borgas is indeed buried there, we're bound to run into trouble of some kind.
Your fellow Stormcloaks are already assembling outside the tomb. I'll meet you there as soon as I'm finished up here.
Get the crown. We will keep an eye out for more of those dustmen.
That crown should be around here somewhere. Just keep an eye out for the bonewalkers...
The Imperials are here in force. Stick together.
What's the Legion doing here? Damn Imperial spies... Well, should be fun for us, at least. They don't seem to know we're here yet.
Ready to spill some Imperial blood for Skyrim?
You ready?
Even the Imperials might eventually decide to patrol their perimeter. Get yourself ready!
That's what I like to hear.
Alik'r, hold!
You've proven your strength, warrior. Let's avoid any more bloodshed.
I think you and I have some things to talk about.
Be careful on the way to Solitude. Damn Stormcloaks could be anywhere.
We'd better keep moving. I feel like that dragon might be up there watching us right now.
Good luck. If you get a chance, look me up in Solitude.
I'm going to rest up here a while before heading to Windhelm. Be careful.
We'd better keep moving. I don't want to run into any Imperials who know what happened at Helgen.
Good luck. Come to Windhelm and talk to Ulfric. You won't regret it.
See if you can find some, and I'll try to find some more interesting work by the time you get back.
A citizen of the Reach has been kidnapped.
A citizen of Haafingar has been kidnapped.
A citizen of Hjaalmarch has been kidnapped.
A citizen of Falkreath has been kidnapped.
A citizen of Whiterun has been kidnapped.
A citizen of the Pale has been kidnapped.
A citizen of the Rift has been kidnapped.
A citizen of Eastmarch has been kidnapped.
A citizen of Winterhold has been kidnapped.
A citizen of Skyrim has been kidnapped.
The Companions have been asked for assistance, and we shall answer. Particularly when the pay is as good as this.
Get moving. I shudder to think what might happen if you're too late.
People are rightly stirred up about the damn Thalmor being allowed to roam around arresting people, just for worshipping Talos.
But was it worth tearing Skyrim apart, and maybe destroying the Empire? No, Ulfric will have a lot to answer for in the end.
Nords have always supported the Empire, and the Empire has always been good for Skyrim.
I just hope the war doesn't come to Riverwood. There's enough trouble in the world without those Stormcloaks stirring up more.
So did I! If the damn Stormcloaks somehow found one, or woke it up... the war might be about to take an ugly turn.
Hard to believe it was just a coincidence, that the first dragon anyone's seen for centuries attacks just as Ulfric was about to be executed.
You didn't know? That was Ulfric Stormcloak and his top lieutenants.
Right, the leader of the Stormcloaks.
They claim to be fighting for Skyrim's freedom, but the war is really all about Ulfric wanting to be High King of Skyrim.
Oh, right, you were caught trying to cross the border into Skyrim, weren't you?
You're not kidding. Ulfric's the leader of the Stormcloaks - you know, the traitors trying to break Skyrim away from the Empire.
I guess that wasn't such a big deal elsewhere in the Empire, but here it's caused a lot of resentment. Native son and all that.
Even I'll admit it hasn't been the Empire's finest hour. But it wasn't like the Emperor had any choice, did he?
If he hadn't signed the peace treaty with the Thalmor, they would have destroyed the Empire - then where would Skyrim be?
That's the part that Ulfric's supporters always conveniently forget about. Unless the Empire stands together, the Thalmor will destroy us all.
It's from that treaty that ended the Great War, remember, when the Emperor was forced by the Thalmor to outlaw Talos worship.
We didn't pay much attention to it when I was a boy - everyone still had their little shrine to Talos.
But then Ulfric and his [QUOTE]Sons of Skyrim[QUOTE] started agitating about it, and sure enough the Emperor had to crack down.
Dragging people off in the middle of the night... one of the main causes of this war, if you ask me.
Name is Stig Salt-Plank, one of the captains of the Blood Horkers.
I've got a top man on the job right now. He should be returning any moment.
I've got a sharp woman on the job right now. She should be returning any moment.
This must be him, then.
This must be her, then.
Hard to say. The weather's taken a bit of a turn, here.
Haldyn's been known to obscure his hideaways with magic.
If we take care of him, the way should be clear to properly assault the island.
Impressive work. We started the attack once you made the fog scamper away like that.
Hope you didn't catch any of the fire.
We can head back whenever you're set. There's celebrating to be done!
The Empire may have been good for Skyrim once upon a time, but those days are long past.
Banning the worship of Talos was the last straw. Thalmor everywhere, dragging people off for honoring our own gods!
I'm glad Ralof is helping drive them out of here. If I was a bit younger, I might have joined the fight myself.
I've got enough to worry about, taking care of my family. I don't concern myself with such matters.
So you saw a dragon, did you? Tell me, what was it like? As big as a house?
Sure, sure. It's just, you know, not every day I meet someone who's laid eyes on a dragon.
Well I'll be! That'd be a sight to see.
Not that I actually want to see one, understand. I hope that dragon stays far away from here.
Don't even say such things! I hope that dragon stays away from Riverwood. We don't need that kind of trouble.
What? Oh, hardly! I don't think even Ulfric could pull a dragon out of his pocket.
Lucky for us it attacked when it did, eh? I wasn't looking forward to getting a shave from the Imperial headsman.
Seriously, you don't know? That was Ulfric Stormcloak himself.
Right. The leader of our fight against the Empire. I forget that most people don't know what he looks like, except for those Imperial wanted posters.
Oh, right, they said you were captured crossing the border.
Still, I'm surprised you haven't heard of Ulfric. He's our leader - the leader of the Stormcloaks.
I don't like this place. It feels like we're being... watched.
It's a simple job, Drennen. We get in, we steal the Lexicon, we leave. Don't get jumpy.
If you two cannot handle this, we can find others to hire.
Enough. Their services will be more than adequate. Let us continue.
This place is unbelievable.
Indeed. Avanchnzel is as much a library as it is a city. Built to hold the vast memories of the Dwemer.
Anavchnzel is waiting.
Why are all these metal... things... ignoring us?
I told you we should have hired a thief.
We are thieves, you fool. We're stealing the cube.
And yet none of us can pick a damned lock.
This place is huge.
It is large, indeed. I did not anticipate Avanchnzel's size or the time needed to uncover the entrance.
Maybe we should turn back. I don't want to sleep here.
Drennen, you do understand that the Lexicon at the bottom of this place holds the accumulated memories of centuries of Dwemer.
So?
So we're not turning back, you fool.
I thought you said these things were [QUOTE]sleeping[QUOTE]?
You said they were sleeping. I said they were waiting. It seems a few of them were [QUOTE]waiting[QUOTE] for someone to try and take the Lexicon.
Great.
The Lexicon had better be worth all this trouble.
I assure you, it is. The knowledge contained in the Lexicon created everything you see around you.
You sure that's power we're meant to have?
Absolutely.
Drennen!
Let the field mouse run. Your pay will be double.
My pay will be nothing if we die in here!
Calm yourself, Breya. We are closing in on the Lexicon. I can feel it calling. We'll continue without Drennen.
We are close now. Can you hear the Lexicon calling out?
So we grab it and we get out, right?
Once we have the Lexicon, we'll need to take it to its podium. I know what to do from there. Soon the Lexicon's knowledge will be mine.
Ours. Soon the Lexicon's knowledge will be ours.
We're almost there. I can hear the Lexicon. Come on. Quickly!
Something doesn't feel right.
Aaaaaaaaaaa....
I have the Lexicon! Where's the podium?
I can't hold these things! We need to leave!
I did not come all the way here just to walk out empty-handed.
The way out is right there! Run, damn it!
Yes, Yes. It is an ancient and ruined city. Built by the Dwemer. The dwarf folk. It is nearby, but I'd stay clear. People say it is quite dangerous.
You think I'd be in hiding if this was something I trusted town guards to handle?
These men are ruthless. Cunning, deceitful... they'll pay off whoever they can. I can't trust anyone here in Whiterun.
Guards and Jarls can be bought. And the Alik'r are close; I'm running out of time, so I'm choosing to trust you.
I don't know for sure. I spoke out against the Aldmeri Dominion publicly; I suspect that's why these men were hired to hunt me down.
Maven prefers that Aringoth remains alive, but if he tries to stop you from getting the job done, kill him.
The Guild has a lot riding on this. Don't make me look foolish by mucking it up.
Without them at our backs, we'd be in serious trouble.
Hey, I'm not done talking to you yet. Come back here!
Let me put it to you this way.
Nothing happens in Riften without Maven's consent. One word from her and you could spend the rest of the fourth era in prison.
I've already said too much.
I gave you what you came here for, now go. Leave me in peace.
Give it your best shot!
No! I'm not about to let you ruin everything I've worked so hard for!
That's between you and Maven and I prefer to keep it that way.
Just keep your ears open and your mouth shut and you'll do fine.
That's between you and Maven and I prefer to keep it that way.
Don't worry about it. Maven's business dealings usually involve quite a bit of gold for her people.
Of course... your pay. Haha! You're smart as a whip, lad.
Keep doing right by us and there's plenty more where that came from.
Of course... your pay. Haha! You're smart as a whip, lass.
Keep doing right by us and there's plenty more where that came from.
Changed your mind? You ready to pledge your blood and honor for Skyrim's freedom?
Never said that. Just that we don't get many of you wanting to join, that's all.
Here's a key to the house. Stay as long as you like. If there's anything else you need, just let me know.
If you really are Ralof's friend, I'll be glad to help you. But you didn't answer my question - how do you know him?
My sister Gerdur runs the mill in Riverwood, just up the road. I'm sure she'd help you out.
It's probably best if we split up. Good luck. I wouldn't have made it without your help today.
You know, you should go to Windhelm and join the fight to free Skyrim. You've seen the true face of the Empire here today.
If anyone will know what the coming of the dragon means, it's Ulfric.
So you are alive. I was starting to wonder.
Look for a way out! We are not going to burn to death in our own damned Sanctuary!
Come on! We've got to find a way out of here!
All I can tell you for now is that he's abused his authority as a Nightingale.
As a Nightingale, I took an oath and was sworn to secrecy.
Be patient and your time will come.
I don't have a clue. That door is impenetrable.
Without two keys, it's impossible to open. I have a key, Delvin has a key, and Mercer has a key. That's it. There are no other copies.
Before Mercer took over, Gallus started collecting every bit of material he could on locations the Guild could heist.
Museums, keeps, estates... you name it. By the time Mercer took over the Guild we must have had a few dozen.
Look, before I have you help track Mercer down I need to know what you learned from Karliah. I mean everything.
Aye. I feared that was the case. From that last entry in Gallus's diary, it looks like he was getting close to exposing Mercer to the Guild.
Anything else?
What? Nightingales? But, I always assumed they were just a tale... a way to keep the young footpads in line.
Was there anything else she told you?
Trying to make Mercer look bad in front of Maven, eh? Clever lass.
Was there anything else?
Look, you've already been told you're not allowed here. Turn around and go back the way you came.
We're causing no trouble. All we ask is to look for her.
I don't care what you're doing, after what happened you're lucky I don't toss you in jail. Now get lost.
We will be back. This is not over.
The College of Winterhold is an amazing sight. I've never set foot on the grounds, but always wanted to.
The Forsworn haven't been kind to Karthwasten. I've heard rumors that they've attacked this place without mercy.
I grew up in The Pale. This land was my home for most of my life... and for a Dunmer, that's quite a statement, I assure you.
We should bow our heads in silent reverence for those who are interred in Falkreath's cemetery.
I've always wanted to make a pilgrimage here to the Temple of Mara. Thank you for bringing me here... you've made me quite happy.
Watch your step, Markarth has quite a reputation thanks to the Silver-Blood family. I wouldn't advise crossing them.
What an amazing city. I've actually never managed to visit Whiterun, but I always wanted to.
Windhelm is absolutely freezing. How can these people tolerate it?
I was a student at the Bards College for a short time... until my affiliation with Vaermina was discovered. I haven't been back to Solitude since.
I've heard Riften's home to the worst Skyrim has to offer. I hope we don't run into any trouble while we're here.
Her Benevolence has taught me patience and mercy, but these vampires deserve none of it.
A good friend of mine was infected by a vampire long ago. He killed himself rather than change into one of those... things.
Vampires are utter abominations. We need to do everything in our power to destroy them.
Being a priest of Vaermina put me very close to dark sorcery at its worst.
Let's try and stay together, the sorcerers in these places tend to... well, harvest bodies for parts.
I've seen my share of black magic, but that's all in the past now.
This place must be cleansed. These draugr were once living beings and they deserve better.
These poor souls... suffering in eternal servitude.
The thought of the dead rising... makes me sick to my stomach.
Bandits know nothing of pity or mercy. No need to show them any either.
A group of bandits descended on Dawnstar once... if it wasn't for the guard, who knows what they could have done to the place.
Bandits are the worst lot. They'd steal from their own mothers given the chance.
I thought I heard footsteps. Be careful.
When I was a young acolyte of Vaermina, I paid my dues in a shrine located within the catacombs of a fort in Cyrodiil.
I served as a healer in a fort not unlike this one long ago.
I can't imagine what happened to the dwarves. How could a race with the capability to build a place like this simply vanish?
I've never been inside a dwarven ruin. They are simply astounding.
Did you hear that? A metal on stone sound... hmmm, perhaps it was nothing.
This place could be massive... very easy to get lost. We have to be careful not to lose our way.
What a marvel of engineering. The ancient Nords were ingenious builders.
Ugh, this place... horrible.
Watch yourself, these Nordic ruins are notorious for their traps.
These ruins are old, maybe a thousand years or more.
Why anything would chose to reside down here is beyond me.
These caves... they harbor ill omens, I can sense it.
Trust in Mara... she'll protect us in this dark place.
I don't like the looks of this place... not at all.
I don't know what persuaded you to assist me when we met in Dawnstar, but I'm glad you did.
I've done a lot of... questionable things in my life. Serving Vaermina was a horrible mistake, and I hope Mara will forgive me one day.
I was recruited as an acolyte of Vaermina as a young elf. I had no real childhood to speak of... we weren't permitted to socialize.
I've always felt a great deal of guilt running from Nightcaller Temple and leaving my friends to die. I'll never forgive myself for that.
After running from Nightcaller Temple, I wandered Skyrim for years until I was taken in by a priest of Mara who lived in Morthal.
Finding Mara was the greatest moment of my life. I'll never forget the warmth that spread through my heart when we embraced.
It was a bit difficult to come to the ways of Mara at first, but my fellow priests were kind and quite patient with me.
I've never admitted this before, but I've killed more than I care to admit. I'll just leave it at that.
My parents are long dead, but they lived wonderful lives... I have no sad stories to tell about them. Perhaps one day I'll visit their resting place.
I've been enjoying this journey with you. Not for the wealth we've accumulated, but just being carry Mara's will to every corner of Skyrim.
It's wonderful to be able to sleep soundly, don't you think?
The Greybeards are an amazing lot. Imagine, living your entire life without speaking to a friend or a loved one. I couldn't stand it.
I've been to Ivarstead a few times, but never climbed High Hrothgar. I wouldn't mind visiting the monastery at the summit.
When the weather permitted, Aerin and I would often walk the Rift's forests. The trees here are so beautiful.
Ah, Winterhold. I've always wanted to visit this place. The secrets locked inside must be astounding.
Incredible... imagine the manpower and ingenuity needed to carve the buildings of Markarth.
Whiterun is a such beautiful city. Have you ever seen the likes of this place?
This is the first time I've set foot in Windhelm. What a dreary place.
My mother always loved the sea. When I was young, we'd visit Solitude and watch the ships from the bluff. Ah... better times.
It feels good to walk the streets of Riften again.
Vampires... an unclean lot. It will be a pleasure to clear this place.
Don't let the vampires strike you or else you may get infected with their blood poisoning.
Be aware of rune traps on the ground or else this could be a very short expedition.
Kill these casters as fast as you can, otherwise they may summon creatures we don't want to deal with.
Ugh... dark sorcery. Always makes my skin crawl.
If there's one thing I'm certain of, it's that draugr burn like tinder. We could use that to our advantage.
Many have fallen in this crypt. The Draugr show no mercy.
Ugh, Draugr. They reek of decay.
When I was a child, my village was burned to the ground by bandits. Do you know I actually saw one laugh as he ran my brother through...
I hope there's more bandits around... their numbers could use a little more thinning.
These bandits would stab each other in the back if it meant an extra coin in their pockets.
Bandits... the worst type of scum.
Perhaps we can find some treasure if we search the grounds of the fort thoroughly.
If fought more than my share of bandits in places like this.
Keep your eyes open for ambushes. These forts have too many blind corners.
These are the most dangerous, but the most profitable types of ruins. The dwarves must have been a prosperous race.
Watch the walls for the sphere constructs... they can appear in the blink of an eye.
The dwarves were masters at subterranean construction... these ruins show  only a fraction of their capabilities.
Mzinchaleft. I swore I'd never return here.
I almost died in a ruin just like this.
Danger's about, I can tell. Be cautious.
Can you just imagine how ancient this place must be? Hundreds of years? Thousands?
There could be Draugr about, I can smell the decay in the air.
I've ventured into quite a few Nord ruins in my day.
Killed my first creature in a cave just like this... I'll never forget it.
I'm certain we'll find some treasure down here.
Keep your eyes open, I don't like the looks of this place.
Exploring these caves feels like coming home. I missed this.
I've really missed traveling like this. Walking the breadth of Skyrim has always filled my heart with excitement.
I've never been a sellsword... never traded my skills for pay. I've always adventured on my own terms.
You should have seen me at the height of my adventuring career... I was fearless and took too many risks. But that's what it was all about.
I remember a cutpurse trying to rob me on the road once. When I drew Grimsever, I think the poor man soiled his armor!
I've seen enough death to last three lifetimes, yet I never tire of a good fight. What do you make of that?
When I was young, I'd journey with my father on hunting expeditions into Morrowind. The cliff racers made for excellent sport.
I love the cold air... it's exhilarating. Perhaps it's because of my Nord blood, but there's something about it that makes me feel alive.
My father wanted me to follow in his footsteps as a hunter, but I set my aspirations a bit higher. He never complained... I miss him.
My mother was a strong woman... she's the one who instructed me on my swordfighting techniques. Can you imagine?
People say Skyrim is one of the most dangerous places in Tamriel. I think they're wrong... it's magnificent and I'm proud to call it home.
As we walk these stone passages, we delve into the very bones of the earth.
There is an unnatural chill in the air. Some evil power is at work in this place.
I do not envy those creatures that make a home in such cold, dark places as this.
Careful. Our footsteps will echo in every chamber and tunnel.
By the Nine, I'd pay good money for a pint of ale to warm my bones!
Curse this chill! I should have dressed more warmly.
If this cold numbs my fingers any worse, I'll scarcely be able to hold a weapon.
Gods, I'd hate to lose my footing in a place like this. A fall on this stony floor will break bones.
Take extra care you don't hit your head on a low-hanging bit of stone.
Mind your step. I think I spied a patch of ice on the floor.
Don't go stopping for a nap. If you fall asleep in this place, you'll never wake up.
Are you sure you can find your way? It would be easy to get lost in here.
This cold is unbearable. It's all I can do not to shiver until my teeth rattle.
Would it be foolish to stop for a while and light a fire? I suppose it would.
Gods willing, we'll find a chest full of gold in one of these chambers.
At times like this, I truly appreciate the joys of a warm fire and a stiff drink.
There are strange echoes in these caves. Keep you eyes open.
If a man can't feel at home in a freezing cave, then he isn't truly a Nord.
I have to admit, I admire your courage. Most folk in Skyrim wouldn't go near a place like this.
When I was a boy, my friends and I used to play [QUOTE]seek the wumpus[QUOTE] in caves much like this.
Caves sounded more exciting in the bard's songs.
It's kind of dark in here.
How deep is this cave?
It feels like a whole mountain of rock is above  us.
In a mine, the poor man labors to find precious stones that only the rich man can afford.
I wonder how many poor souls have lost their lives working these tunnels.
These earthen passages do not agree with me. I already miss the wind and sky.
The fewer of these mines we venture into, the happier I'll be.
The cloying air in this place is almost unbearable.
By the gods, let this mine be small so we can be done with it quickly.
My nose and mouth are so full of dust, I can hardly breath.
Wouldn't it be something if we found a vein of gold?
It would be easy for someone -- or something -- to sneak up on us down here.
Are you sure you wouldn't rather explore, say, a nice tavern?
Let's try not to make too much noise. I've heard that cave-ins can start that way.
I wonder what they were mining down here.
Let's hope the miners didn't unearth anything besides precious stones, if you take my meaning.
Not for all the gold in Skyrim would I spend my life working in these tunnels.
I've heard that miners sometimes die from poisonous gases trapped beneath the ground.
I'm already looking forward to getting back above ground.
You know what I miss the most right now? Fresh air.
It takes uncommon strength to work the mines in Skyrim. The earth here is cold and hard, like the heart of a Nord.
There's an old maid's tale that says our ancestors dug these mines with their bare hands.
I've half a mind to grab a pickaxe and start digging. Never know what you might find.
It seems warmer down here than it was outside.
Hard to believe people actually have to work in places like this.
Wonder what they mine from these walls.
I'll take a sword or mace over a pick axe any day.
Do you think we'll find gold nuggets in here?
It is strange to think that these chambers were once home to the ancient Nords.
I feel the eyes of angry spirits upon us. We are not welcome here.
Few would dare to trespass in these ruins. What you lack in wisdom, you make up for in courage.
Do not ask me to take treasures from this place. I will not risk the anger of the dead.
They say ruins like these are filled with treasure. Of course, they're filled with traps, too.
I could have sworn I heard something right behind us.
I'll bet some of these artifacts would fetch a good price. I hope they're not cursed.
I wonder what the ancient Nords did in these ruins. Unspeakable sacrifices, maybe?
If these ruins frighten you, take comfort in the knowledge that I am here.
Do try not to set off any traps, will you?
I suppose you intend to carry off every item of value in these ruins.
These ruins might be interesting if I wasn't already an expert on Nordic history.
Remember to check behind you every once in a while. Who knows what might try to sneak up on us.
Keep your eyes open for traps. Old ruins like this are usually filled with them.
The ancient Nords were a savage people, but they built some remarkable crypts and temples.
There's a lot of history in a place like that. I'll bet these walls could tell some amazing stories.
Look at this craftsmanship! These old halls fill some folk with dread, but as a Nord, they fill me with pride.
We're bound to find some gold in these ruins, but out of respect, let's leave a few coins for the dead.
It's strange to think that some of my own ancestors might be buried in here.
Plunder these ruins at your peril, friend. The spirits of the dead won't look kindly upon it.
Never knew a place could be so ancient. I bet it's over a thousand years old.
Wonder if any of my ancestors ever walked these halls?
Everything in here seems to be about death. Burial urns, crypts, funeral shrouds. It's a bit depressing.
I wonder what the ancient nords used this place for?
The Dwemer who built this place were sometimes called Dwarves, but history records that they were no shorter than humans.
There are scholars in Cyrodiil who have dedicated their lives to solving the mystery of the Dwemers' disappearance.
It is remarkable that so many of these ancient Dwemer creations still function.
There are those who believe that the entire Dwemer race will one day return just as suddenly as it vanished.
What good is a sword or an axe against an enemy made of brass and steel?
It's unnatural, building all these machines. If you ask me, the Dwemer got what they deserved.
I don't like fighting these Dwemer creations. Where's the fun in killing something that doesn't even bleed?
Watch out for the hot steam vents down here. They'll burn you worse than fire.
Had they placed their faith in magic instead of machinery, the Dwemer might still be around.
A living Dwemer was once discovered in Morrowind. Can you imagine it, being the last surviving member of your race?
I should bring some of these Dwemer artifacts to the Arcane University in Cyrodiil for study.
I wonder what keeps these machines working so long after their masters disappeared.
The Dwemer created so many wondrous machines, and yet nobody ever followed in their footsteps. Why is that, I wonder?
Among other things, the Dwemer were expert trap-makers. Watch the floor for tripwires and false plates.
I've half a mind to dismantle one of these Dwemer machines. I'd like to see how it works.
I suppose the warmth in this place comes from all the hot steam vents.
Scholars say the Dwemer were an advanced culture. Ha! The Nords outlasted their entire race. So much for being advanced.
I wonder why the Dwemer came to Skyrim. Why did they build this place? I suppose we'll never know.
Do these steel walls and strange Dwemer devices make you uneasy? Perhaps it's just me.
I've heard that you can sell Dwemer artifacts on the black market down in Cyrodiil. They fetch a handsome price, too.
This place is amazing! It's hard to believe that mortal hands built them.
What do you think these devices were for?
The stories don't say why the dwarves disappeared. I wonder if their machines turned on them.
It's amazing this place is so well preserved. There isn't even a hint of rust.
So many shadowy corners to strike from! I could learn to like this place.
Silence will serve us well in this place. Let us take our foes by surprise.
Be wary for traps. If you spy one, try to get an enemy to trigger it.
I can see the battle-lust in your eyes. Doom will surely come to any who cross your path.
If it wasn't for all the dangers in here, this place could almost be cozy.
When I was a child, I dreamed about having a fort like this all to myself.
I wonder if we'll come across some bandits who've just finished roasting a rabbit on a spit. Maybe they'll have a keg of ale, too.
If my ma could see me now, she'd scold me good. She'd tell me I should know better than to go poking around in abandoned forts.
This smell of dank earth and worm-eaten wood is going to make me lose my last meal.
How pathetic, being forced to eke out a miserable existence in a place like this.
Just look at this place. Is this what passes for a fort in Skyrim?
The sooner we can get out of this filth-pit, the better.
These timber supports are rotted through. It's a wonder this place is still standing.
Check every crate, chest and barrel you see. Who knows, maybe a few of them have something valuable inside.
Did you bring a torch? These old forts can get pretty dark inside.
There are forts like this all over Skyrim. The Imperials abandoned most of them a long time ago.
Just look at this place. I've seen better workmanship from Nord children only ten winters old.
So this is what passes for Imperial craftsmanship. Try not to sneeze, or you might bring the whole fort down.
What is that stench? Rotting wood, perhaps? That can't be good.
You'd have to be pretty desperate to want to make a home in this dank hole.
The Jarls never want to pay to keep the forts. They just keep slipping further into ruin.
I wonder what great battles were fought here?
Do you think Tiber Septim ever fought here?
I can see why they built the fort here. A small force could control most of the nearby land.
Outlaws and brigands are the lowest of the low. They prey on their own countrymen for profit.
I hope that when I die, I don't end up as a shambling corpse.
The Forsworn are as wild as wolves. Practice those old magics, so some folk say.
Wizards. Why is it always wizards.
It isn't just your blood that a vampire wants, it's your mortal soul.
Fighting draugr is as much about controlling your fear as anything else.
Most bandits are cowards. These seem to be braver than most.
These wizards are mad beyond reason. They understand only violence.
There is no greater madness than those who seek to become vampires. That's a dark bargain if there ever was one.
You can easily break a blade on the metal skin of a Dwemer construct.
I hate bandits and thieves. Men like these raid our town every year.
I hope that when I die, I don't end up as a shambling corpse.
The Forsworn are strange men. They fight to reclaim Markarth, but they live like savages.
I don't like wizards and their spells. Give me an axe any day.
These walking devices are strange yet amazing. What magic powers them?
I'd rather fight bandits than draugr. At least bandits know when to stay dead.
Taken alone, the draugr aren't so fearsome. They're far more deadly in greater numbers.
These Forsworn are just savages. They live in caves and ruins when civilized folk build towns and cities.
You can't argue with these mages. They'll attack you on sight.
It probably took some Dwemer craftsman a year to build one of those things.
There may be no enemy more foul than a walking corpse.
I thought about becoming a bandit. I decided I preferred clean clothes and fresh mead.
These ruins and their mechanical inhabitants are all that remain of the Dwemer.
It's said that the Forsworn make dark pacts with the Hagravens, and that is why they can use magic.
There is no adversary more deadly than a vampire. They are as cruel as they are cunning.
Bandits are desperate men. They have nothing to lose, and they fight like it.
What some call devotion to the dark arts, I call foolishness.
These Forsworn don't even have the decency to dress right.
Draugr are slow and clumsy. Hardly a challenge for a man like me.
I would find the Dwemers' mechanical guardians fascinating if they didn't try to kill everything on sight.
Don't get too far ahead.
Pleased enough, I suppose. At least they appreciate the ways and traditions of the Nord people.
Can't say I ever much liked the idea of the Empire telling us what to do an' how to do it.
Of course they have! I've made no secret of my loyalty to the Empire. I'm no coward.
Twice I've been robbed, and good luck getting any kind of justice from Vignar now that he's the Jarl. He probably told the Stormcloaks to do it.
Lately, they've been threatening to send my whole family into exile if we're caught collaborating with the Empire. They think we're spies!
Needless to say, these rebels and I have no love for each other.
I'm sure my brother Vignar is, since they made him Jarl after throwing Balgruuf out.
Comes the end of the day, Imperials and Stormcloaks ain't much different.
Both sides want to tell you how you should live your life. Guess I'd rather hear it from a real Nord than some Emperor down south.
With open arms, with cheers and song, with joy in my heart and tears in my eyes!
Praise be to Talos, this is a glorious day for Whiterun and for all Skyrim! Our liberators have come at last!
If the gods are merciful, they've found a safe place to hide in the city.
I hope Vignar doesn't find them. He'll ask a king's ransom, I'm sure.
If it's the war you're referring to, I'm on the side of Whiterun.
No doubt General Tullius and his friends in the Empire will tell you that I owe them my loyalty, and perhaps I do.
Ulfric Stormcloak would say that I owe my allegiance to the Nord people as they fight for Skyrim's independence. Perhaps this is also true.
The day might come when I am forced to draw my sword for one side or the other.
But that day has not come yet.
No doubt he thought it was the only way to make his point. And also because he knew he could.
The gold, the jewels... it's all gone.
That son-of-a-bitch! I'll kill him!
Vex! Put it away... right now.
We can't afford to lose our heads... we need to calm down and focus.
Delvin, Vex... watch the Flagon. If you see Mercer, come tell me right away.
Are you all right? What happened in there?
By the Nine...
Is he responsible for this? The Arch-Mage, dead?
There's more. Something's happened to Winterhold. It must be whatever Ancano did. You need to get out there and make sure it's safe.
Quickly now, quickly! I'll find Mirabelle and see if we can't put a stop to this!
I can hardly believe it.
But there's no time. Whatever happened here has affected Winterhold as well. I need you to get out there and make sure everything's all right.
I'll do what I can here. Go now, go!
He's my son. I just... I feel it in my heart. You'd understand if you had children.
You better have a damn good reason to be here with that murderer.
Please, lower your weapons so we can speak. I have proof that you've all been misled!
No tricks, Karliah or I'll cut you down where you stand.
Now what's this so-called proof you speak of?
I have Gallus's journal. I think you'll find its contents disturbing.
No, it... it can't be.
This can't be true. I've known Mercer too long...
There's only one way to find out if what the lass says is true. Delvin, I'll need you to open the Vault.
It's true, Brynjolf. Every word. Mercer's been stealing from the Guild for years, right under your noses.
Wait just a blessed moment, Bryn.
What's in that book? What did it say?
It says Mercer's been stealing from our vault for years. Gallus was looking into it before he was murdered.
That door has the best puzzle locks money can buy. There's no way it can be picked open.
He didn't need to pick the lock.
What's she on about?
Use your key on the vault, Delvin. We'll open it up and find out the truth.
I've used my key, but the vault's still locked up tighter than a drum. Now use yours.
By the Eight! It's gone, everything's gone! Get in here, all of you!
I'm glad you're here. I think some of these people are beginning to suspect who I am.
Are you ready to face the Guild?
Are you finished your other business and ready to face the Guild?
Keep your eyes open. I'm not sure what to expect when we enter the cistern.
Then we show them Gallus's journal and hope for the best.
Remember, we have proof and all he's got is his word.
Time is of the essence here, please hurry back.
It's hardly a secret that they have ties to the Empire, and hate anyone who speaks out against it.
Thorald did worse. He took action against the Empire, and the Battle-Borns knew it.
The Battle-Borns. The Emperor's biggest boot-lickers here in Whiterun.
Their connections to the Empire and the Legion are well-known. When Thorald didn't return home, there was no question in my mind.
They knew Thorald supported the Stormcloaks, knew he was going to aid them in battle. Made sure he didn't come back.
Locked him up someplace to get back at my family. I'm sure of it.
Bloody enough for you, outsider?
Markarth. Is it bloody enough for you?
Then turn around and go back where you came. City doesn't need you, doesn't want you.
Blood and silver are what flows through Markarth. That's the way it is. That's the way it'll stay.
Then you've found your home, friend. Blood and silver are what flows through Markarth. Welcome.
If I was threatening you, believe me, you'd know it.
You outsiders never learn. If the Forsworn don't get you, the guards will throw you in Cidhna Mine to work your fingers off.
Think that's water in the river? Blood and silver are what flows through Markarth, friend.
No. I live in a nice house in Solitude where the air isn't filled with smoke from the silver smelters and golden-haired girls shine my shield.
Been here ever since I left the Bards College. Turns out a few muscles earn more gold than a damn lute.
The Silver-Bloods pay me, let me crack a few skulls, and keep the guards off my back. That's all I need.
Jarl is who you want to talk to. Always coin to be made killing off some Forsworn in the hills.
As long as you don't mind going axe-to-axe with a bunch of Daedra-worshipping savages who practice the dark arts.
It's right there in the name of the most powerful family in Markarth. The Silver-Bloods.
They have a whole mine filled with prisoners to dig up silver ore, gets smelted by workers they pay, and they own half the city.
I work for them. The inn is named after them. When the guards make an arrest, they check with them first.
Why are you bothering me, kinsman?
Why are you bothering me, outsider?
Then you're talking to the wrong man. You want that elf in the keep. Calcelmo.
The only thing I'll tell you about Markarth is stay out of our business. We have enough around here without some outsider causing trouble.
I don't. Go bother Kleppr at the Silver-Blood Inn, he handles the newcomers.
And by Ysmir, if you find work, just do what you're told. There's enough trouble in Markarth already.
That's about the only harmless thing you can do in this city. Silver-Blood Inn is the place to go.
And once you've had your fill of mead, do us all a favor and go home. Markarth has enough trouble.
Grew up in a stronghold. Every Orc girl tended the forge at some point.
But a girl has to grow up, and life in the stronghold asked for a lot in return, so I joined the Legion. Mastered my trade there.
That's right. An Orc stronghold. Kept to ourselves. Lived as our ancestors would have wanted.
Wasn't enough for me, though. I left. Didn't want to end up as the third wife of some lowly chieftain.
You strike your metal like a new mother giving her babe a light slap. Hit it harder.
I'm sorry, Ghorza. I just... flinch, and uh....
If you can't pound the dusk out of your iron, it'll break when it's finished. Hit. It. Harder.
What am I supposed to do? Never leave the house? You want that, Endon?
You're closing the stall, and that's final.
You want to give up now? Out of fear? Is that what we're teaching our daughter?
Mama, why are you and papa fighting?
We're not fighting we're just.... Why don't I get you something to eat? Mama and papa will talk later.
Think we should buy more horses next season?
I'd rather spend the gold on a new litter of pups, but the horses bring in more gold.
How are the new breeds getting along with my dogs?
Haven't attacked each other yet. Good a sign as any.
Sure, what can I do for you?
Sure, what can I do for you?
For a generous fellow traveler? But of course. What would you like to hear?
Sorry friend, but it looks like you're a bit light in the purse, and the wayward minstrel can't afford to do free performances.
Sure, my voice could use a rest.
Well all right, then.
Would you now?
Well, spit it out. What's the matter?
Bah! Stop wasting my time!
What about him?
Did he now?
Nobody pilfers property on my watch.
My thanks for bringing this to my attention, citizen. Don't worry, I'll take care of it.
What?
How dare that little fool! And right under my nose!
