You've done a great service to the Silver-Blood family. I've had the Jarl officially pardon you, and taken care of a few other loose ends.
Yes, you're innocent. As innocent as anyone can be in this city.
I guess we also owe you something for locking you up. Here, my family's ring. And everything the guards confiscated from you.
Now if you'll excuse me, I have a mine that needs new workers to fill it.
Why are you still standing around here? Go get me the Phial, you fool.
Ooooh, an observant one. How clever to ask of Septimus.
This Dwemer lockbox. Look upon it and wonder.
Inside is the heart. The heart of a god! The heart of you. And me.
But it was hidden away. Not by the Dwarves, you see. They were already gone.
Someone else. Unseen. Unknown. Found the heart, and with a flair for the ironical, used Dwarven trickery to lock it away.
The scroll will give the deep vision needed to open it.
For not even the strongest machinations of the Dwemer can hold off the all-sight given by an Elder Scroll.
Who do you think brought Septimus here? Who do you think protected you on your journey to open the box and loose my knowledge on this world?
Your free will is an illusion. Whether you acknowledge me or not is your own business. But I will be in your mind.
What do you need?
Here's what I can spare.
Take a look.
Whatever. Just get back to work. Now.
Now now, brother. Arnoit is just being his usual gloomy self, he didn't mean it, did you Arnoit? You're just being silly again.
What was that?
You touch her, and I swear it'll be your fingers that go missing, you stupid Breton!
Voada, you spilled laundry water in the soup pot again! Do I need to cut off your fingers to teach you a lesson?
Move it. Get to work. Get to work!
Always another big meal to cook. Figures.
Right away, sir!
Filthy natives. Get to work. We have meals to prepare and no time to prepare them!
Nonsense, you're a vital part of my research team. You'll be there, have no fear! Now, I don't want to hear another word of protest.
Could I maybe, skip the excavation, Uncle Calcelmo? I, uh, I just think you won't need me.
The excavation, Aicantar! Right after I finish my book. We'll start excavating Nchuand-Zel again.
[QUOTE]Next season for sure...[QUOTE] What? Uncle Calcelmo, I don't understand what you mean.
Next season, nephew. Next season for sure....
Stop bothering me Aicanter!
Are you sure?
Just a man's life work, is all. I've finally derived the location of the White Phial, but this doting busybody won't let me get it.
Now, how would you like me to align the Phial's properties?
I'm not as skilled as Curalmil, so I'm afraid it will only ever refill with one type of liquid.
It's just one of those things that happens. The lungs just... give up. Even elves get old.
What's it matter to you? Not like you could do anything about it.
Um, no. Nothing. Nothing at all.
I just wanted to know if you needed anything.
What is it nephew? Can't you see I'm trying to think here?
Uncle Calcelmo....
Your job is to do what I say. And I say you have many nails and fittings to make before you even touch a blade. Now get to work.
When will I learn how to forge weapons and armor? Isn't that my job?
You thought what? You would skip a step? Not heat the metal all the way through? Useless! Now do it again.
I... I'm sorry. I just, well, the forge gets so hot and I thought....
Is that what you call it? In the Legion we would have called it [QUOTE]useless.[QUOTE] Look how brittle the metal is!
Uh, a nail?
Tacitus? What is this?
Yes, Thongvor. I'll draft the letter immediately.
Whose side are you on, Reburrus? I'm not worried about Skyrim, I'm worried about the Reach. Specifically, the part of the Reach we're standing on.
Thongvor, do you really think that's wise? I mean, King Ulfric is such a busy man, and there are so many areas of Skyrim to protect.
Ha! About time we got some more muscle in this city.
Reburrus, I need you to draft a letter to Ulfric requesting more men.
Yes, Thongvor.
The Forsworn aren't our real concern, defeating the Imperials and making sure we keep control of this city is.
Well yes, of course you had to go and mention that.
Except the ones attacked by Forsworn.
Very well, Thongvor. With the Stormcloaks here to help, the Silver-Blood family control nearly every route in and out of the city.
How goes the trade in and out of the city?
I see. Well, let's continue this discussion later then.
I, uh, I can't tell Thongvor. It's anyone's guess.
What does that mean Reberrus? Are we winning or aren't we?
Oh, right. Oh, well, things are going well enough. At least, as well as we can hope.
Oh, Talos's breath, Reberrus. Skip ahead to the good part.
I have a few very detailed missives from border patrols, beginning with Fifth Irregulars' reports on the movements of....
I want word on our campaign against the Imperials.
Yes, my Jarl.
Yes, my Jarl.
Enough! We can't imprison the very people that own the jail we would be throwing them into. The Silver-Blood family are to be left alone, am I clear?
I second that, Igmund. Who knows what that family will do for power? They could be working with the Forsworn, for all we know.
Loyal? Thongvor supports Ulfric and his Stormcloaks! We should imprison the entire family as a precaution.
What about them? They seem loyal enough.
Igmund, we need to talk about the Silver-Blood family.
Cowards, the both of you. My father would not sit idly back and wait while evil men take over his lands. We're done discussing this for now.
The safety of the city and our settlements must be our only concern, Igmund. The rest of the Reach is on its own.
And what do Legion soldiers know about the hills the Reach? And the caves that make up those hills? The Forsworn can hide and ambush every assault.
This is why I say we take the fight to them. Gather the Legion and drive those blasted beasts out of the Reach for good.
Things are bad, Igmund. Our forces are barely able to keep the Forsworn in check. Merchants are reporting the loss of more of their shipments.
Raerek, how is The Reach faring against this Forsworn menace?
Very well. I'll send a request for additional Legionnaires to protect trade to the other Imperial holds. Hopefully Solitude can spare more men.
Forgive me for worrying about the future of Markarth. The lifeblood of a city is gold, Igmund, and it doesn't stop bleeding because there's a war on.
Why do you pester me with battles we can't win? I need my steward to plan for our victory, not nag me with every ill account.
Not to mention the rebels completely control Windhelm and all of Eastmarch hold.
Of course there's a collapse in trade, Raerek. The Stormcloaks stalk every road and harass every one of our patrols.
My Jarl, we need to discuss the state of Markarth's collapsing trade with the other holds.
Too bad. That one's my favorite.
I don't buy that story, either.
Fell off the top of the cliff after a drunken party with the priestesses of Dibella.
You're lying. You're not quick enough to be a pickpocket. What's the real reason?
Mining accident, back when I was in prison for being a pickpocket.
How did you manage to cripple yourself, Degaine?
And I'm a porter with no shipments coming in. You're not getting any coin from me, Degaine.
I'm a cripple. I have a reason to be drinking.
Like you won't do different?
Give us a coin, Cosnach. You'll just spend it on cheap ale, anyway.
Sometimes I think we deserve these miserable lives of ours.
Mmmhmm.
[QUOTE]Mmmhmm[QUOTE]? I've been working with you for over 10 years, and all you have to say is [QUOTE]mmmhmm[QUOTE]?
Mmmhmm.
Another foul day at the smelter.
Don't be. We all make mistakes.
I'm sorry, I didn't realize.
I have one. A nephew. He's in prison for being a member of the Forsworn.
I'm sorry. You don't have to tell me if you don't....
Oh. Oh, I see....
I was actually just wondering if you had any family....
You want to know a secret of mine, young girl? The most effective poison to kill a man? A potion to make others fall in love, perhaps?
Bothela, I have a question....
You will. Until then, you'll taste every potion you make before you sell it.
There's just so much to memorize. How am I supposed to remember what goes where for every single herb?
No, no girl. It's the pickled spider tongue and then the decayed taproot. Do it the other way, and your cure turns into a poison.
You're right, dear. I'm sorry to worry you.
Endon, dear, please don't.... Save your frustrations for work.
I miss those days, before the Forsworn took up arms again, when you could walk the roads in peace.
Well, I'm proud of both of you. I haven't been so busy since those nobles from Solitude come into the city three years ago.
Adara bends the silver so naturally. Grandmother would have cried if she saw how deft our daughter has become.
That's right! Papa helped me with the clasps, but I did all the links on my own.
We sold all those lovely little necklaces you brought me today. Did you make them yourself?
If there's still a Legion left, Adara. I'm sure you'd make a great soldier. Just like your brother.
Can I join the Legion when I grow up?
No. I think if I was a young man, I would have done the same.
Endon, we talked about this... Are you still disappointed in Cade's choice?
Our son joining the Stormcloaks. If this war had never happened, Cade would have joined the Imperial Legion, like grandfather.
He's off fighting, Adara, with the Stormcloaks. He'll return when the war is over.
Mama, when is Cade coming home?
Good to hear. You can be a difficult man to find. Thankfully those couriers are tenacious.
Good to hear. You can be a difficult woman to find. Thankfully those couriers are tenacious.
No you aren't.
That's just terrible. I'm so sorry to hear that.
What are you, blind? That store is empty. Forsworn get almost every shipment that comes in.
I wasn't aware that Lisbet was having trouble, Cosnach. Is Arnleif and Sons not doing a good turn of business these days?
All your drinks are watered down, Kleppr. You aren't fooling me, and you know Lisbet can't afford to pay me enough for the finest drinks anyhow.
Another drink, Cosnach? A porter with Arnleif and Sons deserves nothing but the finest here.
Always such a model for decency in these troubled times, Yngvar.
Shut it, Kleppr. Thongvor isn't here, so save your kissing up for a Nord who cares.
Ah, Yngvar, here to sing? You know an employee of the Silver-Blood family is always a guest of honor here.
That's a sensible lad. Now fetch me drink.
Uh, right. Maybe just one of the popular songs, like [QUOTE]The Slaying of the Falmer Princes[QUOTE]?
Son, I know thousands of the old ballads. If I played all of them, everyone in this inn would be as grey as I am before I finished.
Playing tonight, Ogmund? Everyone here is anxious to hear the old ballads performed by the True Skald of the Reach.
Have you seen that Shrine of Azura? They say the dark elves built it after they fled from Morrowind. Sight to see.
We are children of the Twilight. Beings who are to be guided from the darkness into the light. And from the light into darkness.
Azura. Who led her children away from the disaster of Vvardenfell. You are the prophet that reveals our true future.
No harm shall come to me, for I live under Azura's wisdom. Her foresight protects me. Her insight sustains me.
My people, the Dunmer, built it. We fled from Morrowind after Vvardenfell erupted almost 200 years ago.
Those of us who were faithful to Azura were given a vision that led us away from the island before the worst came.
This shrine is our thanks to her. That none will forget that she watches over us all.
Yes. There were others at first, but Azura's visions tested everyone's faith. One by one, they left. Afraid to know their own future.
But I refuse to abandon the shrine. The visions are a gift. Azura warns me of tragedy, war, death before it happens. I won't leave her guidance.
Perhaps that is what you are meant to believe. To better serve your role as Azura's champion.
Do not fight it. Azura's prophecies always come to pass. To deny them is to go headlong into the darkness with no light to guide you.
Well, I've certainly heard worse things.
I think the man you want to talk to is Nelacar. He was exiled a few years ago, bad research. Still hangs around the Frozen Hearth.
You were given a vision? Are you serious?
Whatever. The person you probably want is Nelacar. He's in the Frozen Hearth. Be careful, he was exiled from the College for a reason.
No. I wouldn't.
Why don't you head into town and get a drink at the Frozen Hearth? I hear old Nelacar still has a room there. He knows a lot of stories, that one.
Vision? What vision are you talking about? Oh, no matter.
You should head to the Frozen Hearth and speak with Nelacar. It's his story to tell, and I wouldn't want to discredit him by talking behind his back.
You should go into town and talk to an elf named Nelacar. He was involved in the whole mess.
Yes, I did. I shouldn't be the one to tell you about this. There's an Altmer named Nelacar in the Frozen Hearth. Believe me, he'll know.
Oh no, I'm not talking about that. I'm not being blamed for saying something out of place. Again.
If you want to know, ask Nelacar. He's staying at the Frozen Hearth. Knows the whole sad story.
Almost the opposite. The College got rid of something... someone, that was too much trouble.
There's an Altmer named Nelacar staying at the inn outside the College. You should ask him about it.
Azura? Gods, it's all finally coming back to haunt me.
You're working with the Daedra? Right. Now tell me the one about the Argonian Maid and the lusty baron.
A few coins for my soul? If only you understood the irony.
I don't think you understand. I'm not answering questions.
Just calm down. I'll tell you everything.
Do you think muscling me is going to work? I'm a wizard. An old. Elven. Wizard. Think about it.
That's for the best.
What do you know about soul gems?
They are. Except the gem is always consumed. They're frail. Except for one.
That's what caused all the trouble. Soul gems are used in enchanting, but they break afterwards. Except one.
Azura's Star. A Daedric artifact that allows any number of souls to pass through it.
Some of us wanted to find out how. I was working under Malyn Varen, then. If only we knew what he was really planning.
Soul gems are the subject, friend. They're used in enchanting, then they break. Except one.
The Great War... only thirty years past and already ancient history to most people.
Seems to me like it just ended... it's never really ended for me.
But to answer your question, the White-Gold Concordat was the fancy name they put on the peace treaty between the Empire and the Thalmor.
It ended the war and saved the Empire to fight another day.
Also trampled on the sacred name of Talos, and gave the Thalmor free reign to stamp out Talos worship throughout the Empire.
No, not right now. Maybe later, if I'm still upset.
Are you going to walk over to father and start hitting him again?
Aren't you wonderful! Why can't your father be more like you and your sister?
I've been cleaning up spills and there is fresh linen for the rooms.
How are your chores coming, son?
Dibella's Heart, son, I hope not.
Will I need to talk so loudly with my wife when I get married?
We don't fight, son. We, um, talk. Loudly.
Father, why do you and mother fight so much?
Never mind your mother, Hreinn. You listen to me, and you'll be a great man one day.
That's right! Worst innkeeper in all of Skyrim!
But mother says you're a terrible innkeeper!
Ah, my son, you'll be a fine innkeeper someday, like your father.
Today I've cleaned the linens, washed the floors, and checked in on all our guests.
How are your chores coming, my son?
I am your better half. And your better half is telling you to stop being an idiot and serve the customers their drinks!
Shouldn't you be helping me then, wife of mine? Sharing my problems? Being my better half?
You were just standing there when you were supposed to be serving drinks to our customers!
What? What did I do this time? I was just standing here!
Kleppr, you idiot! Can't you do anything right?
No, just check in the guests and manage the coin and keep a roof over your head. No, nothing important.
Clean the rooms yourself Kleppr. It's not like you do anything important around here.
Frabbi, my dear loving wife, could you please clean out our guest rooms?
Not a day goes by I don't ask that question myself, my dear.
You're an idiot, Kleppr. Why did I ever marry you?
Don't worry, my love. Just show the bugs your adoring face, and they'll scurry away in complete fear in no time.
Assur had to move away because of the Empire. But we get to stay.
The mages don't let us go in the College. They said it's not safe in there.
Assur says his pa says the College made lots of bad things happen, but the mages I've seen look nice.
Assur and I are playing a game. Don't tell him where I am!
There's not many people left in Winterhold, so I only have Assur to play with, and sometimes he's mean.
Assur always wants to play [QUOTE]Hunt the Elf[QUOTE] and he makes me be the Elf.
Pa says the Empire made us leave, but the Empire just does whatever the elves tell them to.
How come you're in Winterhold? My pa says people like you are the reason no one lives here anymore.
We don't get many people like you visiting Winterhold. Usually it's elves.
My pa says elves are bad and not to trust 'em.
Did you know that most of Winterhold fell into the sea? I heard it's because of that College.
Someday I'm gonna grow up and be the Jarl.
I heard the College teaches you how to kill people with magic. Is that true?
I'm just the Housecarl. If you need something, you should speak to Kraldar.
I'm very busy, you know. I'm the only one Kraldar can rely on to assist him.
Kraldar's family was once very powerful in Winterhold. It's my honor to assist him even now.
Kraldar has big plans for Winterhold. We'd be better off if he was in charge.
Some people can't be trusted to accomplish anything that's asked of them. They don't take pride in their work.
I'm not one to complain, but I'm not sure why Kraldar insists on keeping Malur Seloth around.
My job is to serve the Jarl, not waste time talking with travelers.
Thonjolf is convinced I've got some connections at the College, so he goes easy on me.
I don't really know anyone at the College. I guess everyone just assumes I do because I'm a Dunmer.
People won't say it, but they're afraid of me, so they leave me alone.
It turns out that if people think you're some sort of secret wizard, they'll let you get away with a lot.
I'm trying to do as little as possible. You're getting in the way of that.
With the Empire's help, Winterhold will be back on its feet in no time.
There's yet hope that our relationship with the College can be repaired.
Winterhold may not look impressive, but it has a very rich history.
Winterhold was once the capital of Skyrim, you know. Quite an honor.
I'd like nothing more than to see Winterhold regain its former glory.
It's hard to recover from something like the Great Collapse, but I believe Winterhold can do it.
The College of Winterhold is truly an asset to our city... err, town.
I have a very close relationship with Savos Aren, the current Arch-Mage.
Just say the word if you need a drink or something to eat.
We may not have as much to offer as Whiterun or Solitude, but we'll do what we can to make your stay a pleasant one.
Winterhold doesn't offer much, but we like living here. Been here all our lives.
If you're here for the College, don't let the folks in town bother you. Just try and keep to yourself.
The Mages at the College keep to themselves for the most part, so we don't see much of them.
Most of our business comes from folks traveling to and from the College.
If you need a drink, just say the word.
Something I can get for you?
Turns out who runs Winterhold doesn't change much. Can't say I'm surprised.
I won't complain about Korir being gone, but I don't expect things to really be any different.
If there's anything you need, just let me know.
If you've business with the College, you're welcome to stay here. It's where most of our business comes from, in fact.
Unlike some folks here in town, we have nothing against the College or the people that come and go.
Don't worry about Nelacar. He has a permanent room here at the Inn, but he keeps to himself and doesn't cause any trouble.
Let me know if you need anything. We're here to provide.
Without us looking out for Winterhold, it's doomed. Simply doomed.
I'd rather see the Sea of Ghosts swallow Winterhold entirely than have it run by the Empire.
Ours is the only family left that truly cares what happens to Winterhold.
Korir will be the first to tell you that if it weren't for that College, we'd all be better off. I agree with him.
Winterhold might yet thrive if that College had never been built.
We do the best we can, even though we have next to nothing. But we Nords don't give up, not ever.
Assur is going to grow up to be a great man, because he'll have lived through such hardship.
Driven out of my own home. After all this, I can't believe it.
It wasn't enough that the College still stands, now the damnable Empire has Winterhold. I hope they all freeze to death.
I don't care how many Colleges they build, or how much the sea swallows up. I'll outlast them all.
You know Winterhold used to be the seat of power in Skyrim? Now it's a shell.
Few will admit it, but we know the truth about the Great Collapse.
Those cursed mages... It's their fault Winterhold is gone.
The College is the worst thing that's ever happened to Winterhold, maybe to Skyrim.
What is it now?
You want something?
Empire's in charge now, huh? Only a matter of time before we start getting bothered by them Thalmoricars... err, Justimors... Y'know, them elves.
Unless you're bringin' me another round, you can just keep walking.
I'm just trying to have a quiet drink here, all right?
It's not like there's anything to do here but drink anyway.
You ask me, not enough of Winterhold fell off into the sea.
Nothing to do here but drink till you forget you got nothing to do.
I'll sell just about anything, if it's worth my time. Keep that in mind, will you?
I do what's necessary so we can get by. Have to, since I can't count on my brother for anything.
Things are easier now that I don't have to worry about Ranmir anymore.
I still can't believe you were able to help Ranmir pull himself together.
Without all our money going to drink, I can afford to expand my selection a bit.
If you're looking for Ranmir, he's either passed out in bed, or working on winding up that way.
My brother's a good-for-nothing drunk. We'd have lost the house by now if it were up to him.
Just because we live in the middle of nowhere doesn't give Ranmir the right to drink himself into oblivion.
Ranmir has no problem drinking himself under the table, so I have to be the one to make ends meet.
I don't deal with any College applicants these days, so don't bother asking.
My days at the College are long behind me, but I prefer to stay close by.
Dagur and I have an understanding. He gives me privacy, and I make sure my experiments don't blow up his inn.
If you're here for sight-seeing, well then you've seen the sights. Might as well head somewhere warmer.
Don't worry about those Stormcloaks. You're safe from them here. As if they'd want the place anyway.
Keep clear of the College, and keep yourself out of trouble.
Hard to believe I ever complained about Riften being cold...
Take care if you're venturing too far from town. That's a bitter wind coming off the Sea of Ghosts.
Winterhold belongs to Skyrim, not the Imperials, or the Mages.
It's rotten because the wood is cheap and its soaked with ale! Now we'll have to replace all the furniture before bugs set in.
I don't know, my darling wife. I assume you're going to tell me?
All the wood furniture in this inn is rotting to the core. Do you know why that is, Kleppr?
Indeed. I... I thought you captured the Butcher.
You said the city was safe, now. How could this have happened?
Obviously. You should visit the Bloodworks to talk to Wuunferth -- we need to figure out where the evidence went wrong.
Oh, isn't that a shame. And here I am in the Bloodworks.
Looks like you aren't such a sharp investigator after all.
I'm glad you were able to correct your mistake. I'll release Wuunferth immediately.
Ysmir's beard! The man was always a bit odd, but I wouldn't have expected...
We should keep moving.
We need to get back to Jorrvaskr.
There you are.
A smart man came and told us about a blade piece.
Skjor thinks you should find it, and I'm supposed to watch you.
One of those icebrains who wanders the land getting people's hopes up.
From my view, I don't think we'll find anything here.
You'd better hope there's still a chance for you to prove yourself, though, or this Trial might last longer than you'd like.
He's a hapless beggar living in some ruins just outside the village of Ivarstead. Easy even for you.
He lives just outside Anga's Mill, in the woods. He was once the miller. Now Papius is just a paranoid recluse who thinks someone is out to get him.
And he's right.
She separated from her husband several months ago. Now the two run competing mining operations. Beitild's angry and desperate. A fighter.
He's a vampire, and has blended into human society for years. He's never far from his female companion, Hert. Also a vampire.
The contract is for the male, Hern. But you'll probably have to contend with the female, too. So for Sithis' sake, watch yourself.
He is, by all accounts, the worst bard in all of Skyrim.
Apparently so many people sought his death, Astrid had to hold a lottery to determine the client.
He's an Argonian layabout, likes to scavenge shipwrecks. My guess is he'll run if threatened. Or swim, if given the chance.
He's an accomplished wizard. And, locating him may be challenging, as he travels with the caravans.
The wood elf may run a stall in the city, but he retreats to the plains outside Whiterun to hunt. Kill him there, and no one will bear witness...
She's a maid. Old, and feeble. But with this contract it's much more a matter of [QUOTE]where[QUOTE] than [QUOTE]who.[QUOTE]
Your political affairs are your own, but any allegiance you may have in the ongoing war could very well affect your access to Fort Greymoor.
He's dangerous. Very dangerous. A rogue Dark Elf mage doing research into Dwarven artifacts should be both respected... and feared.
Just not by you.
He's the housecarl of Falkreath. You know what that means? He's the bodyguard to the Jarl himself. So be careful.
Ah, yes. The pirate captain. A ruthless she-devil, by all accounts. Deadly with a blade.
And let's not forget her crew - loyal and bloodthirsty, the lot of them.
This is my final contract, and certainly the most challenging. Be careful with this one, my friend.
No! Oh, by the gods, please no!
Oh... Oh no... Please, please... I ain't never harmed no one... Old Narfi just wants to be left alone...
Do... do you want something? Look, if you ain't gonna talk, or spare no coin, just go away...
What? What do you mean?
Oh! Oh... no... No!
Aiiiiiiiieeeeee!
Who are you? You... you're with the Dark Brotherhood, ain'tcha? I knew it. I knew you'd come for me!
And let me guess, that someone is my so-called husband Leigelf? Well the feeling's mutual.
What? Well, we'll see about that now, won't we?
I've a mine to run, so if you'll excuse me...
Well then, you won't be leaving here alive!
Ah, so the Brotherhood has come for old Hern, has it? Well then, let us meet as equals.
Hmph. Don't say much, but there's a strange aura about you. You walk in the shadow of death...
Leave here. Leave here and never return.
Ha! Oh, that's a good one, friend. Killing Lurbuk... I mean, can you even imagine something so ludicrous? Depriving the world of my unique talents?
Hmm... All right... How about this?
Shadows creep, and... and phantoms leap! A man got... he got scared. And the demons dared! To um... visit upon him all which they feared!
Brilliant, I know. It's a gift.
What's the matter, friend? Khajiit got your tongue? Maybe you need a little ditty to loosen your gob, hmm?
There once was a stranger, with eyes full of danger, he spoke not a word, but his meaning was heard... Sing on, sweet Lurbuk, sing on!
You'll have to catch me first!
Go away! I don't know who you are, but this is my spot! Whatever's on that ship is mine!
And why would you be looking for me, hmm? I'm not sure I appreciate your presence here. Friend.
Now aren't you a strange one. Well, if you're here to shop, shop. If not, find some other caravan to stalk.
Are you... threatening me? Walk away fool. It's not worth it.
Is that so? We shall see, villain. We shall see!
Well now, you are a strange one. You remind me a bit of myself, when I'm stalking a deer. I'm not quite sure how I feel about that...
But I have many more rooms to clean. Fort Greymoor is quite large, and rather filthy if I do say.
Sleep? I can't sleep now! There's too much to be done. And what's this Void you're rambling on about?
I swear, you people are an odd bunch. Please, just step aside, that I may return to my duties!
Death? Oh, there's death to be found here, to be sure.
But not my own!
Yes... quite. But if that power could be harnessed. Controlled. The possibilities would be...
But... who exactly are you? And why are you in here? I think it best you leave Mzinchaleft. These ruins can be quite... dangerous.
Who are you? Why are you here? Leave this place. I have much work to conduct....
And why would I... Oh. Oh! Guards! Guards, I need assistance!
Fiend! You will not leave here alive! Guards! Guards!
Right. Well. If you have some kind of official business with the jarl, I'm afraid now's not the time. Go on then. Off with you.
The Dark Brotherhood? Yeah, yeah, yeah. You think this is the first contract I've had on my life?
I'm a pirate, sweetie. Assassination attempts are an occupational hazard. Now, shall we?
Sithis? Let me guess: [QUOTE]In the Void![QUOTE] By the gods, you Dark Brotherhood are a predictable lot, aren't you?
Okay, here's how this works. You try to assassinate me, and I kill you. Horribly. I have done this dance before, you know.
Ah, I see. The old Dark Brotherhood [QUOTE]silent intimidation[QUOTE] treatment.
Oh, I know who you are. Don't be so surprised. You ain't the first assassin sent to kill me. Won't be the last. Now let's get this over with.
I have some thoughts. There are three crucial elements. Some may be easier to find than others.
On the top of the Throat of the World is a patch of Unmelting Snow. No heat can touch it.
Then we need the tusk of a mammoth, ground to a fine powder as only the giants know how.
The final step is tricky. It requires the briar heart from a Forsworn of the Reach.
If you can bring me these materials, the Phial can again be made whole.
You've shown yourself useful so far. All these lunks are too afraid of Haldyn to head in before the fog's cleared.
So if you're willing to perform one more service for the Company, we could put this matter behind us for good.
Take out Haldyn, and we'll handle the rest.
The one who calls himself Ancano.
He seeks information about the Eye, but what he will find shall be quite different.
His path will cross yours in time, but first you must find that which you need.
No, though you may be the last. The one who calls himself Ancano has sought my knowledge as well, through very different questions.
Your path differs from most. You are being guided, pushed towards something.
It is a good path, one untraveled by many. It is a path that can save your College. I will tell you what you need to know to follow it further.
You, and those aiding you, wish to know more about the Eye of Magnus. You wish to avoid the disaster of which you are not yet aware.
To see through Magnus' Eye without being blinded, you require his staff.
Events now spiral quickly towards the inevitable center, so you must act with haste. Take this knowledge to your Arch-Mage.
Ainethach's in charge of Karthwasten. You should bother him.
What do you want? Can't people leave us alone?
Strangers are nothing but trouble.
Karthwasten has enough problems. Leave us alone.
Ainethach's dead, but that doesn't mean we can stop working.
I work in the mines. I hunt. Everything else I do is my business.
These Reach folk are so... nosy.
Ragnar has a strong arm. Pity he isn't an Orc.
Finally, both of my mines are open again. Time for everyone to get back to work.
If the Forsworn aren't attacking my town, the Nords are trying to force me off it.
I'm one of the few native sons of the Reach that owns land. It doesn't make me very popular.
Ainethach is dead. What will happen to Karthwasten now?
I'm Ainethach's right-hand man. I help supervise the mines.
Not many Nords would work for a Reachman, but Ainethach is a good man.
The good mine is closed and the other mine has no ore. Gods have cursed me.
Sauranach mine is open again. How am I supposed to handle all this work?
You're not from here, and we don't need to be talking.
You should talk to Ainethach. He's in charge.
Don't have nothing to say to you, stranger.
Karthwasten doesn't need outsiders prying in our business.
The mine is closed. Get lost.
I've been sent by Silver-Bloods to keep this mine [QUOTE]safe.[QUOTE]
Our business is done here.
We're in control of this mine. No sudden moves.
Time to find another job.
Make them all pay for what they've done to me...
I'm not going to warn you again.
Once more and I'm going to have to kill you.
Don't do that again. Last warning.
You're pushing your luck.
What's the matter with you?
Stop that.
Watch it!
Hey, be careful!
I'm on your side!
What are you doing?
So you don't know anything about this house?
No.
Anyone seen entering or leaving? Any strange lights or unusual noises?
That's quite an accusation. I assume you have proof?
Can't stop to chat, citizen.
No time to talk. Out of my way.
Hmph.
Hmph.
Is that so?
We'll see about that.
I've got my hands full with something. Don't go far. I'll need you soon.
I'm in the middle of something. But don't go far. I'll need you soon.
Good. I can use someone I can trust.
Excellent. I have a couple tasks for you.
Good. I have some things that need doing.
Good. I'm spread thin. I could use the help.
Got my hands full as usual.
There's plenty that needs doing.
I'm disappointed in your failure. But the Empire still needs you. I'll have to over look it for now.
Turns out you're a screw up like the rest. But I still need you. So I'll overlook it for now.
With the Emperor's arrival in Skyrim now a certainty, his security service, the Penitus Oculatus, will need to begin its preparations immediately.
Security is being handled by a Commander Maro. Astrid and I have devised a plan to break the man, and in doing so, cripple the Emperor's protection.
You are to slay the commander's son, Gaius Maro, and once he is dead, plant false evidence on his body implicating him in a plot to kill the Emperor.
To earn your bonus, do not kill Gaius Maro in Dragon Bridge, or on the road. Kill him in one of the other major cities he'll be visiting.
There, the body will be discovered quickly, as will the letter implicating Gaius Maro in the plot to assassinate the Emperor.
Do that, and Astrid has authorized me to grant you a rather unique bonus. It is a special token, to be given to Olava the Feeble, in Whiterun.
Olava is an old and dear friend, and a powerful seer. The token entitles you to a reading of your future. It's an opportunity one should not pass up.
The entire town is being plagued by horrible nightmares. They're in serious danger but I'm afraid there's little I can do about it.
I need to return to the source of the problem, to Nightcaller Temple.
Perhaps you'd be willing to assist me in that regard?
These dreams are manifestations created by the Daedric Lord Vaermina.
She has an awful hunger for our memories. In return, she leaves behind nightmares not unlike a cough marks a serious illness.
I must end her terrible influence over these people before the damage becomes permanent.
Wonderful! My lady Mara will be quite pleased!
Nightcaller Temple is only a short walk from Dawnstar. Come, we must hurry.
Your concerns are understandable; trust is a very difficult commodity to come by these days.
I can only give you my word as a priest of Mara that my intentions are honorable.
Vaermina resides in a strange realm known as Quagmire... a nightmarish land where reality shifts upon itself in seemingly impossible ways.
From her citadel at the center, she reaches forth to collect our memories, leaving nothing in return apart from visions of horror and despair.
Lore holds that the Skull of Corruption holds a constant hunger for the memories of others.
The Skull has been out of touch for so long, I fear it's gained the ability to reach out on its own and try to feed.
What it does with these memories is just conjecture and an argument for scholars and historians to this very day.
You'll be viewing the memory of another through your own eyes and with your own body.
Those around you will perceive you as normal and you will find the words you utter may not be your own.
Thanks to all of these odd principles, there is quite a lot of debate as to whether this is really a dream or just the machinations of Vaermina.
I will watch over you as you slumber to ensure your safety. If I deduce anything is amiss, I will use my arts to bring you back.
Otherwise, I am uncertain what will end your Dreamstride. Perhaps when Vaermina's curious appetite has been filled.
Unless you're here to solve this nightmare problem, I don't need you.
Need a room? Don't worry. Nightmares don't seem to happen for travelers.
You come to Dawnstar at a bad time. Tempers are... fiery.
The Jarl is... tired. Be mindful of that.
These dreams are real I tell you. Real!
Can't sleep well no matter how much drink I put in me.
I envy you travelers. Dreams aren't affecting anyone not from here.
What is it? I haven't had much sleep.
If I get any rest soon, I'll count myself richer than a king.
If you're here about the nightmares, I'm afraid my pleas to the College of Winterhold go unheard.
Seems like no one is getting a decent night's rest in Dawnstar, stranger. Best buy your steel and move on.
Gods I'm so tired.
Please. I must remain uninterrupted if I am to complete the ritual. Have no fear, your time will come.
What troubles you, my son?
What troubles you, my daughter?
Yes, my son, what is it I can help with?
Yes, my daughter, what is it I can help with?
You're wrong to come here, stranger. No rest in Dawnstar.
By the Divines, I'm tired.
No. I don't have anything for bad dreams, so don't ask.
Lady Mara will save us from these nightmares. You'll see.
Wish to converse with the crazy old elf, eh? Very well. Go on.
Apologies accepted. I understand how this entire story can be mistaken for fiction since the circumstances are so abstract.
However, I can assure you that I will do everything in my power to keep you safe if you're willing to help me.
Amusing. Now if you'll excuse me, I need to continue my research. I have no time for idle chatter with any simpleton who strikes up a conversation.
Thank Mara. I was afraid I'd never be able to convince you.
Allow me to gather the materials I need for my ritual, and then I will meet you outside the ruins.
Let me take a look...
Mara be praised! There is a way past the barrier to the inner sanctum.
It involves a recipe for a liquid known as Vaermina's Torpor.
I believe there is a laboratory in the east wing. If we proceed there, we should be able to locate a sample.
Damn it. The priests must have activated this barrier when the Miasma was released.
Impossible actually. Hmm, I wonder...
There may be a way to bypass the barrier, but I must check their library and confirm it can be done.
I still have my key to the library. Whenever you're ready, let's move on.
Farewell, Brother Casimir.
Go now! The orcs could breach the inner sanctum at any moment!
Brother Thorek, we must remain here and guard this Skull with our lives if necessary.
And what about you, Brother Casimir? Are you prepared to serve the will of Vaermina?
Then it's decided.
Brother Casimir, you must activate the barrier and release the Miasma. Let nothing stop you.
Then let it be done. Farewell, my brothers!
Agreed. To the death.
We have no alternative. It's the will of Vaermina.
The Miasma? But, brother...
Then we have no choice. The Miasma must be released.
But... no more than a handful of us remain, brother.
We must hold. We can't allow the Skull to fall into their hands.
The orcs have breached the inner sanctum, Brother Veren.
These thralls of yours are slower than Argonians in a blizzard.
Feel free to grab a pick and help them out. I prefer not to sully myself with manual labor.
There goes another one.
Bah. Weak-willed rabble. Even dead they're almost useless.
They seem less intelligent each time you raise them, if that's even possible.
As long as they can swing a pickaxe where I tell them, they're as smart as we need them to be.
You hear that? The others must have found something!
We'd better go see. These can tend to themselves for a few minutes.
All right, please stay close to me while we're inside. It should be safe, but it's always better to be cautious.
Of course. And you've repaid your debt, in full.  Here's the key to the shack. But why stop here? I say we take our relationship to the next level.
I would like to officially extend to you an invitation to join my Family. The Dark Brotherhood.
In the southwest reaches of Skyrim, in the Pine Forest, you'll find the entrance to our Sanctuary. It's just beneath the road, hidden from view.
When questioned by the Black Door, answer with the correct passphrase: [QUOTE]Silence, my brother.[QUOTE] Then you're in. And your new life begins.
I'll see you at home.
The Unholy Matron, the Shrouded Lady, the Mistress of the Void. She goes by many names.
Ages past, Sithis gave a woman five children. She killed them to win his favor, thus becoming the Night Mother. If you believe that sort of thing.
Today, she's... well, she's a skeleton. An ancient corpse. But, more importantly, a corpse that's being brought to this Sanctuary by her Keeper.
Used to be the Dark Brotherhood was bound by Five Tenets, but we stopped following those years ago.
All those rules, all that discipline, and look where the Dark Brotherhood ended up. We're the last of our kind, and we live the way we see fit.
Bottom line - respect your Family. Do that, and everything else will fall into place.
They used to come from the Night Mother. Potential clients would perform the Black Sacrament, and she would hear their prayers.
The Night Mother would communicate this to the Listener, who would then dispatch a Speaker to arrange the contract with the client.
But that was a long time ago. There hasn't been a Listener in years, not since Cyrodiil was overrun in the war with the Thalmor.
But people don't know that. So they still perform the ritual... and we eventually hear about it. When someone wants us, we find out.
I don't know who you are, or what's going on here, but you ought to be ashamed of yourself.
What's happening? Damn it, what are you doing?
Get these things off of me!
Cowards! Stealing a woman from her home! For shame!
By the gods, when I get out of here you're dead! You hear me? Dead!
Aggghh! Re...lease me!
Thank you! Thank you! I won't tell anyone what happened here, I swear it!
Oh, gods, please! Let me live! I'll do anything you want!
I... I can hear you talking out there. Please, let me go. I've done nothing to you.
Is this about that raid last week? I told Holgrim there was no honor in killing sleeping men, but he wouldn't listen! It wasn't my fault, I swear!
I'm just a soldier. Killing is my job! Surely you can't fault a man for doing his job?
Please, oh please, I don't want to die...
Ah, sweet freedom. Now that's more like it. You have my thanks, stranger.
Whoever this is, clearly we got off on the wrong foot. Ah, but no worries. This is not the first time I have been bagged and dragged.
Come now. Whatever the problem, we can talk about it like civilized folk. Hmm?
Hello? Hello? Ah, I know you're listening.
A man in my position makes lots of enemies. But what is a life-threatening situation if not an opportunity for mutual benefit? Hmmm?
You'll let me go. I know you will. This is all just part of the game we play...
Yes. A few months ago I received word from the Night Mother's Keeper that he had arrived in Skyrim from Cyrodiil.
The Night Mother's crypt, in Bravil, was destroyed. A result of the chaos caused by the war with the Thalmor. That forced a relocation.
I don't know where the Keeper has been these past few months, but I recently received another letter. He's bringing the Night Mother here. Soon.
Very little. You have my word on that. The Night Mother represents a chapter in the Dark Brotherhood's history that has long since been closed.
Today we live by our own rules. We're the last Sanctuary in all of Tamriel, and only by forgoing the old ways have we survived for so long.
My only worry is her [QUOTE]Keeper.[QUOTE] I'm not sure what Cicero expects to gain by bringing the Night Mother here, but he'll soon learn this is my Sanctuary.
Molag Bal. You think you can best Boethiah's faithful? I have won this contest before!
Ah. But I have my own champion this time, Logrolf.
What? You!
Mortal. I give you my mace, in all its rusted spitefulness.
Crush the spirit from Logrolf's bones. Make him bend to me.
No more.... No more.... I submit, Molag Bal. I submit!
Don't know what that man expects. House is empty.
Untie me. Now.
No.... Not again!
No more.... No more!
Don't kill me.... I don't want to die!
I... won't... surrender!
Call... that... a... swing?
You'll pay for this....
I'll never submit!
Do your worst, monster!
I won't bend. Never!
Good. Wipe them out. So long as one of them is left alive, they will come for me!
What? How? I thought they weren't allowed within the city!
At last. I can rest safely. You have done me a great service, warrior. I cannot thank you enough.
Take this reward. I managed to sneak some of my wealth out of Hammerfell when I left. It's the least I can do.
For now, I will maintain my ruse here. You are always welcome in the Bannered Mare.
Assassins? No, nothing so crass.
[QUOTE]Saadia[QUOTE], as you know her, is wanted by the noble houses of Taneth for treason. We were hired to see her returned to Hammerfell for her crimes.
You can help us with that, and make sure no one else gets hurt.
I'd hoped we could work something out, that you would see reason.
That we could avoid having to kill you.
Very well, then. If that's the way you want to play it, we will.
She trusts you, at least to some extent. She sent you after us, and has no reason to think that you'd do anything other than that.
Convince her that we'll be coming for her, and she needs to leave. Lead her to the stables outside Whiterun.
We'll be waiting to take her into custody.
I'll gladly share a portion of the bounty in return for your efforts in seeing proper justice done.
Good. We'll be waiting for you at the stables.
It will be good to finally be able to return home.
Would you look at that!
Don't rush ahead. This is a trap if I ever saw one.
I hope your stay in Markarth treats you better.
Need to get going. What is it?
New to Markarth?
I'm shopping. Excuse me.
Oh it's you. The one from the market.
I'm sorry, I'm still a bit dizzy from everything.
The Treasury House is really just for patrons of the Silver-Blood family. You don't belong here.
I'm sorry. We're only interested in helping our patrons.
I work for the Silver-Bloods. Help clean.
Just here to work.
Looks like you weren't followed. Good.
Once you've found out anything, come straight to me.
City's got eyes. Be careful when you're out there.
I'm sorry, but you're not leaving alive.
Let me know as soon as you've found anything.
Be careful who you talk to.
Keep your eyes and ears open.
I should never have come to Markarth.
What's happening to this city?
This has ruined my entire day.
This is it! Gathrik awaits us!
What are you on about? Let's just get the treasure here and go.
Some nights I dream about the mists of Sovngarde.
When you get to be my age, you'll come to miss the smell of blood. Strange, I know.
How goes the hunting, brother?
How goes the hunting, sister?
A stranger comes to our hall.
Greetings outsider. If you have some business here, speak it.
Are you still here?
Let's not waste too much time talking when there is glory to be had.
Get a move on.
Haven't seen your face before. I'm watching you.
This is a place for warriors, new blood. What brings you here?
You still need to prove yourself, whelp.
You might make a decent Companion yet.
Are you looking for help with something? This is a busy time.
This had better be important.
You again?
What now?
I can't keep helping you with everything.
Blood on the wind today. Good hunt ahead of us.
Do you have guidance for me, Harbinger?
I've been running interference for you around here. I don't think anyone's caught on to our little campaign. Yet.
Have you been bringing the battle to the Silver Hand, friend? I wish I could be there with you. Soon enough.
I hope the hunting goes well, sister. We've got the cowards on their heels now.
I hope the hunting goes well, brother. We've got the cowards on their heels now.
I've heard you may actually be stronger than you look. Perhaps we can hunt together someday.
Don't let them intimidate you, sister. We both know how to keep our heads while the men let their hearts rule.
It's good to have another quick-eyed Shield-Sister in the hall. Come to me with any troubles.
If you wish to hunt with me, your feet need to be quick, and your eyes quicker.
Ysgramor himself wouldn't have the patience to deal with all the rabble around here.
Are you on the hunt?
Blood running hot?
You look strong. Come to Jorrvaskr and be a Companion!
Vilkas said you are the new Kodlak. I don't know what that means, but you seem honorable, so that's good.
Skjor says that I have the strength of Ysgramor, and my brother has his smarts.
Some people don't think I'm smart. Those people get my fist. But you, I like.
You are new here. I don't trust the new.
My brother Vilkas is a better talker than me. He should be around someplace.
I'm here to help.
Thinking I need to train some more.
Getting tired of hanging around talking all day.
I wouldn't have expected someone like you to be the Harbinger, but Kodlak trusted your judgment. And so will I.
Come to me with questions. I know our history almost as well as Vignar by now. Except I can remember it.
What brings you to me? Find some strange creature in your travels?
I think by now I've killed one of every living thing in Skyrim. May be time for a trip to Morrowind.
Great, another ambitious visitor. You think you can just wander in here and join us?
Did you just wander in out of the white?
I suppose you have another question?
What is it now?
You're a talkative one, aren't you.
I swear, every wanderer who shows up in Whiterun looks weaker than the last.
I always thought the new Harbinger would be taller, myself.
Ah, fresh blood. Hope you know how to handle yourself.
I never thought they would actually let me join the Companions. But now it looks like they're letting anyone in these days.
I avoid going to Eastmarch if I can. Something in the air... I think it's just too close to the border.
Are you thinking you're better than me? I crawled west out of the wasteland, so show some respect.
We are all Ashlanders now, brother. Good to find another family that cares where they came from, eh?
To what do I owe the honor?
Look, I've got training to get to.
You don't belong here. What do you think you have to offer?
I'm still trying to figure out why Skjor let you in in the first place.
If the Circle vouches for you, I'm sworn to respect their judgment. But that doesn't mean I like it.
What guidance could you offer me?
What now?
Oh, it's you.
Fight with us and you'll have stories to tell. Come up to Jorrvaskr if you're worth anything in a fight.
Here to be a Companion? Well, they just let me in, so there's probably no more room.
I was the newest Companion, until you came along. I guess that's ok. Just means I can show you the ropes!
Oh, hey there. I killed a bear yesterday. Did you kill anything?
Good to have some fresh eyes up there at the top. I follow your lead, Harbinger.
Oh, got more to say?
What's on your mind?
Oh, so you're the one in charge now? Fine, fine.
I haven't seen you before. Have I? Have we met? I'm sorry if I've forgotten.
The latest recruit! Right? Wait, is that right?
Might head down to the meadery later. See what they're brewing up. You can smell the honey on the wind.
What do you want from me, now?
You're a talker, eh?
I don't think we're going to get those potatoes to come in.
Well of course, not with an attitude like that!
The ground is practically frozen. We can't dig down far enough.
Come on, we just need a little elbow grease.
Now, I've been reading about the best ways to grow corn in permafrost...
I keep telling you, without a warming enchantment, it will never grow past your ankles.
Right, but if you plow the soil with fire salts...
Then you've salted it and nothing will grow at all. Genius.
Oh dear, I hadn't thought of that.
I'll bet this is better than trying to grow something in Morrowind, though, isn't it?
Firstly, I've never even seen Morrowind. Secondly, in volcanic soil the plants practically grow themselves.
Oh, my, I hadn't thought of that.
There are places in the world that aren't wrapped in ice, you know.
I was wondering if you had ordered the shipment of that frostwheat, sir.
Yes, but that fool Endario can't get it in. I'll thrash him when I get back to the city, don't you worry.
I wasn't wanting to get anyone in trouble, sir. Just wanting to get the new planting started, is all.
Yes, wouldn't want to miss the lush summer we have ahead.
Make sure the back fence is repaired. I swear I saw some skeevers in nibbling the leaves yesterday.
Oh, no skeevers out here, sir. They can't stand the cold.
Maybe, but the way you burn through all that wood to keep the cabin toasty, they might mistake this place for Elsweyr.
Sorry, sir. These old bones do like a bit of warmth in the evening. There's no need to make fun.
You just need to remember that there's a war on, and firewood isn't cheap these days.
So have you ever actually spoken to Captain Lonely-Gale?
By the gods, he's just a retired ship's captain.
Maybe to you, but he's just so... his story is...
He's just a guard captain. And not a very good one, at that.
How have things been with you?
I got another harangue from Torsten yesterday.
Don't worry about him. I know you work hard, and I'm the one who gets you your money.
Thank you, miss, I appreciate that.
And what about the dogs? How are those precious little angels?
Healthy and strong. Ysgramor's coat's gotten so thick, he looks fat!
Oh, that's just adorable.
Tulvur! I've just completed inspection of the farmhouse.
Oh?
It's filthy in there! Dirt everywhere, and it looks like the dogs have the run of the place.
Well, sir, it's a farmhouse. It's not going to be as clean as your house in the city.
I just know that our sailors are able to keep their ship quarters clean, and I expect the same of you.
I'll do my best, sir.
Sir, I'm going to need some better equipment if you want me plowing the frost.
Like what?
Well, some tools that aren't rusted through would be a start.
I'll provide you wood and timber to make whatever riggings you'll need.
I'm not building a ship, sir. I'm trying to make things grow.
Did I tell you I got a letter from General Tullius? They've conscripted some more archers and will need...
Sssssh! That's not something we want everyone to be hearing.
Oh, like the sleepy rebel supporters in this town are going to tell anyone.
Let's just not take the chance. We can talk about this later.
That last brigade of soldiers said there's a tall forest on the eastern edge of the White River.
Yes, but that's too close to Mixwater Mill. We don't want to get Gilfre angry at us by stealing her trees.
Well we have to harvest somewhere! This is getting absurd.
I want to make money just as much as you do, but we don't want to make the Nords angry.
Who could tell the difference?
We've got a new order in.
Is that a joke?
No! Roggi and Kjeld need some more support timbers for the mine.
I suppose Kjeld asked for the usual discount?
Well, he is the mayor.
No, it's fine. I don't mind being poor.
What about Ulfric? Did you ever hear back from him?
No, but his housecarl sent us a letter.
Why didn't you tell me? What did he say?
He... thanked us for contacting him, but said they didn't need any more lumber at the moment.
Oh.
You see? That's why I didn't tell you!
There is some good news though. I think the borders of the shrine may be smaller than we think.
Wait, so you think we'll be able to harvest some of the sacred trees up there?
Well that's just it. Some of them might not be sacred.
I'll let you explain that one to the Nords.
They have to be reasonable about it at some point.
Gemma. This town is called [QUOTE]Kynesgrove.[QUOTE] That stand of trees is Kyne's Grove. You don't honestly think you can just cut some down.
Well, we have to cut down something!
Maybe we should just admit that this is a horrible place for a mill.
I'll never understand why you're so bitter about everything.
I'm bitter because we had lives in Cyrodiil. And we came out here to be paupers.
But we choose our own path now.
And a whole lot of good that's gotten us.
Mama, when can we go play in the river again?
Not with all those soldiers all over the hold. Their horses can't see you, you know.
I know, but...
And you'll be trampled to death!
Please take the Lexicon.
It's yours now. I won't take it back. I won't.
Avanchnzel. Take it to Avanchnzel. You must take it back.
No way. I'm quick!
Well why don't you be quick about finding my book that you lost?
You need to take better care of your sister.
But she's so stupid!
She said you threw her into a goat pen yesterday.
Because she was being stupid!
Don't make me bring your father into this.
I'm going to need your help in the kitchen tomorrow.
But papa was going to take me hunting tomorrow!
Oh, I don't think you're old enough for that yet. You can help me salt the cheese curd.
Why can't Froa do it?
Because I'm telling you to.
Papa, mama's making me do kitchen work again.
And what did you say to that?
She can't tell me what to do!
There you go, son. Be your own man!
And then I told her about the vampires and how much they would pay me for her.
That is rich. What did she do?
She's a girl. She cried.
It's good to toughen her up. Not an easy world out here. Keep at it.
When do I get to go hunting?
Miss Grelod is... well she's a terrible old crone. No person could be that cruel. I think she's part hagraven.
She only lets us out in the yard once. In the morning. And she just stands there watching us.
Like I said. Hagraven.
Sometimes, when she goes to her room to work or sleep, I slip out for a bit. Noontime, every day - that's when I hit the streets.
A boy's gotta make a livin', right?
I hate her. Everyone hates her. She's the meanest person I ever met. Sometimes she even locks us in the... room.
Constance tries to stop her, and is real good to us, but it's never enough.
I ain't afraid of the old hag. Still, I wish Constance was in charge. She treats us real good.
Constance, sometimes she gives me little snacks. Which is good, 'cause we only get but one meal. Late, too, in the afternoon.
I'm a growing boy. I need as much food as I can get.
I will do nothing of the sort. You have no business here. I'm sorry, but you really must leave.
When you're able to draw a bow all the way to your shoulder.
I can do that! I did it yesterday!
Oh, really?
So can I come?
We'll see.
Have you heard about Goldenglow Meadery?
Did something happen to it?
All the apiaries... it will take years to get those bees happy again.
Do the bees need to be happy?
Of course! You can't make good mead without happy honey!
If you like mead so much, why not go live in Riften?
Oh, I wouldn't be able to help them. Their skills were given by the Divines.
Maybe you could be a taster or something.
Ah, but I can do that right here. Right now!
How are the little ones?
Oh, you know. Little Kjeld is a handful, and Froa is just so quiet.
He takes after his father, and she takes after you.
Well, that's the good and the bad of it.
I'm not sure that's a good joke to tell with women present...
But don't you get it? She thought he was a troll!
I get it. It's funny. It just might upset your wife.
Eh, let her get upset. She'll be angry no matter what I say, might as well enjoy myself.
So, Roggi, when are you going to get yourself a woman?
Oh, I'm not sure I could ever settle down like you have, friend.
Who says I've settled down?
I think this is yet another conversation that wouldn't make your wife happy.
That's just it... if she's not happy, there are plenty of other women who will be.
Oh, you old charmer.
How much do you know about the brewing of mead?
I know all there is to know about the drinking of it, and that suits me just fine.
I've been trying to figure out what makes Riften mead better than the stuff from Whiterun.
Better honey?
There has to be more to it than that, though. I wish I knew where the bees got it from.
I hear Mauhulakh is wandering again. He's after a new woman.
He's lonely. What do you expect?
No matter. You'll take care of things like you always have.
Please, let's not have it come to that.
True... we could simply make sure she never reaches Narzulbur.
That wasn't what I meant.
If he does show up with a bride, we'll have to move quickly.
Once she's with child, I will not harm her.
Is there... something else you need?
You are the Listener! You are the Listener! I have served mother well, I have!
Yes, you've made that quite clear in the past. And now we have Urog and Dushnamub because of your weakness.
They are good, loyal children.
Oh, but how can I defend you? How can I exert your will? If you will not speak? To anyone!
Yes, you. You, who shares my iron tomb, who warms my ancient bones. I give you this task - journey to Volunruud. Speak with Amaund Motierre.
What? What treachery! Defiler! Debaser and defiler! You have violated the sanctity of the Night Mother's coffin! Explain yourself!
Speak, worm!
She... spoke to you? More treachery! More trickery and deceit! You lie! The Night Mother speaks only to the Listener!
And there is... no... Listener!
They squander their father's love. We can't dally this time.
Have you scried anything new in the entrails?
She... she said that? She said those words... to you?  [QUOTE]Darkness rises when silence dies[QUOTE]?
But those are the words. The Binding Words. Written in the Keeping Tomes. The signal so I would know. Mother's only way of talking to sweet Cicero...
Then... it is true! She is back! Our Lady is back! She has chosen a Listener! She has chosen you! Ha ha ha! All hail the Listener!
Very little. It's an uncertain time.
Not for us, it isn't.
For all of us.
Come back to me when you have something useful.
He's been spending a lot of time at the graves again.
Good. The more time he pines for the dead wives, the less time he spends finding a new one.
Be careful. The spirits can speak to the living if there's a strong connection.
Excellent. Now, you must come with me. You've become a part of this. You must be present for the ritual.
In a Daedra, of course.
Now, we begin the ritual...
Why are we bothering with this?
You pathetic weakling!
What's that?
You dare summon me, Yamarz?
What? What is this?
Bah. He never had a connection with any of them beyond what his loins told him.
You don't deserve to call yourself an Orc! You're weak, you're small, and you're an embarrassment!
You let giants... Giants!... overrun my shrine. Bring me their leader's club as an offering, and I might release you from this curse!
So it will be. Malacath has spoken, Yamarz. Your path is clear.
Very well. You, outsider, come here! I want a word.
This is all your fault, you know.
I'm stuck fighting a giant now, thanks to you. So you're going to help me.
You're going with me, and you're going to make sure I don't have any trouble reaching that giant.
Don't worry, I'll make it worth your while.
Thanks to you, I've just been issued a challenge in front of my whole tribe, by a Daedric Prince, no less. I can't ignore that.
I didn't say I wouldn't fight the giant. I just said you're going to help me get to it.
Meet me outside Fallowstone Cave. You clear the way to the giant for me, and I'll make sure you get paid for it.
This giant... It's not the only thing in Fallowstone Cave. Getting to it isn't going to be easy.
You're going to clear a path to the giant, so I can conserve my strength. I'll make sure you're paid for it.
So you meet me at Fallowstone Cave, and we'll get this over with. I can have my tribe back, and you can... You can leave us alone.
If there's a chance this will save me, then I'm taking it.
I'll lead the way, but you'd better back me up.
Let's get this over with.
Maybe, but...
We're the ones he loves. Me, and you.
Bolar, I must ask you something.
Yes, child?
Have the spirits told you where I may find a wife? One who will be safe from this curse?
Oh, all things in time, my boy. All things in time.
What more do you need that Yatul and I cannot provide?
First off, we've learned the location of some rebels scouting our positions throughout the hold. Need to take them out.
First off, there's a couple of Imperials skulking about the hold. Need to cut their throats so they can't make their reports.
First off, they've got some rebels holed up in a nearby settlement. Need to clean them out so our boys can move in.
First off, there's a band of Imperials hiding in a nearby village. We're going to flush them out and put them to the sword.
First, we need to limit Stormcloak capacity and send them a not so subtle message by sabotaging a resource they claim to control.
First problem here is a pack of Imperial dogs drooling over resources stolen from the people. A little sabotage will sour the taste of that victory.
First, we have information regarding the movements of a rebel courier. We need to intercept him and confiscate his package.
First, we've learnt the whereabouts of an Imperial cur fetching documents for his master in Solitude. We need to put a muzzle on that, don't we?
First of all, one of our men was captured by rebels who refuse to surrender him. So we're going to break him out.
First of all, a son of Skyrim rots in an Imperial prison. We'll be getting him out of there soon.
First of all, I need to sew confusion and doubt through the rebel troops. I want to assassinate their commanding officer.
First, if we can assassinate their commander, we'll be able to strike them while they're busy tucking their tails between their legs.
First, our intelligence suggests one of the rebel garrisons has become disaffected. If we play our cards right, we should be able to turn them.
First off, we hear a group of Imperial legionnaires are coming around to our way of thinking. With a little encouragement they'll join our side.
First off, seems the Jarl's Steward might be vulnerable to blackmail. Need to investigate that possibility.
First off, it seems that we might be able to blackmail the Jarl's Steward. I need to find out for sure.
First on my list, is a problem with our supply caravans being constantly harassed by a giant. Need to deal with that hairy brute. And soon.
The last few supply caravans have been attacked... by a giant. As if I didn't have enough to deal with. Need that damn hairy brute straightened out.
First, I need to get a handle on rebel operations. Need to discretely liberate some documents from their headquarters.
First, I need to know what the Imperials are planning. Need to slip into their headquarters, grab plans, maps, something useful like that.
First of all, I'd like to drum up some more support from the local populace. I have someone in mind.
First of all, there's someone in particular I'd like to win over to our cause.
First off, there's an Orc hanging around causing me headaches. Something about a vision quest he needs help with.
First off, there's a damn Orc hanging around getting in the way. He's been yammering on about needing help with some kind of vision quest.
First, we're mounting an attack on the Fort. We aim to confiscate it from the rebels.
First, we're attacking the fort. I want that fort.
Secondly, some rebel scouts that have seen too much are moving through the hold. Need to take them out before they report back to their leaders.
Secondly, we got a couple of Imperial spies roaming through the hold. Need to put an end to that.
Secondly, we got more of 'em hiding in a village, using the local populace as shields. Not to worry. We can dispatch them without harming the locals.
Secondly, we plan on liberating a settlement from Imperial hands.
Secondly, I need to cripple rebel production capabilities with a little sabotage.
Next problem - Imperial thieves have, yet again, stolen an important resource.  So we're gonna take it from them permanently - by destroying it.
Soldiers win wars, but where to put them is the key. We have word of an enemy courier in the area. We aim to confiscate his documents.
And then, it seems an Imperial worm wiggles it's way back home, carrying information stolen from us. We need to steal it back.
And perhaps more importantly, I need to break one of our boys out of a rebel controlled fort.
And perhaps more importantly, we have a brother rotting in an Imperial prison. He won't languish in there long, will he now?
And we have an opportunity to slay the rebel field commander. Without a clear command structure, they should fall into confusion and disarray.
We also have the opportunity to slay an Imperial Legate. That'll put fear and confusion into those faithless dogs.
And we understand a rebel garrison is close to abandoning the resistance. We need to send them a little encouragement.
And we hear a handful of Imperials are realizing they are Stormcloaks at heart. We need to send them a little encouragement.
Next, I need a little investigating to confirm the possibility of blackmailing the Jarl's Steward.
Next, I need dirt on the Jarl's Steward. Heard there's blackmail potential there.
And then there's a tiny problem with a giant that's been raiding our supply caravans... You heard me right. A giant. Need to put a stop to that.
And then there's a tiny problem with a giant attacking our supply caravans. A giant! As if I didn't have enough to deal with.
I also would like to get a handle on what the rebels are planning - slip into their headquarters and steal their war plans.
Also, I need a peek inside Imperial headquarters, ideally lifting some documents detailing their plans. I need to know what to concentrate on.
Then there's a little matter of some recruiting. I have someone in mind I'd like to join our campaign.
I need to send someone out to do a little recruiting. There's someone in particular I'd like to join us.
And then there's this Orc who's been hanging around causing me headaches. Something about a vision quest he needs help with.
And as if that wasn't enough. I got this damn Orc hanging around, getting in the way, yapping about needing help with some kind of vision quest.
Secondly, we're mounting an attack on the Fort. I want to gain a fortified position here before we launch our final attack on the capital.
Secondly, I want to take the fort here. Having a fortified position will make it easier for us to amass men for our ultimate attack on the capital.
I need more children.
I surrender! I surrender!
Well, that's a different matter...
Oh! There's no need for that. I know why you're here. Tell Brynjolf not to worry about it anymore.
Oh! And look, I even have the payment I owed. Here, take it.
Then I thank you for showing me mercy. Here, take this coin to him. If it keeps us together, it's worth its weight.
Wha... what? Oh, it's one of you people.
So, Brynjolf doesn't even bother to show up himself anymore, eh? What's this message?
Petty threats and fist waving are not going to sway me. You people are all talk, and everyone knows it!
Pay you to protect me? You can't even protect yourselves!
Likewise. Now, I have a lot to do, so I'm afraid you'll just have to leave!
Don't fool yourself. It's only a matter of time before you people are run out of Riften.
I know who you are. You've been terrorizing the entire city.
Please, there's no need for that here. Message understood. Here, I even have the payment!
I knew when we were married, this would come between us one day. I don't want to lose what we have, so I'll pay him gladly.
You... you have my statue! What are you going to do with it?
What does he want now? I already explained to him that you can't get blood from a stone.
Look, I can't make the coin appear out of thin air. Please, be reasonable. I'll... I'll pay next month.
Are the gods angry with me?
And so have I. What's the point of paying anyway? Your outfit can't even fend for itself. I could do better tossing the gold into the sewer.
You can't scare me with your tough talk. I'm not paying you people a single coin.
Despite your mistakes, I see more potential in you than half the snot-nosed footpads that stumble their way into the Flagon.
I'm going to put my neck on the line. We need people like you in our outfit.
Judging from how well you handled those shopkeepers, I'd say you've done more than simply prove yourself. We need people like you in our outfit.
What's on your mind?
We've run into a rough patch lately, but it's nothing to be concerned about.
Tell you what. You keep making us coin and I'll worry about everything else. Fair enough?
I look forward to it.
The hags are hateful of anything which grows from the earth. They made the weapon strong against the natural world.
It's the only thing I've even heard of that could cut Eldergleam. Stick it in, give it a twist, and the stuff will just flow out.
The hags are hateful of anything which grows from the earth. They made the weapon strong against the natural world.
It's the only thing I've even heard of that could cut Eldergleam.
Eldergleam's sanctuary grove is to the east of here.
You can use Nettlebane to retrieve some of its sap.
Shall we proceed, friend?
Thank you for your kindness.
I understand. Some journeys must be taken alone. I'll be here if you change your mind.
Why do you ask me that?
Why else have they cursed me? Killed all my wives?
Perhaps it's actually a sign of their love for you. They don't want to see you with unworthy mates.
Then they should send one they consider worthy.
Patience, boy.
Don't you ever wonder, father?
All the time.
But your aunts don't even seem to care.
They are good women. They love me. You will speak no more ill of them.
I've just never heard of a midwife losing all her mothers like that.
Father, I'm worried about Gadba and Mul.
What about them?
If Ulfric's making a move for Whiterun, then we need to be there to stop him.
Draft another letter with the usual platitudes, but this time share some of your intelligence regarding Ulfric's plans. Embellish if you have to.
We'll let it seem like it's his idea.
Yes, sir.
You Nords and your bloody sense of honor.
Sir.
You don't worry about two Orc men coming into your stronghold? That they might challenge you?
They're miners. Harmless.
I've just learned not to trust luck around here.
Someday, you can have your own stronghold.
I think it may have to be far away from here.
Oh, if you're worried about me trying to meddle with you...
It's not you I'm worried about.
How is your hunting with Yatul?
We are strong. We get the job done.
I'm proud of you for helping provide for us.
Well someone has to provide around here.
What is that supposed to mean?
Nothing.
I was apprenticed to Balimund before he died. He taught me everything I know about forging armor and weapons.
Balimund pulled me out of Grelod's orphanage when I was just a child. I don't know what he saw in me, but I was glad to get out of there.
I've spent years watching his techniques and learning his tricks. Sadly, I don't think I'll ever be as talented as he was.
Catchy, isn't it?
In my youth I was a fisherman... I had a beautiful ship named [QUOTE]The Brawny Prawn.[QUOTE] But the years have a way of creeping up on you.
I ended up selling that ship to open this place. Seemed only fitting to name it after her. Well, changed it a bit I suppose.
If I had been smarter, I would have kept my boat. Coming to this city was a big mistake.
Would you mind helping me with the demonstration? Are you at all familiar with ward spells?
Well, then this should be no problem at all for you.
That's what this lesson is for. Perfect time to try it out.
That's all right. I can teach you a very basic ward, one that's enough for the purposes of this lesson.
Now, if you'll just stand right over there, I'll cast a spell at you, and you block it with the ward. Here we go.
Shhh!
Leave me alone.
I'm trying to pay attention.
After I've finished showing you the grounds, we can talk.
Welcome to the College.
How do you think we should spend the remainder of our classroom time?
If you have any further questions, can you please hold them until I've finished?
Greetings. Welcome to the College of Winterhold.
If it's true, and you do have the Voice, would you mind showing me? I've never seen it first-hand.
Much knowledge lies within the College's walls.
The College is an asset to Skyrim, even if it goes unnoticed or unappreciated.
Winterhold's glory days may lie behind it, but the College lives on.
No matter what, the College will endure.
I don't know what your aunts told you, but...
They're not my aunts. They're your aunts. And they told me enough.
What are you talking about?
About how the Divines cursed you. What horrible thing did you do to deserve it?
Nothing! I... it's ill fortune. That's all.
Well, your ill fortune means I have no mother.
What I am doing is none of your business!
Why are you here? Did you follow me?
I demand that you leave at once and never speak of this again.
It is none of your concern, I assure you. Just... Forget that you ever saw me here.
I am under no obligation to tell you anything. Now, leave me at once and never mention that you saw me.
Is that so?
I should have expected as much. Fine, I shall give you 200 gold, and you shall leave me in peace.
Now go, leave me to my work.
Thank you. I will not forget this.
Ah, Falion. Always looking where he shouldn't for things he doesn't need.
What has he done now?
I've never trusted him... what has he done?
I... I'm sorry.
Haven't I always been a good father? A good chief?
Yatul and I do all the hunting. Mul and Gadba do all the mining. It seems like all you do is find more wives to get killed.
That's not fair, now.
Ah, so it is not just dreams then. I have seen this.
I will see that it is dealt with. Thank you for bringing clarity.
Is that so? Well, I'll make sure that's taken care of immediately.
It's good that you brought this to my attention.
I see. If something does happen, you know where I am.
Either this is some kind of a joke, or you're keeping something from me.
Whichever it is, I don't like it.
Falion, I am disappointed.
I'm told that you're up to something out in the marsh, Falion.
What is the meaning of this?
You've been exploring places you shouldn't, and you know it.
I don't even want to know what it is you've been doing.
It stops at once, or else there will be consequences of an unpleasant nature. Do you understand?
It doesn't happen again, or else I'll have you thrown in jail. Clear?
I... Yes, I understand.
There's a... A problem, yes.
I'm worried about Idgrod, and I don't know what to do.
Yes, but... not so loud!
